Today is Bhagavad Gita Jayanti, on this day Bhagavad Gita was spoken by Shri Krishna to his beloved friend & disciple Arjuna. It is one of my most favorite books, & has guided my life since my teens. Here are 3 reasons why I think everyone should study (not just read) the Bhagavad Gita with a teacher

Three reasons why everyone should study the Bhagavad Gita

1) It is highly relevant to the times we live in

It was spoken right in the middle of a battlefield. The battlefield symbolizes chaos & confusion of life. As the world becomes increasingly chaotic & confusing, & as our mental health gets challenged just like Arjuna’s, I feel its message is more relevant now than ever before

2) It takes into account different mindsets & attitudes

It is not a one-size-fits-all scripture. It accepts that individuals are different, with varied mindsets, attitudes and beliefs, dictated by predominance of Gunas in their personality. In this sense Bhagavad Gita is empathetic & speaks directly to each one of us

3) It provides various modalities that can be tailored to different mindsets

It seeks to answer the problem of suffering, & provides a variety of solutions keeping in mind the varied mindsets humans have. The solutions it provides are graded & can be tailored to the mindset one brings in to the Yoga path

This thing called ‘Ego’ gets a lot of flak. There’s so much ‘Ego’ anxiety in Yoga world, that I’ve met many who unknowingly end up rejecting their current state of self, labeling it as (bad) ‘Ego’, to desperately seek some (good) ‘True Self’ out there, somewhere. Such self-rejection births Spiritual Bypassing & I’ve often been told by Yoga skeptics that Yoga encourages spiritual bypassing

Beyond its popular understanding as self-conceit, ‘Ego’ is nothing but the “I” or the self of a person. It's neither good nor bad. Rejecting, hating, or denying the self by labeling it as bad ‘Ego’ creates an inner division that is constantly at war with itself

In last night’s panel discussion on Bhagavad Gita, I spoke about this very topic

Yoga is deeply rooted in acceptance of how & where one is. The entire 1st & start of 2nd chapter of Gita details Arjuna’s dismal mental state. If Yogic tradition wanted us to look away or deny present reality, then such incidents wouldn’t have been stated

Arjuna neither rejects his confused state, which could have been spiritual bypassing, nor does he fake a positive stance, which could be seen as toxic positivity. He is neither embarrassed by his sorry state, nor does he feel shy in front of his Guru & friend Krishna. Arjuna embraces his ‘Ego’ totally, & in this totality he is humbled to seek the counsel of Krishna

In Itihasa - Purana (the epics) one finds many brave men & women, including Gods like Rama & Krishna, going through their own challenges with complete acceptance of their current state of self. Even Bhakti tradition is full of incidents of sadness, suffering, guilt, regret, the so-called, ‘shadow emotions’

There can be no transformation in denial. If one rejects current state of self, as bad ‘Ego’, then one is rejecting self-transformation itself, cuz’ there can be no transformation without recognition & acceptance of the self (lower self)

Yoga is a path of accepting the current, limited self, & realizing the True-Self hidden within it. A blanket rejection of the limited self as 'bad Ego' will only cause division & anxiety

Relax, embrace your current state of self, the 'Ego', & transform mindfully, with empathy & faith

I love hugs, giving & receiving. I've often wondered, what if all philosophies & practices of Yoga that we try (struggle) to engage with lead to an embrace, a warm comforting hug? 

What if all our spiritual pursuits, challenges & stresses end in a cuddle, a gentle loving cuddle? Beyond terse philosophies & rigid notions of spirituality, what if it all is just a big sigh, a deep rest of sorts in the comforting  arms of the Divine? My Yoga is making me sink deeper in to those arms, more n' more..

So many mystics, across cultures have expressed their highest spiritual state as a loving embrace from the Divine. The 13th century Yogi Saint, Sant Jnaneshwar expresses his most profound spiritual experience as “shevati vishwarupe mithi det Hari”, meaning, at the end I was embraced by the universal Lord Hari”. Then, we have the 17th century mystic, Saint Tukaram exclaiming lovingly his spiritual enlightenment as “prem rase baisali mithi”, a cuddle filled with nectar of Love

On the other side of the world, we have the Christian mystic, Saint Angela of Foligno of the 13th century, presenting her enlightenment as “The embrace of God that produces a light so great that the soul understands the fullness of God's goodness, which it experiences in itself”. Or, the Sufi mystic, Jalalludin Rumi, expressing his unconditional love for the beloved by saying “In the orchard and rose garden, I see your face. In the shadows of passion, I am embraced by your love”

Truly, a Bhakta (devotee) doesn't care for transcendental experiences. The devotee, in their love for the Divine, manifests the profundity of enlightenment in the here & now. There is nowhere to go & no place to reach for the Bhakta. While philosophers argue & the skeptics debate about what it is & how it is, the Bhakta experiences it right in the heart through total surrender & unashamed love of the beloved Divine. Divinity is always embracing us, we just have to acknowledge it & melt in it. Why struggle when you can snuggle? 

Hug somebody warmly today
Assure them with a gentle touch
Comfort them with a cheerful smile
Our world needs more of it now then ever 

I send you all comforting Hugs 🤗

All that I am is because of him 

Today is a very important day for Yogis in India, it's Dattatreya Jayanti, the day of Lord Dattatreya who is considered the ‘Guru Principle’ – Guru Tattva. He is the primary deity of most renunciate ascetics, Yogis & Sadhus. This ‘teacher of teachers’ is so important that even the incarnating Gods go to him for knowledge

He cannot be understood as a concept, only as consciousness. One can only cognize him by becoming him. He is the original anti-authority of Yogic culture, taking all concepts & turning them on their head for us to emerge out of our minds. As a principle, he is the Avadhoot of Tantrics, the Aulia of Sufis, the holy-fool of Christians & the crazy oracle elder of the indigenous tribes of the world

He makes the seeker challenge norms, breaks their mindset & unwrap what lies within. Only beyond mind does his domain begin, if you can get there through self-effort & grace, you are welcome, or else, find yourself someone else

He is a strict disciplinarian, yet his love is as tender as that of a mother’s hug. He does not molly-coddle, yet his is the most secure lap to rest your head-on. He topples every ladder, he demolishes every structure that emerges from the recesses of mental constructs, that’s how he works. Words, language, scriptures & holy books squirm at his feet for he is beyond any tangible expression. He is represented as a wanderer ascetic yet he is the stable foundation of Yogic knowledge system. He is only accessible through Tapas, no non-sense view of life, sharp intellect & naked devotion of a loving heart

He inspires through perplexing ways, he teaches with the strictest of discipline, he guides with a keen eye of a parent and he supports with unconditional love. In this sense, he truly is the Guru of the Gurus

Where will you find him?, only in your heart. How will you reach him? only by strongest of Vairagya - dropping all that you are not. Silence is his expression, solitude is his abode. He is never in the grey, yet you find him when you go beyond the black and white

My salutations to Datta Guru, today & always. Thank you for holding my hand & showing me the way 🙏🏽❤️

I am in love with ageing. Yes! I am truly enjoying watching this body age. Like a curious child I am amazed at how the body complains at efforts that it once managed with youthful zest. It’s quite an eye-opener to notice how hard it is to drop body-fat now as compared to my competitive bodybuilding days. I chuckle at the fact that I can’t manage activities & effort that were a breeze just a decade ago. I enthusiastically wait to regrow my beard every few months just to be surprised by the growing number of grey hair, &, above all, the gradually receding hairline, the ever growing crows feet, the sagging skin, the faintly crackling joints, they all have become my besties now. I deeply appreciate how my ageing body has made me value it even more & made me disciplined towards maintaining what I consider my physical ‘home’ for now…

In Hatha Yogic terms the body is addressed as a Ghata, a baked clay pot. The pot is said to ‘house’ contents only for a certain time period. For me, it’s beautiful to see how life entered this pot some decades ago, how life is ‘life-ing’ itself through the years, & how the pot endures on despite the bruises & batterings.

In due course, a day will come when this pot will crack & the life within it will be released. Then, life will ‘life’ itself someplace else - in another residence. I await with curiosity to go through that beautiful process of Death,  the time when this pot will eventually break. Life will go on, repeatedly housing itself in temporary accomodations that are beyond my idea of I, me & myself, & even beyond my concept of 'my body'.

So sacred is this ritual of Life n' Death for me that being alive has itself become my prayer. 

We all are ageing, willingly or unwillingly. I choose to age willingly with total acceptance of what life presents in its journey, from one pot to the next.

We all would like to know where we stand on the Yogic spiritual path, wouldn't we?

Unfortunately, there is no fixed scale to measure spiritual evolution per se. Though the scriptures give various schemas, they often come across as vague. This is because, ideally, in the Yogic tradition, the Acharya (teacher) or the Guru (spiritual guide) ascertains how the student is doing on the scale of spiritual progression. If one ends up analyzing oneself, there is a chance of subjective bias (both negative & positive bias).

In spite of the above limitations, here is a simple 4C scale of Yogic self-assessment that I usually prescribe. It can give you an approximate idea of how you are doing &/or how far you have come on your Yogic spiritual journey.

These 4 Cs are 4 important variables that gradually refine as we grow on the Yogic spiritual path. They are,
• Calm
• Clarity
• Contentment
• Compassion

Ask yourself these questions,
1) Is my mind calmer than before?
2) Am I clearer in decision-making now than before?
3) Am I more content than before?
4) Am I more compassionate towards myself & others?

*here, ‘before’ could be any time period you wish, eg: 6 months, 2 years, 10 years, and so on.

You could go beyond Yes/No answers and attempt to elaborate on each answer to get a descriptive view of your progress. All the best. 

Remember, the idea of this exercise is not to be self-critical but to get an objective view of where one stands. Be gentle & patient on the path 

Feel free to share.

Social Media can get overwhelming. A decade ago, I too suffered from Social Media burnout, since then I decided on the following

I am often asked what’s my Social Media Strategy. Well, I don’t have any. Instead of Strategy, I choose to focus on Clarity. Sharing my clarity here, feel free to use the tips in your context

Number 1: Clarity
I do not consider Social Media to be evil. It’s like any other resource that needs to be regulated. So, be clear about why you are on it. The more clarity you have, the lesser the overwhelm & time waste

Number 2: Limiting Usage
Unbridled usage can drain you. This is why clarity matters. Once you have clarity, the next step is limiting usage of Platforms & Time. In my case, I am active only on Facebook & Instagram. I do not do Twitter, Snapchat, TikTok or even WhatsApp. Limiting my usage has cost me a lot of friends & also a lot of work/business, but I am fine with sacrificing that for my sanity. I also do not use it for a few months a year when I am away for my yearly silence

Number 3: Education
I use Social Media as an education tool primarily for 3 of my main educational interests
a) Exercise Sciences
b) Finance & Economics
c) Interior Designing

Number 4: Expression
For me, Social Media is a tool of expression. I express my joys, sorrows, happiness, traumas & my Yogic learnings through my posts. I especially focus on my Yogic journey in hope that my sharing helps others

Number 5: Promotion
Social Media helps me promote my work. Learning to do this has been a journey in itself, but now I am comfortable. I know many find this part daunting 😮‍💨 but I want to assure you, if you keep up with it, one day it won’t feel as tough

Number 6: Distraction
I use it as entertainment & distraction. I enjoy silly memes & animal videos, especially those of dogs. I also enjoy annoying others by forwarding them silly memes & loveable animal videos 😄

Most Importantly – Social Media can make us think about ourselves & how others respond to us way too much. This could make us assign exaggerated self-importance to ourselves 🤣 So, its imperative to step back once in a while to look at ourselves in isolation of trends & popular notions

On Earth, we find species of flora and fauna that are endemic (native) to one particular ecosystem out of many forest and ocean ecosystems. This is what makes them unique and deserving of protection.

Just as a species of plant or animal would be native to one particular ecosystem, Yoga, as a spiritual-intellectual body of knowledge, too has emerged out of one such cultural, traditional ecosystem for over past 2 millennia.

Yoga is a living tradition – it is not a fossil. People in the Indian sub-continent still live Yoga, and not just do Yoga.

Like myself, I know many Yoga seekers & Teachers who are passionate about environmental conservation. What if we extend the same sensitivity and consideration towards conserving a cultural ecosystem like Yoga ?

This is why, I believe, it becomes incumbent upon every Yoga Teacher, who borrows freely from the extensive corpus of Yogic tradition, to be a little more sensitive, responsible, considerate, and curious about Yoga’s cultural, geographical, historical, and traditional roots.

Yogic innovations in context of the time we live in are welcome, but not at the cost of erasing the original intent of Yoga.

If we, as Yoga teachers, don’t recognize our Moral Duty towards conserving the cultural & traditional roots of Yoga – the essence and ethos of Yoga will keep getting dumbed down, diluted, and ultimately destroyed – akin to a forest ecosystem that is destroyed due to deforestation and disregard for its components.

Please reflect 🙏🏽

Lets get a few things straight,
1) We are all born with Karmic baggage
2) Life experiences make Karmic baggage heavier or lighter
3) No one's going to carry our Karmic baggage for us, we have to do it ourselves
4) To lug around Karmic baggage through life or to lighten up, is a choice
5) We can lighten our Karmic baggage by living Life as a conscious process of Lightening Up. This is Yoga
6) Sort it out here, before you get out of here. Resolve before you dissolve

.
Let life take away everything from you,
everything that you are not.
So it can make you realize
what you truly are, and always were.
Don't be afraid of letting go.
Your power of letting go is your prosperity.
Remember Shri Krishna's promise in the Gita
"undisturbed peace follows letting go...."
(tyāgāt shāntih anantaram)

The intent of this post is not to undermine popular modalities but to give a broader view of diverse traditional Yogic practices that have existed for hundreds of years

In modern times, Yoga is so closely identified with āsana-prānayāma that its impossible to even imagine Yoga without them.The ‘āsanization’ of Yoga & physicalization of Yogic practices is a fairly recent turn in Yogic history 

It might come as a surprise to many that even today most Indians practice Yoga (knowingly or unknowingly) without even doing āsana or pranāyāma 

Traditionally, āsana-prānayama were modalities used primarily by renunciate monks to calm the mind & bring it to a state of samādhi. But, spiritual aspirants who were not monks & lived in a family unit as house-holders (grihastha) have used other modalities that served the same purpose 

I have seen my mom do her sādhanā every single day without fail. Each day she would read her scripture (swādhyāya), chant her mantra (japa) & pray devotedly at a specific time. My dad, who was not so religious, would neither do scripture reading nor chanting, but I never saw him miss his japa-meditation, which he would dedicatedly do twice a day. I am sure those who come from Indian households too have witnessed such scenes at home, right ? 

If you go to smaller towns in India, you see people of all ages sit around a tree & do bhajan (devotional singing) or pāțha (group scripture reading) every evening. Every morning one can see devotees go to their respective temples with flowers, or to the river for holy dip & do ‘Sun Salutation’ – mantra prayer to the Sun (not the physical exercise). 

Most families (house-holders) will light a lamp at their home altar at sundown & do prayer (ārati) & charity (dāna) like feeding people or animals everyday. Then, there are weekly/yearly pilgrimages (yātrā), & community talks (pravachan) etc. These practices work on the practitioners gradually over the years serving exactly the same purpose as āsana & prānāyāma does for monks

Why am I saying all this? Because our definition of Yoga practice guides our growth in Yoga. If our definition of Yoga is narrow, our transformation through Yoga too will be partial

.
As curtain falls on another year,
raising frenzy of new year resolution.
I look within myself now,
and plan my new year dissolution.
I appreciate my well wishers.
I thank my detractors.
I am grateful for my failures.
I am learning from my loses.
I embrace my agonies.
I rejoice in my ecstacies.
I cherish my loved ones.
I realize their transience.
I relax in the ignorance that I have.
I recognize the contradiction that I am.
I deal with what I can't.
I accept what I must.
Holding my heart a lil' closer,
with sincerity and trust.
As earth goes round the sun again,
I look for that me which still remains.
And once again I make a resolve,
to surrender and dissolve.

This post is not a flex, it’s an invitation to reflect on our wants & habits
 
When Amol Ghag & I went to Sivananda Ashram to do Teacher Training some 20 years ago, we had an interesting experience. During registration, we saw many non-Indians (foreigners) carrying odd type of mats. We had gone to the Teacher Training without a Yoga Mat (can you imagine!!😀) because we didn’t have a concept of Yoga Mat back then. We had no clue what others were carrying. It didn’t look like usual sports mat that we knew of. On enquiring we got a stare down from the receptionist who said, "What, you didn’t bring Yoga mat?" 
 
We rushed to Trivendrum city from the forest ashram & managed to buy something that came closest to a ‘Yoga Mat’. I paid 75 Rupees (US$1) for it back then. Thus drumrolled the Yoga Mat in my life. It has been the only Yoga Mat I have bought till date
 
I had never used what we know as Yoga mat till then. We used bare floor or handwoven straw mat called chatāi for asana & meditation practice. It was comfortable, basic, & enough. Even today, for my asana, pranayama & dhyana practice at home I use bare floor or a folded cloth mat.Traditionally, those were the things Yoga practitioners have used & many still do
 
I am definitely not hinting at not using a mat, it is a personal choice & its usage depends on the weather etc. I am also not against spiritual merchandise. I understand how & why retail has become an essential component of Yoga Business Model now

But, how much is too much & how much to feed our psychological vaccuum with material stuff to feel 'spiritual', needs to be thoroughly examined. At times advertorial provocations make us believe that a range of merchandise is essential to grow spiritually. Social Media too triggers our FOMO & competitiveness. Yes, some items do help but they are incidental, the core component is self-motivation. Without self-motivation spiritual merchandise becomes just another external dependence. So, don"t let means become an end
 
Remember, Bodhi Tree didn’t make a Buddha out of Siddharta Gautam, his determination & sincerity did

Truly, we need very little to realize lasting peace & that peace is not in material stuff

As a lover of Christ, Christmas is close to my heart. Have been celebrating it at home since I was a kid, thanks to my mother’s enthusiasm. Sharing 3 qualities of Christ that inspire me deeply

1) Jesus Loved: Mark 10:21 says when Jesus looked at a young rich man, he loved him.This was Jesus’ attitude towards all (unless he had some specific lesson to deliver). Jesus loved his followers tenderly. The stories of Martha, Mary, Lazarus warms my heart & makes me tear up every time I read the Bible. [Ref for study, John 11.3,5,11,36]. Jesus loved not only his friends but his enemies too – this was the power of his unconditional Love. The 3 Johannine texts, John 3:16, 13:1 & 13:34 make it clear. For me this power of unconditional Love is a huge source of inspiration

2) Jesus Respected their Freedom: In the ways of a true teacher, Jesus did not force his opinions on others, he respected their freedom to agree & disagree. Yet, he is hopeful & says, “You will know the truth & the truth will make you free” (John 8:32). If they disagreed, he was sharp & objective enough to justify his side of argument along with citations & demonstrations. He does not over-simplify the path but gives honest insight & says "This teaching is difficult, who can accept it?". When many of his disciples start turning their back on him, he asks the others “Do you also wish to go away?” (John 6:67).This reminds me of Shri Krishna’s advice to Arjuna at the end of the Gita where he tells Arjuna to do what he feels is right. Spiritual pursuit indeed demands whole hearted commitment to the path  

3) He Challenged Them: Spiritual guides like Jesus challenge listeners eg: Mark 19:17, Luke 18:18. Opening to our own inner light is difficult, requires ruthless changes. Jesus challenges the mind-set of his listeners & asks them to change their ways, to go & sin no more (John 5:14), to wash each other’s feet (Mark 3:4), to love one’s enemies (Luke 6:27) & to serve God rather than wealth (Luke 16:13). No true spiritual growth can happen without going through the hardships of challenging & surmounting our limiting mind-set

May this Christmas bring cheer to the world beyond our mutual divisions & discomforts

We all have faced rejection in our life. But life of Christ is one of the biggest example of rejection. It was this rejection that prompted Jesus to remark “a prophet is not without honour, save in his own country, & in his own house” – Matthew 13:57

Incidentally, all episodes of rejection culminate at the end of Jesus’ mortal life into one of his greatest teaching, the teaching of forgiveness

Forgiveness is the other side of Love. Love & forgiveness go hand in hand. Life of Christ shows that love of God resides in our Being & expresses itself through forgiveness 

Our life is mired by experiences of resentment. Bitter experiences of past have power to stir our present. Resentment multiplies when held close.The solution to this is forgiveness

Many times we do not even know that we have the power & capacity to forgive. But the power to forgive is one of the strongest powers we have. This power has the capacity to lighten the burden of past

The power of forgiveness is not just for forgiving others but also for reconciling with our selves. We have a habit of holding a lot of self regret & guilt which manifest as self punishment. Remember, we have the power to forgive ourselves too & start anew without the baggage of past

Christ’s own life & death was a great example of forgiveness. After being rebuked, scourged, ridiculed, spat upon, beaten & cruelly crucified, Jesus still had the capacity & resilience to forgive those who subjected him to such heinous treatment. The immortal words “Father, forgive them, for they do not know what they are doing” still guides many to work on forgiveness

Forgiveness is empowering not only for oneself but also for the other. When you forgive, the karmic bond binding the two losens up

If somewhere in the corner of your mind you feel a need to forgive or even ask for forgiveness, be brave & do it. Let this Christmas be the start of a reconciliation process with those who we hold grudges against, & that includes ourselves

Let us forgive, forgive lovingly & openly. Forgive others & above all, forgive ourselves

Pic: Me, lighting a candle & seeking forgiveness at The Church of Nativity, Bethlehem, in 2013

It’s that time of year when we rush to make New Year Resolutions. It’s good to have goals and pursue them, but we need to be aware of a few things here

For decades I used to make New Year resolutions out of a sense of inner lack. My low self-esteem would unconsciously compel me to raise bench-marks so high that they would be beyond my reach. The lesser I felt about myself, the higher the bench mark would be. I would strive hard, give it all that I had got, but would either exhaust myself or inadvertently give up and fall into the puddle of guilt and resentment. Every New Year Resolution would thus result in lowering my confidence and my sense of inner lack would sink further

Using the wisdom of Yoga philosophy helped a lot to resolve this issue. I learned the secret of Small Steps – to create goals not to fill the inner void of low self-esteem but for the sheer joy of experiencing a newer dimension of myself

Here are some realizations and reflections that have helped me, hope they help those who are in similar situation

1) When I would catch myself rushing to set new goals, I would ask myself, ‘What’s the rush?’. This would help me pause, reflect on my impulsiveness and be patient 

2) Don’t do what you don’t enjoy. If you have to do it anyway, learn to enjoy it, or be clear about that fact that you have to do it even though you dont enjoy it

3) Before setting goals be very, very objective about your circumstances and capabilities. Be realistic and deeply reflect on the impulse and sense of lack that’s making you set goals. Your goals should be ‘your's’, they should neither be compelled by social trends nor be pushed by peer pressure, especially stuff of social media

4) Realize that you cannot achieve everything all the time, there is no need to have everything or please everyone. You don’t have to be perfect, you just have to be your self

5) Above all, remember that every long journey is made up of smaller steps. You can realize lofty goals by breaking them into smaller parts and pursuing them joyfully without anxiety

Take it easy, easy does it

8 Scriptures every Yoga Student must study👇🏽

1) Bhagavad Gita with Shankara Bhashya
2) Sankhya Karika of Ishvara Krishna with Kaumudi of Vachaspati Mishra
3) Yoga Sutra with Vyasa Bhashya
4) Dasbodh of Samartha Ramdas
5) Tarka Sangraha of Annamabhatta with the Deepika
6) Sarvadarshana Sangraha of Madhava Acharya
7) Vivekachudamani of Adi Shankara Acharya
8) Tantraloka of Abhinava Gupta

Of course, this is not an exhaustive list. These are some texts that have benefited me immensely, so suggesting here. You can make your own list
 
Scripture study (Swadhyaya) is the life-breath of a sincere Yoga student who seeks to grow, intellectually & spiritually

Remember, these are not books, they are scriptures (Shastra). They are neither bedside reads, coffee-table books, nor recreational flip throughs. They are profound documents of wisdom that promise release from a tormenting mind. They need to be studied, not just read

The 15-year time frame is my generous guestimate if one studies diligently every day. It could also take more time. Also, study of scriptures is never a one time study, revisions are a must
 
If your mind goes - what?? so much time? 15 years?? then, please reflect on how the mind is in a hurry to accumulate knowledge

Knowledge transfer in Indic spirituality happens patiently & experientially. Also, 15 years is not much when you realize that scripture study (Swadhayaya) is a life-long endeavour, to be carried on until the subject matter is realized within fully

If an intellectual study is not followed through with Sadhana, one becomes like the Donkey, as mentioned in Sushruta Samhita (an important Ayurvedic text) which says, 

“the actions of a person who has studied scriptures without making clear exposition of them are useless like the efforts of a donkey that carries a load of sandalwood without ever being able to enjoy its pleasing scent”

Give yourself next 2 decades to study these texts deeply under the tutelage of teacher/teachers, & live the philosophies & methodologies through your life & your Sadhana

Live a little lighter in the mind & leave the world a little better than what you came into - your Swadhayaya will help you do that

A few years ago, after my workshop in Belgium, one participant approached me looking visibly confident and radiant. 

He said, 
"I stopped doing Yoga 10 years ago because I had an injury while doing postures. My teacher back then repeatedly used to say "push" your limits in the pose - and, one day, my body just gave up. I couldn't push anymore as I injured myself doing a pose."

Smiling ear to ear he continued, "Today, I came to this workshop reluctantly, with a little fear. But when you said "explore your limit" instead of "push your limit" I felt confident and reassured. Thank you, I will start doing Yoga again regularly."
.
Dear friends, your āsana practice is a doorway to numerous subtler discoveries that await your attention. As we move through our body in āsana practice, our mind has an opportunity to become still. A still mind takes us beyond the web of set notions of how an āsana should be or how it should look like.
.
When our awareness is set free of such predetermined notions of perfection, it is given permission to explore the subtle universe beyond notions and ideals. When the awareness dives deep into the subtle, inner universe through an āsana, one organically starts exploring aspects beyond physicality. 
.
Remember, 
Yoga is a discovery, not a destination.
Yoga is an exploration, not perfection.
Yoga is a process, not a pose.
.
This subject matter will be dealt with in detail in my upcomming workshop called "Rethinking āsana"
.
Watch this space for details, soon.

I do Yoga, therefore I am a Yogini (or Yogi). Such correlation would be too simplistic to grant ourselves the title of a Yogini (or Yogi). Sharing something specific (but in a simplified way) about what a ‘Yogini’ is in Indic tradition

Yoginis are common to Hindu, Buddhist & Jaina traditions. It’s an honorific bestowed upon women Yoga (Tantra) practitioners by a traditional lineage after achieving a certain state of spiritual mastery. It’s also a name for girls, but that’s not the point here

Yoginis extend across spectrum – from advance practitioners in physical body, to elevated masters optionally in it (not necessarily a human body) & ones that are demi-goddesses/goddesses

All 3 have supernatural powers (Siddhi) to manipulate 5 elements. They are guardians of secret teachings & disseminate spiritual/mystical knowledge according to level of the seeker. They are known to be fierce teachers, disciplinarians, very hard to please & mostly perceived as sorceresses (esp. as Dakini). Propitiating them requires mature levels of detachment (vairagya) & sacrifice (tapas). Tales of wrath of Yoginis are common in many secret (guhya) Tantra Yoga sects (kula). Depending on sadhaka’s spiritual level, Yoginis manifest as objective or subjective phenomena. At times they (as Dakinis) literally handhold a sadhaka through advance levels of spiritual practices (esp. pranayama) by guiding movements of their inner geography, throwing challenging circumstances at them or facilitating teacher-student meetings in dream or awakened state

In Hindu Goddess worship, Yoginis are attendants of Durga, & also her warrioresses. Shivapurana describes how Yoginis fiercely attacked King Daksha after Sati sacrificed herself. 64 Yoginis also are experts at 64 Kalās (skills), esp. alchemy (Rasāyanavidya). Embodying them makes one materially complete. There are elaborate, long term studies & sadhanas to manifest them within. At times they are also linked to the power of speech (Vāk shakti), with a Yogini (Mātrikā) guarding each phoneme of Sanskrit alphabet. In one Tantra scripture, Yogini is specifically defined as the one who resides in the bliss of self, beyond the bondage of spiritual ignorance

2022 was extremely challenging, with so many deaths, personal losses, existential triggers & mental breakdowns around me. But, the Yogic teachings sailed me through this year too. 

I have come to know so many of you this year through Instagram & am so deeply inspired by your knowledge, your sharing, & the ways in which you navigated life challenges. 

I am a recluse. Its not easy for me to make friends or even start conversations. I prefer my own company & truly enjoy it. So, somewhere around February, I decided to put myself out there through my Instagram Posts to challenge my reclusiveness. In return I've received so much love that I can't even express. 2022 was my year of inviting my readers to reflect & deeply introspect on Yoga & their own ideas & perceptions. Introspections can be unsettling. I seek your forgiveness if my tone has caused distress to you. In 2023 too I will continue the call to reflect & instrospect, but with an endeavour to simplify the complex & diverse Yogic teachings. Lets see where I get with this project 

Once again, thank you all who have walked with me & supported me during this challenging period. Your support means a lot to me.

In the popular narrative, Yoga is defined as a ‘set of practices’, usually indicating a collection of modalities like asana, pranayama, etc. But is Yoga only a set of practices?

The term ‘practice’ indicates application, the doing, the ‘how’, as opposed to the theory relating to it, the knowing, the ‘why’. 

Defining Yoga merely as a set of practices in isolation from its profound philosophical basis leads to dumbing down & decontextualization of Yoga where Yoga is uprooted from its core philosophies & practiced as isolated modalities, as opposed to being practiced as a wholistic knowledge system that is lived through life.

This is why we see so many Yogic practices done haphazardly in the popular Yoga culture without much clarity on why they are actually done. Yoga teachers know how practitioners are more inclined towards doing rather than knowing. This is also why practices that have little to do with Yoga are passed off as Yoga in popular culture. It’s as if we are so caught up with the ‘how’ that we have forgotten the ‘why’.

The solution to this is to teach Yoga not merely as a set of isolated practices but as a holistic system of transformation based on a clear philosophical premise, a well-defined goal & a steady hierarchy of practices that help the practitioner reach the set goal. 

The responsibility of educating the students about Yoga in this manner lies completely upon the Yoga teacher.

Svadhyaya means personal study & introspection of Yogic texts.Traditionally, it entails studying sacred texts, reading, reciting, reflecting & applying. It also means meditation & reflection on self. By self study one studies the self 

Svadhyaya is one of the most essential aspects of a Yoga practitioner’s life, after Sadhana. It is NOT a haphazard reading of books, frenzied gathering of knowledge, or anxious retention of information out of FOMO. Svadhyaya is always systematic, meticulous & stems from a sincere desire to understand life & self 

Why is theoretical study important in Yoga ? 
That’s because the Yoga process often tests us through tricky life challenges. This tends to create self-doubt & shake our trust in the path. A diligent theoretical study keeps us assured that we are on the right track & anchors our confidence in knowing that the path we are on has been tried & tested since thousands of years by millions of Yogis 

This assurance is essential, without which one keeps jumping from one modality to other in self-doubt, ultimately becoming a modality junkie 

Svadhyaya has more to do with assurance of the Heart than intellectuality of the Mind 

I've seen many reject theoritical study of Yoga by claiming Yoga to be all about experience. Here, Svadhyaya is analogous to driving. Even though driving is all about the hands-on experience we need basic theoretical knowledge of signals, highway codes & machine mechanics that aid navigating roads safely & help ourselves in case of automobile break-down. This is exactly how theoretical study, Svadhyaya, works – it helps us navigate spiritual path & gives us faith to rise when we fall or doubt. Investing even 10-15 mins in daily Svadhyaya, to revise & to reassure our heart & mind, can go a long way in regulating existential anxiety 

In my own life Svadhyaya works in tandem with Silence, Surrender & of course, Sadhana

Here are my 4 tips for sincere seekers
1) consciously take time everyday for study
2) study a scripture or book that speaks to you
3) best would be to study with a teacher
4) apply what you study in your daily life

Common misconceptions about Yogic Philosophy in popular culture

1) Yogic philosophy is a single philosophy revealed in one book, usually thought of as The Yoga Sutra of Patanjali

No, the subject of Yogic philosophy encompasses multiple ideas, notions, concepts, and systems, at times, opposing each other, that have been revealed over time through various sources across various scriptures. Thus, Yoga philosophy is not limited to Yoga Sutra alone.

2) Yogic philosophy is based on the Vedas

No, all philosophies of Yoga do not necessarily emerge from the Vedas alone. Especially, the Yogic notions of the Buddhists and Jainas do not prescribe to the Vedas

3) Belief in ‘God’ is essential to follow Yogic philosophy

No, there are philosophies of Yoga that do not necessitate a belief in ‘God’. Some Yogic philosophies are based purely on ethical-moral principles, and neither include ‘God’ as a variable in their cosmological model (ideas of creation of the world) nor in their soteriological model (ideas of spiritual liberation)

4) Sanskrit is the only language of Yogic philosophy

No. Though Vedas are in Sanskrit & so are the Upanishads, Yoga Sutra, Gita & Itihasa-Purana, there is more to Yoga philosophy than these texts. Over the last 2500 years, the philosophical wisdom of Yoga has also been produced in Indic languages like Magadhi, Prakrit, Tamil, Avadhi, Marathi, and others too.

Thus, Yogic philosophy as a subject is ancient, layered, and complex & yet, extremely practical, applicable, and accessible. Studying it systematically with a teacher and practicing the Yogic teachings consciously and patiently does make life easier, happier and lighter.

Happy studying !! 🙏🏽❤️

Narratives depend on how we consume information. What we see, and what we hear constantly, creates a popular narrative. The popular narrative tends to become a dominant idea, especially when social media dominates how we consume information.  

There being no filter or fact-check, at least for the Yoga industry, whatever is popular tends to be considered sacrosanct. 

Popularity doesn’t always connote authenticity. These days, whatever feeds demand and keeps the revenue stream flowing is emphasized by the Algorithm. Such selective emphasis on ideas, without examination of their authenticity, tends to create a lop-sided discourse, often perpetuating a bandwagon effect. A bandwagon effect is based on the assumption that whatever is popular is right & therefore one should adopt certain ideas & behaviors simply because others are doing so.

The way we understand Yoga today is heavily influenced by social media narratives that may not always be based on history, facts, or evidence. What is popular & trending tends to become a dominant industry discourse, becoming the actual voice of the stakeholders, gradually building a Yogic culture that stands independent from its original intention & ethos.

My note is not necessarily a critique, but an invitation to reflect. It is based on thousands of talks & chats I’ve had with Yoga teachers from around the world over the last 3 years, especially post-pandemic. 

A diligent study, dedicated sadhana, acuity of critical thinking, and a deep trust in the teachings can help filter through narratives and establish self-clarity in our minds and in our work.

Please reflect on the above 🙏🏽

I'm often asked how to find a teacher to study with. I too have mentioned the importance of studying with ‘your’ teacher. Lots can be said, probably I will write a Blog, but for now here are some clarifications & tips

Yoga is not a Do-It-Yourself project. Yes, one can learn from internet & books initially, but a time comes when all that knowledge needs to be personalized. As one matures on the Yoga path, the study is undertaken not for intellectual curiosity but for inner exploration.This is where one needs guidance of a teacher, ‘your’ teacher. This is a very important step on Yoga path

When I say ‘your’ teacher, I mean a teacher who you can study with, over a long period of time, with reverence, dedication & trust. The term ‘your’ entails a mutually recognized teacher-student relation

How to find ‘your’ teacher-

1) First, deeply reflect on what subject matter or dimension of Yoga interests you. This requires clarity cuz' we live in times where there is too much on offer, enough to confuse anyone. So, finding clarity in what one wants to study is a good first step

2) Then, start looking for teacher/s that can teach & guide you on that subject. This will be like finding a needle in a haystack

3) This process is refined by trial & error. You will have to approach different teachers & experience their teachings, till you find specific one/s that give you whats needed & you feel connected with. This too will be a process of filtration, at times misleading, not always a happy one, but it will refine your search nevertheless  

4) Gradually, by process of elimination, you will end up with one or a couple of teachers with whom you will want to study consistently. This clarity will help you create a dedicated relationship. The reason why I have mentioned one or two teachers max is that by the time one reaches this stage, one has filtered through the overwhelm of wanting to study multiple things. One is content with a single or a few teachers to learn specific things

5) Once you find such teacher/s, commit to them wholeheartedly with dedication, trust, reverence & humility

6) Note: Your teacher may or may not be your spiritual Guru. But about that, other time

Many practitioners limit themselves only to physical practices, because they link Yoga to a specific idea of ‘God’, & therefore to organized religion. I understand many may not have had comfortable experiences with an idea of ‘God’ &/or institutions of ‘God’ (organized religion) & therefore it's natural that they project their anxieties or views on Yogic spirituality

But, 'God' is a fluid concept in Indic spirituality. Theres no single, specific idea of ‘God’ in Yogic knowledge systems. Followers of opposing views of ‘God’ have thrived side by side in India over millennia. Even Gita allows for this freedom of interpretation, Krishna says in 4:11, “Howsoever they seek Me, even so, do I approach them. All follow My path in every way”

This is because Yoga is primarily a pursuit of absolute Truth (Sat), not necessarily a pursuit of ‘God’. But, this Truth takes the form of ‘God’/‘Gods’. Thus, Yoga can be a pursuit of Truth and/or of ‘God’, for they are not different or separate

Traditionally, the view of ‘God’ depends on Yogic ideology one aligns with. Here are some diverse ideas across Veda & Tantra. One can choose any to grow spiritually, for it’s not about who one worships, but how the worship transforms the seeker

• Theism (Bhakti lineages)

• Polytheism (Hindus worship many deities)

• Monotheism (Vaishnava, Shaiva lineages)

• A-theism (Sankhya, advaita Vedanta, Bauddha, Jaina)

• Pantheism (Vedic Gods permeate universe/nature– Goddess Ushas, Sun God, Surya Dev)

• Divine as human (Krishna/Saints)

• Divine without form, as Absolute consciousness (Brahman)

· God as Creator, Sustainer, Destroyer

• God as one’s own Guru, child, lover, friend, mother, father & also the guest

• Spiritual illusion too is considered a Goddess (Maya-Shakti)

• Most importantly, God in each one of us, in hearts of all (says Krishna in Gita)

So, let ideas of ‘God’ not stop you from embracing Yoga in its completeness. There are diverse views of Divine in Yoga for all. Even if one doesn't want to prescribe to any view, one's own undeniable existence itself is ‘God’, the Truth (Sat)

Nothing is not Divine, nothing is not ‘God’, nothing is not ‘Truth’ in Yoga – know it, be it

The other day I saw a sponsored post – “Do Camel pose to cure back-pain” & knew what to write about 

The human individual is not so simplistic that we make blanket statements like the above. Our individuality is not unidimensional, it is complex, multilayered, interactive & inheres a larger matrix

That’s why, offering unidimensional, linear solutions to problems needs to be avoided by Yoga Teachers. Such unidimensional solutions are common in the Yoga world
Eg: Migraine? – Do Headstand
Shortness of breath? – Do Pranayama
Insomnia? – Do Yoga Nidra

I've even heard people make general statements like, "Just do Yoga, no need to do anything else"

Its not as simple as saying “Do this pose to cure back pain” because the person’s back pain could have less to do with physical anatomy & more to do with ergonomics, diet, sleep, habits, foot-wear, posture, inactivity, heredity, past-traumas & many other factors

Though, the reason for our unidimensional POV cannot be pegged on a single factor. I believe it is a reflection of our Colonial education system that has upheld a sharp Mind-Body dicotomy (Cartesian dualism) over last 4 centuries
 
Traditional Yoga & Ayurveda sees the world differently though. Its based on a concept called “Pinda-Brahmanda Siddhanta” - Micro-Macrocosm Principle, which states that every micro-unit is a part of a macro unit & every macro unit is made of many micro-units. These units are not mutually exclusive but they essentially influence each other. In togetherness, they create a whole system - like the tiny parts of a wrist watch

An Individual exists simultaneously at multiple dimensions – physical, mental, social, cultural & spiritual, that constantly interact to keep them alive & thriving

The micro-unit, i.e individual’s mental state, could create physical chaos, which could, in turn, create a societal crisis. The macro unit,  i.e societal uncertainty (like the Pandemic), could initiate individual insecurities, which can have a dire physical impact

We can't separate an individual’s micro-macro interactions from societal micro-macro expressions, & V.V

This Dynamic & Holistic view needs to be kept in mind by Yoga Teachers & Therapists🙏🏽

I sincerely believe that if one has even completed their basic ‘200 Hour Yoga Training’ they have enough transformation techniques to last a lifetime. If the seeker doesn't understand this, then what they need is not more techniques but more trust

But we live in tricky times, because while Yoga is a path of generating one-pointed focus, we live amongst excess of modalities. New techniques, styles & practices are launched as if going out of fashion, each claiming to offer something new, different, & better. The practitioners, with their restless minds, bored by the same old practice, triggered by FOMO, tend to either get overwhelmed by the sheer number of techniques on offer or keep hopping from one to another without giving their practice enough time to come to fruition

This is why we need to filter through sales pitches, inquire into our need for more, our FOMO, reflect on our boredom, question our addiction to excitement & simplify our practice

Let’s swelter on the path till we find the teaching & teacher/s that we need, then, single-mindedly let’s pursue the teaching with total commitment, faith & sincerity. This is what Yoga scriptures call an Ekāgra (एकाग्र) Chitta, a one-pointed mind. Its the working goal of all Yogins, without it, there can be no samādhi or self-realization 

Etymologically, ekāgra means ‘single-intent’, fixed on one point, undisturbed. Ekāgra is also one of the most refined states of mind that facilitates ‘Chitta Vritti Nirodha’. According to Patanjali & Vyasa, there can be no Vritti Nirodha without an ekāgra mind

In the middle of the Gita, Krishna tells Arjuna to make his mind one-pointed (tatraikāgraṃ manaḥkṛtvā). Then, at the end of the Gita, Krishna asks, “O’ Arjun, have you heard Me with an ekāgra mind? Has your ignorance & delusion been destroyed?” This tells us the importance of ekāgra mind for seekers

Yogic spirituality is not a path of incessant gathering but a path of refining & lightening. It’s not how much you know but what you do with whatever you know

So, instead of losing energy in just gathering techniques, trust your practice – it will lead you within. Know that the Self is verily within, so look within

Asana don't have to be complicated to be effective. Though 'complicated' is a relative term, what I mean is, one doesn't really have to resort to acrobatics or strenuous contortions for asana to work effectively. I believe the "advance" of asana is in the ease of doing & depth of attention, not in complicated arrangement of limbs or complexity of effort

Yes, the tapasvi sadhu (yogic ascetics) of past did do effortful contortions but their goal was not physical culture or wellness but austerity & penance

If there is one posture that is effective in its simplicity, its Janu Shirsa asana /Maha Mudra

This, one leg forward bend is mentioned in some traditional Hatha texts not because its a complicated contortion but because in its simplicity it is effective in pranic modulation

Though i've mentioned advanced effects below, my point is not to trigger impatience but to help us allow the simplicity of an asana to work its magic over time instead of squeezing each asana effortfully always in our practice

Physically, be on sit bones & bend. If you don't reach foot it’s fine, hold ankles. It’s not about how much you bend but from where you bend (this is important if done as a mudra for kundalini kriya). Don't rush to touch chin to shin or let impatience mess your back. Be gentle, relax in posture & be with steady breath & attention (or breath holds in jalandhar bandha in advance phase). During my anushthaan in 2015, i've even used this mudra effectively as pranic dhyana

Psychologically, this asana/mudra neutralizes opposing mindsets over time. It 'lightens' an emotionally heavy mind. Its calming & rejuvenating if not rushed into & aided by steady breath & attention

The pose is purposely kept simple in the tradition because in its effortlessness the attention ventures deep into psychological depths

Pranically, in initial stages, it ensures balanced functioning of apana & a steady movement of samana vayus. In advance stage, when done as a mudra with prana sankochana (pranic recoil) it also aids in redirection of apana

So, keep it simple, keep practising & give your practise time to mature🙏

Source: My venerable teacher, Gheranda Samhita, Hatha & Joga Pradipika

This memory came up, reminding me of an incident. A few years ago, someone saw pictures from my workshop & asked,

"Prasad, I've noticed, the people in your Yoga workshops don’t look like Yogis, they all look like ordinary people. What 'style' of Yoga do you actually teach?"

My answer was sincere. I replied, 
"Yes, the participants in my workshops are ordinary people & that’s the ‘style’ of Yoga I teach, it's called - Yoga for ordinary people."

I do not really identify with any 'style of Yoga' because what I have studied & know is Yoga. And, as for the people in my workshops looking ordinary, I cherish it. I am humbled how everytime the participants turn up for the workshops in whatever shape, state or form they may be in, uninhibited, with trust & openness

Dear friends, Yoga does not make you extraordinary. In fact, a diligent practice of Yoga makes you realize that you are ordinary, just like everyone else

Any need to feel special, or to be validated as extraordinary is the need of the Ahambhāv - "ego"

When you use Yogic teachings in its broader sense, for self-understanding, you realize that there’s nothing really special about you, you are ordinary, just like everyone else 😊

Allow Yoga to help you come down from the complexity of your mind to the simplicity of your being

Life is simple, but our minds become complicated. Constant need to feel extraordinary & fill the inner vaccuum with external validation is one reason why mind becomes complicated
 
As a Yoga Educator, I try to educate students to live life in its simplicity & enjoy their ordinary-ness without anxiety & strain of feeling extraordinary

This is why my posts are often reflective & inquiry driven. Let us all enquire as to how we have unnecesarily complicated our mind & life 

That's my Yoga teaching 'Style', if you will. 🙏

By the way, here's that picture from my Bangkok workshop in 2019. Look at all the lovely ordinary people in there - big, small, women, men, old, young, wrinkly, taught, bald, hairy, Yoga teachers, first timers, Yoga pants, no Yoga pants – we all had a great time learning Yoga

Let's normalize ordinariness ❤️
Share with your ordinary friends 🤗

Spoke to a group of 200 hour teacher trainees today as a guest teacher & reminded them that their potential is far, far greater than their self-dobut.

Many times we overthink things that may not actually happen. Our anxiety makes us overthink & exaggerates a tiny stimulus into a monsterous trigger. An anxious mind impulsively reaches outward to grasp material objects thinking that they will provide security.

But, the world of thoughts & things is infinite & makes the anxious mind even more anxious & overwhelmed. The thirst for more rests on a belief that it will bring lasting peace & happiness, which unfortunately is a lie.

Stop investing your energy & attention in overthinking. Slow down, step back, breathe, & allow the anxious buzz of the mind to calm down. Focus your time & energy to calm down that mind instead.

When the mind calms down you will know that you are more than the thougt based reality you have concieved for yourself. This is when you stop being a slave to the mind & become the true owner of the mind. This is when you stop living a life of anxious projection & live a life of conscious possibility. This is when lasting inner peace is not only sensed but also embodied.

Our life is an opportunity to make this shift happen. 

Life is like a leaf, barely holding on to the branch that it hangs from. Its existence is fragile. When the season changes & the wind blows, the leaf will fall. What will you hang on to when the leaf of your life lets go off the tree of life ? Anxiety or Peace

This is for all those who want to deepen their Yoga journey. If you want to understand Yoga, Ayurveda, Tantra & just about every Indian philosophical thought, then this is the one philosophy that you will need to study – Sankhya Darshana (Sankhya philosophy)

Super excited to launch a 5-week certificate course on Sankhya Philosophy to help gain an accessible & practical understanding of the root philosophy of Yoga & Ayurveda.

Patanjali’s Yoga Sutra too uses the framework of Sankhya, & therefore an understanding of Sankhya philosophy is crucial to understand the essence of Yoga Sutra.

In this course, we will study the most important & authentic scripture of Sankhya philosophy called Sankhya Karika in a traditional way.

Here is the list of topics covered,

Week 1 - History

• Difference between Darshana & Philosophy
• Meaning & purpose of Sankhya Darshana
• Sankhya History, authorship & its link to  Yoga-Ayurveda & Veda

Week 2 – Metaphysics

• What is dualism of Sankhya
• Purusha & Prakriti, & their interaction
• Gunas & their impact on mind & body

Week 3 – Epistemology

• What is knowledge & its nature
• What is ignorance & its nature
• Bondage & release in Sankhya

Week 4 – Cosmology

• Sankhya theory of creation
• Sankhya theory of causation
• Sankhya & Karma theory

Week 5 – Relevance & Application

• Role of ‘God’ in Sankhya
• Importance of Sankhya in Patanjali’s Yoga
• How to live the Sankhya Darshana

Once I fared badly in school science exam. I asked my elder sister why the teacher had marked my answer on Newton’s law wrong when it was correct. Reading my answer, she smiled & said, “Prasad, you can’t make up your own law & call it Newton’s law”. She was right, I had just put together some keywords & made up my own interpretation of Newton’s law which didn't come even close to his original statement

We often come across subjective interpretations of Yoga that are generalized as Yoga, as in “I feel Yoga is…so, Yoga is….”, or “I have experienced Yoga as, therefore Yoga is…”. It's like saying, I’ve walked in the forest behind my home, therefore all forests in the world are like my backyard

Such subjectivism has created so many interpretations of Yoga in popular culture that it’s hard to know what Yoga is anymore

Yes, Yoga is a personal experience but generalizing one’s own experience as the definition of Yoga not only creates confusion but also devalues & dilutes the original thought & its cultural context

Does that mean subjective experience has no value? No, individual experiences are important in Yoga, after all, Yoga happens within, but the interpretations need to happen in context

Throughout Yogic history, the issue of subjectivism was regulated by contextualizing one’s experience (anubhava) with reference to scriptures (shāstra). Students were taught how to deduct, formulate & defend their statements. In popular Yoga, since we don’t give much weightage to scriptural testimony or scriptural study, it’s a free for all

Just like lawyers don’t create their own laws to defend their clients, or scientists don’t make claims without evidence, we as Yoga professionals too need to responsibly back our claim to avoid confusion created by emotive subjectivism

A decade ago, someone saw my Yoga teacher training post & asked if I would like to use their book on “poetic interpretation of Yoga Sutra” as a textbook. I was told many YTTs were using it. When I read some pages, I was shocked to find it to be the author’s personal, creative interpretation that had hardly anything to do with Patanjali’s thoughts. I wonder what the students took home as Yoga Sutra..

As modern Yoga aligns more with Anatomical & Therapeutical approach instead of Ontological approach, as mainstream dismisses or side-steps Scriptural teachings as ‘religious’ or ‘outdated’ & opts for science-backed research as evidence for Yogic benefits, one wonders if Scripture study is even relevant 

To understand this, one needs to know what Yogic Scriptures are

The ancient Yogis were ‘Scientists’ in their own regard, driven by curiosity, inquiry, experimentation, & zest to answer deeper questions of life like any genuine Science enthusiast. They tried to answer fundamental life questions in their own way, by giving their own models & systems of inquiry. But, the aim of their inquiry & experimentation was not exploitation of nature, but elimination of suffering

One could think of Yogic scriptures as ‘Scientific Journals’ of Yogi Scientists. Traditionally, there is an elaborate method of assessing the efficacy of Scriptures, akin to stringent norms of today’s peer-reviewed Scientific journals

Yoga has been codified & presented in what is called as Shāstra, which etymologically means the one that saves through its teachings. Adi Shankara, 9 CE, compares Shāstra to a mother nurturing her child. The Gita (16:24) too says, knowing Scriptures one should elevate themselves & society. There are thousands of scriptures written across Yogic history. These Shāstras aim to guide, educate & motivate the seeker to facilitate their own psychological liberation

Thus, Scriptures are not mere intellectual head scratching but about human self & life, about you & me. If studied rightly they help us liberate our mind from self-inflicted mental limitation

Scientific study has empirical relevance & Yogic Scripture study has Psychological & Ontological relevance. (Ontology means related to the nature of self). Both can work together

As an educator, the reason I teach Scriptures is cuz' they have helped me make my life simpler & live with clarity & joy

Scripture study (Swādhyāya) is Life Education for me, & in the words of one of my favorite educationists John Dewey, this education is not preparation for life but life itself

Join us in my upcoming Sankhya Philosophy Course

Once, a participant in my Meditation Facilitator Training had an interesting question. She asked,
"when does the actual Dhyāna begin? Not what we know as moving meditation, not as mindfulness exercise, but the actual, seated Dhyāna, that we read about in the Yoga Sutra, Upanishad or Purāna"

I told her that Meditation as Dhyāna begins when one can sit without past regrets, future plans, and a need to do something in the present.

I also gave her a Thought Experiment which I want to share with you here.

1) Take a piece of paper
2) Write down all the identities that you can recall - identities in name, form, as a mom, as a son, as a teacher, as an expert, etc.
3) Now, fold the paper & keep it away
4) As you keep the paper away, try to step back from your association with those identities
5) Sense what state of mind ensues 

It is in this state of mind that the self stabilizes & sits with itself in silence. This is when Dhyāna begins.

In the Yoga Sutra, this is the 7th anga (limb)
&, in the Tantras, this is the place where Kundalini is said to be situated at the Hridaya Kamala, what we know as the heart chakra in popular culture

Note: This state of mind may NOT be a comfortable place psychologically, unless the aspirant has courageously practiced over time (abhyāsa), patiently prepared themselves with detachment (vairāgya), & has the Kripā (grace) to their aid

Connection between Tantra & Physics is so delicately beautiful & yet, so ruthlessly devastating. It's fascinating that the symbol for “wave function” in quantum mechanics is Ψ (psi) which looks like Trident of Shiva.Incidentally, in Shaiva Tantra philosophy, Shiva is said to manifest in waves (यस्योन्मेषनिमेषाभ्यां जगतः प्रलयोदयौ - Spandakārika).

Some Physicist say fundamental nature of universe is ‘fields’. Mathematically a field is something that takes value at every point in space. Even the ‘vacuum’ is not 'nothing' but is made up of ‘fields’ - throbbing with potentiality. Physics has always reminded me of Tantra Agāma & thinking of ‘fields’ & ‘waves’ takes me back to mind-blowing works by Tantra Masters like Kallāta, AbhinavaGupta & Kshemarāja

Fascinatingly, these 'fields' cannot be still, they vibrate in excitation, constantly change in mathematical value & every excitation manifests a particle. The manifested world is excitation states of these fields. I am often tempted to correlate this with ‘Abhasavada’, the doctrine of appearance in Tantras. Excitations of ‘fields’ are like threads that connect all objects, like invisible threads that puppeteers use to move puppets.These fields create what physicists call ‘action at a distance’

When I teach fascial anatomy I love to imagine these ‘fields’ extending from my body’s fascia to a Neutron Star light-years away. These ‘fields’ are continuous just like fascial network & transfer of energy happens through ‘waves’, just like how tension transfer happens through the fascial network. Excitations happen in chunks of energy & this energy creates mass, that mass becomes a particle, & we are all made of particles. All atoms in our body are ripples in these ‘fields’. We are all in it & we are all it. Neither do we know their material reality as yet, nor can we see 'fields' with visible eyes, but what we do know is that these fields are connected & in that sense we are all connected.But, all this could also be an approximation as we still don’t have answers to the 'why?'

Perhaps one day we will dig deeper into mysteries of Universe.Till then, I dream my life away, as Ozzy Osbourne would say..

Stay well y'all. Hugs

It would not be an exaggeration to say that in modern Yoga world many of us have parachuted straight into Yoga Sutra without a background of its root philosophy

Since Yoga Sutra has become the poster child of modern Yoga, we make a genuine attempt to know it. But trying to figure out Yoga Sutra by itself, without background & context, is like trying to drive a car without wheels, wheels being the fundamental tenets of Sankhya Philosophy

Yogic scriptures are not novels to be randomly picked & read. They are manuals of knowledge that have to be studied in a systematic manner. Just as one doesn’t study Calculus without an understanding of basic Mathematics, Yogic scriptures too have a certain scriptural hierarchy where each new topic builds on an earlier one

The Yoga Sutra of Patanjali is built on rock-solid foundations of Sankhya Philosophy. In fact, traditionally, Yoga Sutra (Yoga Darshana) is considered an extension of Sankhya Darshana. If Yoga is ‘how’, then Sankhya is ‘why’

And this is why the first Sutra, ‘atha Yoga anushasanam’ emphasizes the term ‘atha’ which means ‘now…’, where ‘now…’ connotes a continuum of study. The usage of ‘now’ also indicates that Patanjali assumes that the students have already unpacked Sankhya philosophy & are now ready to understand Yoga Sutra

I believe it is due to the lack of background understanding that the discourse of Yoga Sutra in contemporary Yoga circles has not gone beyond a few select topics like Yama-Niyama & Asana, when these topics actually cover just a few Sutras out of the total. (That doesn’t mean Yama-Niyama are not important)  

This is also why popular understanding of Yoga Sutra is highly fixated only upon the ‘Ashtanga Yoga’ part, which is the practice system given by Patanjali, when there is so much more to it

There is a need to understand Yoga Sutra in its wholesomeness, as theory & practice, & not merely in its partial form as a list of practices. For this, it is important to study the ideas, concepts, notions & systems it is based in

This is why I am teaching a course in Sankhya philosophy. If you want to understand Yoga Sutra in its wholesomeness, do consider joining it to get your basics right

This post is a deeply personal memoir & not a public teaching. I know my words will be ambiguous & perhaps misinterpreted, but a contemplative Sunday gave me the strength to share this with you all, humbly & vulnerably

So, over the last 12 years, the two variables I am working on in my Yogic practice are, Silence & Surrender. Silence, some other time, for now, here's Surrender

A time comes when a conscious seeker realizes that the rabbit hole of self-delusion goes deep. It’s dark, dingy & uncomfortable, but the only way out is through. So, the seeker squirms through, with faith, bearing the stench of rotten memories that were wounded by attachments & blinded by neediness, allowing every bruise to peel off layers of generational conditioning, societal limitations, self-inflicted harm & grandeurs of self-delusion. Then, suddenly the tunnel caves in

Surrender is the last choice the seeker exercises, the choice to fall. It is the final, conscious act, the voluntary giving up of personal sovereignty, the so-called ‘Free Will’ that we so strongly cling to

Like Shraddha (faith), Sharanagati too grows over time, through participating in life. The furnace of life has to bake us enough for us to deeply recognize its value. One has to mature towards it. Till then, life is entertained, playing hide n’ seek with a friend that doesn’t exist

Life tests us, throws us off the cliff, raises us to the clouds & then smashes us down again. Bouncing about, one sees life & self differently & learns to give up on oneself, give up oneself

But, this giving up, this surrender, does not feel like a defeat, or punishment, because it is not. It is a detachment that organically ensues, where all defenses fall away, all protection mechanisms are abandoned willfully, & the consciousness constrained by the idea of self is set free

Sharanagati, spiritual surrender, is the bravest act of letting go & the most authentic act of freedom a seeker can undertake. It is the biggest favor one can do for oneself. It’s the final page of the book of self-love, after which one doesn’t fight life, one flows with it, one doesn’t love life, one becomes love – this then is the deepest rest & highest joy

A fish can swim because it is supported by water currents all around it. A bird flies because it is supported by air flow all over. Humans walk and run because they are supported by opposing muscular forces. The solar system too is supported by forces like gravity and inertia.

In our day to day struggles it is very easy to forget that we are supported. The feeling of anxiety and overwhelm may make us feel that we are fighting our battles all alone. But one has to just look around and reach out, only to know that we are embraced by existence itself. When you feel lonely, when you feel lost, when you feel exhausted – know that you are supported.

That which supports you may not always be visible, but it is there, holding you for sure, in various names, forms, sizes and ways. The more you trust, the more you realize that you are supported.

Your body holds you, your breath nourishes you, your loved ones cheer for you, your hope makes you move on and your faith makes your journey effortless. You are NOT alone, you ARE supported. So, keep the faith and carry on.

Loving reassuring hugs to all you out there who are finding it hard to pull through...

Spread the assurance.

Support and be supported 🙏🏾

Last week I spoke on Cultural appropriation in a 200 Hr training. Here’s a quick glance at it. My intent is not to criticise but to raise awareness

Some years ago, I took a class in a studio in Europe. At the entrance was a big Buddha statue. To my shock, the students had placed shoes on the lap & shoulders of Buddha

This for me is a prime example of Exotification, which means glamorizing & romanticizing elements of a culture without right understanding & portraying them as unusual/uncommon. Curiosity & fascination about other cultures is natural, but exotification creates sweeping generalizations & stereotypes

I’ve been to studios where the ‘quintessential’ Buddha statue had become just another dusty furniture piece, Lakshmi statue was used as scarf hanger, Nataraja idol was a keyholder & Shri Yantra was Yoga mat design

In a way, Exotification is an output of Tokenism, where things are done merely for effect, just to project a specific image or impress others, & not necessarily out of right understanding or intent

Tokenism is when one wants a Buddha statue to make the studio look ‘spiritual’/'zen', or wants deity idols or artifacts as decoration pieces. Indeed, having spiritual objects can change moods of a space, but respect & intent matters in the usage

2 years ago, in an advert of a pandemic fundraiser for India, I noticed someone sitting on the Indian flag. This amounts to offense as it violates Indian Flag Code. On pointing out I was told that organizers were informed, yet the graphic was being circulated. Is this tokenism or carelessness? Tokenism is rampant in India too. One just has to see how Ganesha & Devi idols are tossed in ocean after festivals

A few tips
1) Educate yourself about cultural contexts & artifacts, & clarify your intent
2) If you have an altar with deities, inquire into basic altar Do’s & Dont's & keep your altar clean
3) If you already exotify cultural artifacts or use them for validation, or as a token, inquire into your need for it & refine your view towards them sincerely without feeling guilty
4) As practitioners we borrow from the Yogic culture, our sensitivity matters. Such complex topics indeed deserve deeper reflection

In Greek Mythology, Sisyphus was a cruel king who was condemned to push a large rock up a steep hill, only to find it rolling back on nearing the top. Ever since then, he has been known for pushing the rock tirelessly till eternity.

The famous contemporary existential philosopher, Albert Camus compares the absurdity of our life with the situation of Sisyphus in his book The Myth of Sisyphus.

Camus says that the ‘absurdity’ of life is in the fact that there is a basal conflict between what we want from the world and what we find in the world. He says that it is not possible to find meaning and purpose in life unless we totally accept this absurdity. If we don’t do that, life itself comes across as a meaningless endeavour.

We have to craft out meaning for ourselves in this profoundly mysterious journey called life.

Yogic tradition too accepts life's absurdity & helps us create a meaningful life by asking us to live in faith, faith in the fact that we are loved and cared for by the Divine.

This is called Shraddhā in Yogic thought. The organic output of Shraddhā is surrender to the Divine will, called Sharanāgati.

Shri Krishna says in the Gita, 'yoga-kṣhemaṁ vahāmyaham' - surrender to me, I will take care of you.

I believe that the Divine provides constant promptings to help us grow through life, but we are too busy in transient pursuits like King Sisyphus, pushing a sliding boulder over & over again.

Yes, life is absurd & challenging, but believing deeply that the Divine loves & cares for us can help ease our existential anxiety, making us live effortlessly.

As Camus says at the end of his essay, "The struggle of life itself ... is enough to fill a man's heart. One must imagine Sisyphus happy".

I am sure we all have faced an Asana practice plateau sometime in our Yoga life. The immediate tendency would be to be frustrated, feel not good enough, & do something different, something more, mix & match practices, or even start something completely new. 

Impulsive solutions emerging from frustration could distract the practitioner from the Yoga path. What I propose here instead is to be with that plateau, deeply listen, examine & reflect on the points below, instead of reacting with a feeling of inadequacy

1) Being stuck in your practice could help you become empathetic toward yourself. Know that the physical body has limits & each person has their own limitations. So, being in a practice plateau could help you examine your limits & work with them, not against them

2) Hitting a practice plateau could help you inspect if the plateau is due to your own experience, as in, “why am I stuck at the same point in a forward bend since a year”, or due to your desire to be like someone else, as in, “why am I not able to extend as much as that person on Instagram”. This inspection could help you become more realistic about how you set your goals

3) Being in a practice plateau could make you examine if your lifestyle variables like diet, sleep, and mental state are in regulation. This is a big one, Yoga practice goes hand in hand with these variables & reflecting on them could help you generate a wholesome view of your practice

4) Sometimes, not growing in your physical practice could be an invitation to become patient with yourself & examine the ambitious benchmarks you’ve set for yourself. The body has its own time & wisdom which may not always conform to your impatience

5) Being stuck in your physical practice could be a blessing in disguise, inviting you to step back, take it easy & explore the deeper, subtler practices of Yoga

So, be with your practice plateau, listen deeply & reflect, instead of reacting with frustration.

Your Yoga practice is not here to entertain your fancies but to lead to the truth of Self. Be still & listen...

Hi, my name is Prasad & I am an introvert

My work demands that I be amongst people, which I genuinely enjoy, but at heart I am a recluse

My social engagements are bare minimum, my phone conversations are brief, I have very few close friends, I love being at home, but above all, I cherish my aloneness.All this at the risk of being labeled insensitive, rude, proud & weird

No, I don’t hate people, I don’t think world is bad, I am not anxious about the future of humanity, I am not overwhelmed by social situations, but, genuinely, I am neither keen to know who is doing what, nor nervous about not knowing others

I am over the need to excel, I’ve had enough of wanting to prove myself, I am done with finding meaning & purpose, & am happy to follow when not required to lead

I have always been reclusive.But accepting it has been a painful journey. I’ve spent years doubting myself, thinking something was wrong with me. I’ve beaten myself up for not being outgoing & bent backward to fit in by faking extrovertedness. Even the competitive sport I chose as a teenager was an individual sport. It has taken me decades to accept my personality trait (swabhāva) & turn it into my strength - thanks to my Guru & sadhanā

As I look back, I am grateful for my nature. As a boy it helped channel my anxieties through art, which was my only recourse of self-expression. It made me more reflective & less reactive, which organically turned me toward Dhyāna as a teenager. Later, my meditations lead me to explore the practice of silence (mauna), at times happily being in silence retreats for 4 long months, alone. Each turn made me comfortable with myself

Today, if I want, I can genuinely be in a social group, with empathy, for I am assured in my aloneness. I am there for me, even when others don’t want to be. This helps me be there for others, if they need

Popular culture celebrates extrovertedness, but not everyone needs to be out there as a foot soldier activist. Revolutions can also start quietly in a laboratory of a scientist

We all have our personality type, become comfortable with yours & grow

Note: Introvertedness is not all-or-none, it exists as a continuum. Seek help if needed
