I am usually asked what is advanced Yoga, & my reply always is - seeing divinity in everyone is advanced Yoga

It is easy to see divine in idols, tempels, photos & even nature & animals, but when it comes to seeing divine in our fellow humans, especially those whom we dont like, it seems challenging...

Its easy to seek divine in places of worship as an escape from the 'big bad world', its convinient to pray to images & symbols to feel upifted, but only when one deeply sees that the divine is in all places, at all times, the mind stabilize 

This is why the Bhakti tradition of Yoga has always maintained that the divine is not only in the temples & idols but also in our fellow beings

Seeing divine only in temples and idols, and not recognizing divinity in everyone is spiritual bypass

Shri Krishna himself says multiple times in the Gita that He, as universal consciousness, is seated in the hearts of all Beings

Chaitanya Mahaprabhu (15th century) says in Chaitanya-charitamrta (Madhya 8.274) "The seeker devoted to Krishna sees all moving and nonmoving things, but does not exactly see their forms. Rather, wherever he looks he sees the manifestation of His worshipable Lord."

My dearest Mauli, Sant Jnaneshwar (13th century) too says in Jnaneshwari, "wherever you see any being, see them as manifestation of divine"

Even Kabir (15th century) says, "Scholars are never made from reading countless books. You only need to understand 'love'
to be a true scholar."

All images of the divine are only to guide us back to the divine within. This is how the process of Yoga works

Reflect on this in your own way 🙏🏾

Share, to make the world a more amicable place

Teacher: Did you feel the pose?
Student: No
Teacher: Go deeper, more, push. Now do you?
Student: No
Teacher: Wait, I will push. Now?
Student: Ah!! Now I feel the pose. 

Such a dialogue is common place in many Asana classes

The "service industry" nature of Yoga makes many Asana teachers feel obligated to provide their students the ‘feel’ in poses

Often, the teacher's expertise at teaching is measured by how much the student ‘feels’ the pose. Disgruntled students leave the class saying "I didnt feel anything". Atleast for a teacher who is starting off, this is a nightmare. So, every "Yes, I feel the pose" from a student is a validation of sorts to the teacher's skill

More the 'feel', the better the class, such correlation could compel the teacher to overtly load a student if the student doesnt 'feel' the pose, not only to make the student happy but also to make themselves feel validated. Jumping on the student's back, standing on their knees, lying down with complete weight thrown on student who is already trying their ‘best’ & is in peak contraction (full range of motion) could become a formula for injury

When we look at asana practice as more than a project of stretching a muscle & see it as nervous system training instead, the tonality of teaching changes

The practice doesnt become an opportunity for instant gratification. Instead, patience & empathy helps improve the 'feel' component gradually. The practitioner progresses using the path of patient practice instead of the path of pain

All this & more will be discussed in my upcoming Asana focused worlshop called "Rethinking asana". If you want to create a more stable, empathetic & patient practice, and also learn how to teach that way, you may want to consider joining the course

But for now, Remember,
• Injuries happen because we are not patient with our limits.
• Injuries happen because we blindly agree with someone else's idea of right alignment.
• Injuries happen because we seek perfection in a pose when the true perfection is that of the Self alone.
.
Train your body with patience and treat your body with respect.  As the Sanskrit phrase goes, 'deho devalaya..' - Your body is a temple...

.
Sorry, but no one's coming to save you.
.
The Universe will root for you.
Your Teachers will guide you.
Your Friends will cheer for you.

It is you who will have to walk and svelter in the fire of life challenges to grow through Yoga.

Save yourself from drowning in the depth of your own delusions.

A few years ago, in my Meditation workshop I said, "if you have physical issues due to which you can't sit on the floor, please feel free to sit on a chair to meditate".
 
After the workshop one participant approached me looking very content and said, "thank you for permitting me to sit on the chair and meditate hence forth. Since last three years I have been struggling with meditation because my back was damaged in an accident. My teacher doesnt let me use a chair, I have to sit on the floor in his class. Therefore, even though I love to meditate, every meditation is a sour experience for me." He then gave me a warm hug and walked away...
.
You don't 'have to' sit in lotus pose for the meditation to be effective. In fact lotus pose has more to do with Pranayama then with meditation. There are various seated meditation postures mentioned across traditions. Maharishi Vyasa in his commentary on Yoga Sutra has given 13 basic meditation sitting postures (Asana).
.
It is very important to realize that the path of Yoga, including all its methodologies, are aligned to transform an individual. Every individual is unique. Therefore, when guiding asana, pranayama, kriya and meditation, the individual's uniqueness, capabilities and limitations need to be kept in mind.

Generalisation of instructions is fine at a superficial level but after a certain maturity the methods and approches have to be personalised to the practitioner.

Guide the students from where they are, not from where you want them to be.

#meditation #yogapractice

Today is Thursday, Guru day. It will be little over a year that my 1st Yoga Guru passed away. Back in 1985, he told us, Yoga is personal well-being for self-realization.That was Yoga for me, still is & will be

But since I started teaching internationally in 2003 I encountered narratives of Yoga that were all over the place 

2003-2005, teachers in Europe told me real Yoga was strict postural alignment & flexibility 

2006-2009 was all about Astanga Vinyasa.
Ashtangies tried convincing me that authentic Yoga was about the 'flow' & Patanjali was the source of Vinyasa flow 

2009-2011 was about Yoga injuries.Yoga was looked at with suspicion. Safety was on everyone's mind 

2011-2012 was my tryst with Bikram Hot Yoga & 'Kundalini' Yoga.I was also told why Hot rooms are crucial & that Patanjali had prophesized birth of Yogi Bhajun 

Come 2013, Fascia was on everyone's lips. Suddenly Yoga was all about Meridians.Yoga became Yin & slow became sacred 

2013 - 2016, 'Fascia'nation of long stretches hybridized with Taoism remained popular. Over stretched, injured Yogis could now officially rest in a pose 

Post 2016, Yoga became all about Movement. Yoga teachers became 'Movement educators' as Asana became 'conscious movement' 

From 2018 on, Yoga & activism became synonymous. If you were a teacher & not linked to some kind of 'cause' you weren't compassionate enough 

All this as Yoga industry grappled with stories of abusive Gurus, cults, social media narcissism, cultural appropriation & cancel culture.Many well meaning teachers were overwhelmed, stopped teaching or migrated to other modalities 

& then, Pandemic happened & Yoga went Zoom!! Many lost jobs, sold studios or gave up teaching.The tech savvy migrated to 2D screens to teach 3D bodies, others went into self-doubt or debt

This note is not a criticism, its my personal observation 

I think our 'Yoga Industry' is in its infancy. Akin to a child wearing parents' shoes & pretending to be an adult, it is experimenting & trying to find its own identity & place in a bigger consumeristic ecosystem 

Yoga teachers, it will help to find clarity in what Yoga is for you & not confuse yourself with changing narratives🙏

Last year or so my Instagram has increased considerably & with it has increased trolling, cancelling, blocking & triggered responses

I make sure to write with an all-round perspective & a considerate tone. I am neither looking for an agreement from the reader, nor wanting to convert them to my perspective. My sole aim is to stimulate reflection & research. Yes, at times I do call spade a spade & back my arguments with valid references where possible. But perhaps that triggers people. Most triggered pushbacks are either emotive or made from a point of subjectivism – they are neither rooted in historical evidence nor scriptural citation. In such times, trolls usually resort to personal attack, which itself tells that they don’t have a valid argument 

Quoting here just 3 of the most common pushbacks I’ve received

1) Yoga is not ancient. Its just 100-odd years old

This is a common argument made by those considering Asana-based physical practice as ‘Yoga’. Neither Yoga nor Asana practice is 100 years old, & there is enough evidence for it. Many seem to have misinterpreted recent scholarly works on Modern Yoga & exaggerated this point

 2) Your posts are disruptive to my Business Model which is based on physical Yoga practice

Firstly, I am in no way responsible for your Business Model. Secondly, I am not against physical yogic practice. In fact, I believe it is crucial for our times. I know many who have beautifully integrated their new understanding of ancient Yogic culture into their physical Yoga-based business model. My ideas could become disruptive only if you are closed to newer perspectives

 3) This is what you think, but I ‘feel’ Yoga is…

Though Yoga is a personal experience it is rooted in a mature intellectual tradition that has evolved through symbolism, language, logic, moral & social contexts. Interpreting Yoga in whatever way one likes, without context or reference to its root culture, dilutes an ancient intellectual tradition. Just because one ‘feels’ Yoga is XYZ doesn’t make the entire Yogic understanding XYZ

Friends, no one is perfect. Be curious, explore, learn from a proper source, integrate & keep growing as a sincere student practitioner

In a listing of Yoga classes we find various ‘styles’. Unfortunately, one so-called ‘style’ among them is Hatha Yoga

We live in times where the way one does posture practice has come to be known as ‘style’ of Yoga. That is because Asana practice has popularly come to be seen as Yoga. But Hatha Yoga is neither a ‘style’ of Yoga, nor a way of doing postures

As if that were not enough, Hatha Yoga is also perceived as a ‘gentle’ style of Yoga (gentle way of doing postures), as opposed to physically intensive ways. Even popular websites like WebMD dumb down Hatha Yoga to a ‘Gentle’ physical practice, stating - "Hatha yoga originally meant the physical practice of yoga, the poses rather than the breathing exercises.” 

Labelling Hatha Yoga a posture practice is like reducing an entire 7-course meal to a plate of salad. That's because,

Hatha Yoga is (at least) a 1000-year-old philosophy & practice system of psycho-physical transformation aimed at Self-realization (Moksha). I do not think any of the ‘styles’ of ‘Yoga’ either aim for Self-realization or provide a complete system of transformation towards that end. This itself makes Hatha Yoga an odd term in the list of Yoga ‘styles’

Hatha Yoga is also not limited only to posture practice (Asana). Traditional Hatha teachings mainly give five core corporal practices, namely, Shatakarma, Asana, Pranayama, Mudra & Bandha, called Hatha Kriya. These Hatha Kriyas are done for mind-body refinement to reach the psychological state of Samadhi. Yogi Swatmarama, the author of Hatha Pradipika, emphatically states that “the knowledge of Hatha is given only for attainment of Raja Yoga” (HP 1:2). Here, Raja Yoga means path of Self-realization

Such erroneous generalizations occur because we correlate the entire system of Hatha Yoga with one of its parts, the Asana practice

If you want to refine your outlook here are suggestions

1) If you just do asana, say you do asana – no need to call it Hatha Yoga

2) Desist from referring to Hatha Yoga as a ‘style’ of Yoga

3) Do not label ‘Hatha Yoga’ as a ‘gentle’ practice because, even etymologically 'Hatha' means forceful, so, in no way it is gentle !

4) Try to view Yoga in its entirety
I am often asked how to create a regulated life with Yoga. So, here are my top 5 tips. Use them and share if you feel it will help. Cheers !

Are You ready to stand in your own shadow to go through the process of transformation and come into the light of Self?
.
The process of Yoga is not simple, not at all. For a sincere seeker spiritual bypassing is not an option. Yoga brings the worst out of you, makes you face all that you've been avoiding or delaying, only to transform and make you shine like the diamond that you are.
.
Like a raw chunk of iron that goes through the heat of the furnace and blows of a hammer to become a sword with a purpose, the Yoga sādhaka too is shaped by the trials and tribulations of life. Life is the training ground of a Yogin.
.
Accept your inadequacies, transform them with faith and meet yourSelf there where the mind rejoices in its own bliss.
.
The seeker must be ready to bring forth their inner darkness honestly, recognize it objectively and transform it lovingly.
.
This requires a lot of strength. 
Have you found the strength?
.
Who or What is your strength on the path ?

In spite of being on the Yogic path for 6 long years I am still such a mess, I don’t know if I will ever find peace” - I’ve heard such statements of defeat from my students and mentees way too many times.
 
Those of us walking sincerely on the spiritual path are in a fix of sorts. We don’t like our mental limitations but we also want quick resolution from our messy mind. Such inner tug-of-war makes us impatient with ourselves and also with the Yogic process. This impatience can result in a lot of unconscious self-harm...

This is why, I feel, it is very, very important to be patient and good to ourselves on the Yogic journey. The mind that we are dealing with has matured over thousands of life times. It has developed a personality of its own. A few years of Sadhana is simply not enough to deal with the mind that has become us. This is why, patience is a very important virtue to cultivate on the path of Yoga.
 
To be patient and good to ourselves we have to first stop comparing our spiritual journey with that of others (especially on Social Media). Just cuz’ someone has had an “extra ordinary” spiritual experience that sounds cool, doesn’t mean you too should have it – unfortunately, Social Media can make us feel that way.

You are an individual, your growth and experiences are, and will be, unique to you. Yogic spirituality and spiritual FOMO can’t go hand in hand.

Here are two tips for all who feel impatient with themselves on the Yogic journey.

• Allow yourself to ignore your little transgressions in life. Permit yourself to let some mistakes slide. It's fine to go easy with your errors and laugh at your follies. You know what, you don't have to figure out things all the time - allow things to figure themselves out sometimes.

• Don’t strain yourself in wanting to leave a mark or wanting to make it big in this world. Relax and realize that your birth is the greatest miracle and your inner contentment is your greatest contribution to the world. Be still and know.
.
What are your ways to be gentle with yourself ?
Please share 🙏🏾

Thursdays, Guruvar, the feels hit differently, always !! And today was no exception. 

Its been a year that he is gone, gone back to his 'mother'. When I asked about his whereabouts this time last year, I was told, 'Kursi se hi uthaliye unko' - he was lifted-up from the chair itself. 

He was one of the greatest Bhakta (devotee) i've known. For the last 12 years we had met many times, spoke lots, cried many tears together and melted in assuring hugs of Her loving devotion. Our laughters together, those stories of Her grace, those long pregnant silences, the muffled tears reminiscing Her, I will deeply cherish, and miss. 

When I met him, just before the pandemic lockdown, he had said "I am on a wheel-chair now but She doesn't want me to go so soon. I will serve Her till I go, till my last breath" - and that he did !

He was getting weaker by the year, I knew his time was to come soon, but those innocent eyes kept sparkling with more overflowing love as years passed by. His Love towards Hazrat was like that of a child towards his mom. His sajdā (reverence), his tasleem (surrender) is very rarely encountered. It's hard to find genuine lovers like him, those who have allowed themselves to drown in the ecstasy of loving surrender. 

Now he is with Her, resting and playing in her lap. We drank from the same spring, we were intoxicated by the same waters, as time stood still in the Rose Garden of Gulrukh. 

As Hilmi Dedebaba would say "A tent is erected where lovers are slowly cooked – this stopping place for love addicts is really a rose garden if you look...." 

God speed my friend, my fellow Lover. Our Babajan will take care of you now. You lived like a true Sufi. I will see you on the otherside, and we will continue our laughter.

My 5 week Sankhya Philosophy course will end next week. Over last 4 weeks we have deeply reflected upon a scripture called Sankhya Karika of Ishwarakrishna (5th CE). Multiple hours of discussions, home work, reflections, questioning, studying & applying has shifted something within all of us, including myself 

If I had to summarise the profound teachings of Sankhya in one sentence it would be this - Play, don't get played

The Yoga Sutra is based on Sankhya philosophy & therefore the above statement extends to it too. This is why traditionally the student studied Sankhya philosophy before studying Yoga Sutra

Both these schools tell us that we, as eternal consciousness (Purusha), are immersed in materiality called Prakriti. This Prakriti includes everything that we think we are, i.e our body, mind, thoughts, posessions & relations. 

If we are alert & use Prakriti to evolve, we realise who we truly are. If we don't, we sink deeper into the sinking pit of delusion called Sansara

So, my rescue remedy to the students is - Play the game of Prakriti, play life enthusiastically & sincerely, use whatever it brings to you & keep evolving towards your true nature (Purusha). But in the bargain, make sure you don't get played by it

The Upanishads too tell us that our anxieties are predicated upon our mind-body identities. So, play your roles, fulfil your responsibilities, don't avoid, do what you ought to, but dont get attached to any of it. Live your Dharma, not the Drama 💪🏽

My fondness for Black & White photography began in mid 90s when I came across the work of the legendary American Fashion Photographer Herb Ritts. I just couldn't understand how someone could see things in a dual tone the way he did when there was so much colour to capture.
.
It fascinated me so much that I started purposefully changing the way I viewed things in my mind. When I would look at people and things I would change perspectives in my head, flip from colour to Black & White, to dual tone, back to colour and so on. It helped me understand that what we see is what we want to see.This knowing, in my early spiritual life, helped me in my pursuit of figuring out myself. 
.
Later, in the 2000s, when I came across the work of another legendary American Fashion Photographer Bruce Webber I started appreciating the beauty of forms, human or otherwise, and seeing that everything and everyone is beautiful in their own unique way. It helped me refine my appreciation towards all forms of creation.
.
I am a recreational photographer. I love taking potraits shots of people. Photography has helped me understand that our view of Life depends on the kind of Light that illuminates our mind.
.
Please know that you all are beautiful in your own unique ways. Don't try to be like someone else, instead, see yourself in the light of your own calm mind - you will love what you will see...
.

.

This talk with @mpoweredwithmrudul was inspired from one of my favourite dialogues in the Upanishads - between Sage Yajnavalkya and his wife Maitreyee

"My dear Maitreyee, know that a wife loves her husband not for his sake but for her own sake, for the sake of the Self. In loving him she loves the One who is both in her as well as in him. It is really this One whom she loves. Similarly it is so for the husband, and indeed, for all love relationships - father and son, mother and son, mother and daughter, father and daughter, friend and friend, and so on. Whatever is held to be dear is so because of that one Self. It is this Self that has to be seen, heard of, thought about, meditated upon. This being known all else is known." -  Brihadaranyaka Upanishad, 2.4

Had a beautiful conversation with @neaferrieryoga this noon on importance of interpreting history of Yoga in context. It reminded me to repost something I had written 2 years ago

"Sanskrit is the language of Yoga" - this oft-quoted statement, with emphasis on ‘the’, ignores extensive Yogic exploration & literature that emerged over past 1500 years (if not more) through Yogis who did not fall in Sanskrit-speaking strata of Indic society

Yes, Vedas, Upanishad, Sutras, Gita & Itihasa-Purana are in Sanskrit but that’s not the end all of Indic spiritual literature

India has never been a one language land. Even modern India is a nation of 22 “official” languages - over 120 spoken ones, & over 19500 dialects, most are hundreds of years old

2500 years ago, Gautama Buddha chose to give sermons not in Sanskrit but in language of locals called Magadhi Prakrit. His teachings too were written not in Sanskrit but in Pali. Later, with influence of Tibetan Buddhism, texts were written in Tibetan languages

Over last 1500 years, Yogic Bhakti Movement saw a wave of vernacular literature that expressed ideas of Yogis that came from the rock bottom of society & reformed people using local languages because Sanskrit was NOT the language of the masses

Ramcharitmanas, a 17th CE retelling of Ramayana in Awadhi language is often called ‘5th Veda’ in north India. In the province I come from, Maharashtra, we have Dnyaneshwari, a 9000 -verse, 13th CE commentary on Bhagavad Gita, which is as sacred as the Gita but is not in Sanskrit. Divya Prabandham, a 4000-verse compilation of 12 Alvar Saints written in Tamil is considered as important as the Vedas in South India. How can one forget Thirumantiram, a 3000-verse mystical Tamil text on Shaiva Tantra by Yogi Thirumular from around 6th CE ? The texts of Sikh Gurus, & those of Sants like Mira, Kabir, Ramprasad Sen & Eknath too are not in Sanskrit

A more appropriate phrase then would be, "Sanskrit is one of the languages of Yoga" & not THE language

I am not undermining importance of Sanskrit in Yogic literature at all, but we do tend to miss out on the beautiful flowers of vernacular spiritual literature by avoiding a comprehensive view

The other day @samyayogahealing messaged me saying “I was re-reading the Yoga Sutra, and while reading one Sutra I immediately understood the reference to Sankhya philosophy, thanks to your Sankhya course”

I was so touched, because this is exactly why I had decided to teach Sankhya Darshana. The understanding of Yoga Sutra without a proper understanding of Sankhya tends to be shallow, often leading to misinterpretations.

I have always maintained that the study of Yoga philosophy should not be haphazard, because the Yogic texts are graded, based on what level of maturity the student brings to the table. There are scriptures for all levels of students and can be taught to all, depending on the context & capability. When a student randomly picks up a scripture to study, a text that does not align with their level of development, misrepresentations tend to happen. This is why having a teacher, having faith in the path of Yoga, being patient with ourselves, & being accountable to our own practice (sadhana) are the four key traits of Swadhyaya.

Sharing here 3 points in which Sankhya Darshana can be lived.These points were a part of my Sankhya course’s concluding slide. Hope they inspire you to stay positive on the path.

• Your mind & body are Prakriti. Sankhya says Prakriti is generous and selfless.Therefore, use your mind and body as a precious resource, with respect and responsibility.

• No matter what Drama you are going through in life – remember, the True Self (Purusha) is always beyond it. So, work through your life situations and keep refining yourself till you realize your True Self.

• Your current state of mind and life are not absolute. You are not stuck in your situation. Yes, the mind and emotions can be transformed with dedication, faith, and effort. Life situations can be surmounted, as far as you don’t get distracted. Keep the faith, and stay on the path with a one-pointed focus. 
.

An important point to note by all who are into study of Yoga, Yoga philosophy & Yogic culture is that India is not a nation of one language & one ideology. India has always been a land of diverse languages, sub-cultures, localized traditions - including languages, scripts, customs and ways of life, that has thrived over the past 3500 years. 

Here's an example. Today we celebrate our New Year. But, as seen in the picture, it is called by different names & even celebrated in different ways in parts of the country. At times the rituals and customs are so different that one can't even recognize if its the same festival 

This diversity is the hallmark of India and the accompanying complexity needs to be kept in context when studying Yoga. If not, things come across as ambiguous and confusing, making the student feel they dont know enough.

I talk to many Yoga teachers who have a genuine interest in wanting to understand Yogic history and culture but they approach the subject with a unidimensional mindset, i.e, to know Yoga through one book or one lineage. Such a mindset will only offer a partial view of Yoga.

Looking at the complex interconnectedness of ideas, philosophies and traditions stretching across thousands of years, Yoga should be recognized as a complex body of knowledge that ought to be studied patiently, over time, in context, under someone who has lived and studied in the ecosystem of its origins.

When one has an understanding of the complexity of the subject one is studying, it is easier to keep up the motivation to study. 

Yogic study is not a short term pursuit of knowledge but a long term commitment to self-understanding.

On the path of spiritual self-transformation no amount of growth can be experienced if one suffers from an uncomfortable relationship with self. An inner discord, where one is opposed to one’s own self, is a formula for suffering.
.
A body in which the limbs and organs refuse to cooperate, a mind where hundreds of opposing voices give thousands of opinions, rambling away night and day,  an inner dialogue which allies with self-criticism to create an army of deceivers within, an attitude of constant comparison that looks at self through other’s eyes, where worry and anxiety makes our very existence feel like a battle-field – if such a system is running you, then you don’t need enemies because you have become your own enemy. 
.
Our life is not a battle field, it shouldn’t feel like one. If it feels so, then take a step back and introspect. Reach out for help and assistance if needed, work yourself out.
.
The Bhagavad Gita says, if you help yourself grow, you are your own friend, if you subjugate yourself and deny yourself the glory and abundance of Self, then you are your own enemy. 
.
It’s time to become your own friend first. Friendship is an attitude, a commitment. Let that attitude and commitment be diverted inwardly, allowing you to bring you closer to yourself.
.
The world is not opposing you, there is no enemy out there, there's no one stopping you, please don't stop yourself. Become your own friend.

This old pic. popped up today. After a 4-month silence (mauna sadhana) I had the honor to tend to the Dhuni (sacred fire) of Mahayogi Matsyendra Nath, the founder of Hatha path of Yoga. It prompted me to post this,

The inspiration behind asanas that we practice comes mainly from the Hatha tradition.The Hatha Marga (path) has its own profound concepts & philosophy that takes the seeker all the way to Moksha, Self-realization

Below are a few couplets from an old scripture of the Hatha tradition. It is a dialogue between the Guru, Matsyendra Nath & his disciple, Gorakh Nath. I had translated them in English from Awadhi language back when I was studying them with my teacher. The teachings mentioned below may not be immediately relevant to us but they do give us a glimpse into the depth of symbolism & the profundity of the Hatha path. Enjoy,

Gorakh: What is root, what is branch? Who is Guru, who is disciple? In what essence can one delight in the Self?

Matsyendra replies: Mind is root, Prana is branch. Om (shabda) is Guru, scripture (shastra) is disciple. The essence is Self-realization, in which one wanders rejoicing

Gorakh: What is seed, what is field? What is direct hearing (shravan)? What is true vision? What is Yoga, what is its method? What is liberation? & what is salvation?

Matsyendra replies: The word (OM) is seed, perception is field. Scriptural teaching is direct hearing & discriminative discernment is true vision. Ocean is Yoga & land is method, light is liberation & flames are salvation

Gorakh: What is creator of body & from where does radiance (Tej) arise? What is mouth of Divine wisdom? How can Unseen be seen?

Matsyendra replies: Absolute is the creator of body, out of Absolute radiance arises, nothingness is the mouth of Divine wisdom & via Guru's grace & realization of disciple alone the unseen is seen

Gorakh: How many thousand moons exist in body? How does fragrance reside in flower? Where does ghee hide in milk? How does Atman mask itself in body?

Matsyendra replies: There are 200,000 moons in body. Fragrance is the eternal essence in flower. Ghee is immanent in milk & the Atman is all-pervasiveness in body, always

Every night as she went to bed, I would go kiss her goodnight & lie next to her as she lovingly pat my head. At times I would throw my arm around her & invariably every time she would say endearingly "ah, you have become big now, your weight will squish me". This had become our ritual of sorts. One such day, I threw my arm around her but she didn't react to my "sleep well mumma", she had left her body, she was dead

Death of our dear ones is traumatic indeed but, somewhere, it is also a reminder to us of our own eventual departure. Each streak of grey, every new wrinkle, every age spot is an invitation to pay heed to what truly matters

Inquiry into death is an integral part of traditional Yoga. Upanishads are full of it. Patanjali too refers to it as Abhinivesha. In Mahabharata, a celestial Crane intercepted Yudhishthira & asked him, "what is the greatest wonder?” Yudhishthira replied that humans know death is inevitable, yet they live as if it will not happen to them. Truly, how hard we try to distract ourselves from accepting this fact by labeling death as something bad/evil or by hoarding stuff, or obsessing over our physical body

Optimize your living. Make every moment count. Do not wait to sing the song & dance the dance you always wanted to. Embrace your existence in the now, settle your conflicts, make closures, simplify life & lighten yourself. Living in fear, worry, regret & guilt is just not worth it. Yes, there is primal anxiety deeply ingrained in us, but only in honest acceptance of death can one make life truly meaningful

I've been fascinated by the topic of death since my childhood, maybe cuz' I was a hyper-anxious sickly child always in & out of hospitals. My inquiry into death deepened after death of my beloved parents which happened in quick succession. I believe life is preparing us every moment for our eventual passing. My parent’s death hit me hard but it also empowered me. It woke me up from the deep slumber of taking my life for granted. I now see life & death as warp & woof of the very existence, a continuum of sorts. 

I feel dealing with death is an important process we all need to learn from. Death is truly a great teacher 🙏🏾

When you pinch & zoom into your selfie, you realize that it is just a group of Pixels coming together to form an image that you call ‘my selfie’

The same way, what you believe to be your ‘self’ is just ideas, concepts & conditionings coming together to form an individuality that you so fondly call ‘my self’

There is no difference between your selfie & your self per se – both are formed by & dependent upon something else. In the case of self, it’s the ideas, & in the case of selfie, it’s the pixels. Both are virtual, apparent & not really real

Indian & Western philosophers have dissected the problem of self for over 2500 years

Buddhism says that ‘self’ is just a byproduct of desires & attachments. If you like, there is a video of my talk on this Buddhist theory - the concept of Pratītyasamutpāda on my Youtube channel

Even, Advaita Vedanta of Adi Shankara says that the ‘self’ is an illusion (mithyā) & that all there is, is Brahman (Universal Consciousness)

In the Yoga Sutra, Patanjali calls it Asmitā which results from Avidyā, the misconception of regarding Purusha as Prakriti

In the West too, thinkers like Plato, Descartes, Hume, Freud & Heidegger have challenged the idea of self

As more & more of us spend time on Social Media, especially as Entrepreneurs, our attachment to the idea of self becomes tighter. We start taking our self too seriously - well, cuz' there's a 'self' brand at stake 😄

So much time & energy invested in protecting & moulding this idea of 'self' according to public perception & trends. The more this 'self' becomes real, the more the anxiety. No doubt we are so exhausted !!

Relax, your self is as virtual as your selfie. Be kind to this self (& others'), have clarity in what you want to do in life, & try to live in contentment & simplicity

Everything is dispensable, even you. Recognize this & don’t unnecessarily get anxious about being something that others are, or what others think you should be

Focus your energies instead on discovering what you truly are beyond the ideas of 'self' you have created in your head. This is what Yoga is truly all about

Chill, don’t take yourself seriously but do take yourself sincerely

Have fun ❤️

As legacy media houses & social media platforms are bought over by corporations that are more or less hand-in-glow with political & secterian establishment, we are all well entrenched in what economist call Techno-Feudalism 

As digital media becomes a mainstream source of spiritual learning, many are overwhelmed by amount of information out there. Most people I counsel is on topic of spiritual information overwhelm 

With 100s of videos on different modalities, 1000s of articles on varied philosophies, millions of influencers telling us what to do, Algorithms determining what to watch, AI telling us how we should communicate, & increasingly anxious society where an average American spends 5.5 hrs & Indian spends 3.5 hrs glued to phone, no doubt we are sensorily overloaded & mentally overwhelmed

Personaly, I like to be well-informed, & think I am fairly well-informed, but I don't need to be informed about everything happening in the world. This is why I am not on Whatsapp, Twitter, TikTok or Linkedin, out of choice. Does it affect my work? Yes, it does badly. I've been told I am not 'well-connected' in spiritual groups or Yoga communities. But for me that is a price I am willing to pay for my mental peace & I value my peace the most 😊 

We all have an anxious core. Unbridled information consumption triggers innate fight-flight anxiety. More the trigger, more we consume, & more someone makes money out of our fears. More the Fear, more the Purchase

Be aware of what & how much information you consume, & why. You have a choice

Information is the nutrition of mind, just as food is nutrition of body. Be a consumer, not the consumed.

Reflect & reach your own conclusion 🙏

.
As my hair line started receeding, 
they were appalled.
It doesnt look good they said, 
you are going bald.

When I started going grey, 
they had a lot to say.
I refused to color my hair,
much to their dismay.

And when wrinkles started showing up
adorning my face with crow's feet.
They handed out to me anti-wrinkle creams
and anti-ageing diets to eat

All this while projecting their own fears on me 
and wanting me to get scared too.
Fears of degeneration and death of their body, 
because body is all that they knew.

There are instances when we feel vexed, frustrated, and out of sorts. But when you hurt - you don't just internalize those feelings for yourself; you also inflict them upon others. 

A wise man once said know thyself, meaning not only knowing oneself intellectually or emotionally but feeling the truth about oneself internally.

To achieve this, Maun Sadhana was taught in India as a cure-all for all ills. This ancient practice helps us cleanse and free ourselves from mental strife which can be traced back to the root cause of suffering - which is ignorance. Step by step, the process leads to our highest spiritual goal: freedom from all emotional discomforts from ignorance.

Discover the insights and wisdom that Prasad Rangnekar provides on Maun Sadhana and its power to transform our lives! Take a few minutes out of your day and read our blog to learn more about the impact of Maun meditation and to have all of your questions answered.

Thank You for your generous response to my upcoming Emotion Management course. I consider Emotion management a Life Skill, just like swimming, hygiene, & decision-making, something we all need to learn as the world becomes increasingly anxious & uncertain

Curiously enough, someone asked if the course was about ‘Nervous System Hacks', another asked if it was about ‘Brain rewiring’ – it made me write this 👇🏼

I know the subject of Nervous System regulation is trendy (& very useful). But, there is a specific reason why my course is titled ‘Yoga Based Emotion Management’ & not ‘Nervous System Regulation’ or 'Brain Hack'

I refuse to reduce emotions to Limbic (Neuronal) activity alone, as I do not prescribe to the materialism theory of mind (physicalism). Though I accept that the Neural Correlates of human emotions can be demonstrated by Brain scans, for me emotions are a complex phenomenon arising out of intricate interactions of many variables that can’t be reduced to physical parts alone

Secondly, the course is ‘Yoga based’ Emotion Management. Traditional Yoga works with the self in context. The subjective aspect of an experience (called Qualia) is crucial to any Yogic exploration, including the explorations in my course 

I have not seen any solid argument that can comprehensively explain the qualitative characteristics of a person’s experience. This is because subjective experiences are not reducible to physical properties of the Brain/Nervous system alone

Eg: The Blue color of a Krishna idol makes me cry out of devotion, but for someone, it is just a color that hardly creates any excitation response. The experience of ‘Blue’ in both is different

This is what makes emotions subject-specific. This is also why my course gives importance to components of self-introspection, self-reflection, & witnessing because one trigger could arouse different responses in different subjects

Though we will also work with Nervous System regulation, the course is not all about that. It is a deep dive into creating personal accountability towards one’s own emotions – the kind of work I feel is more comprehensive than generic Nervous System ‘hacks’

So, what makes one a Yoga practitioner?
- Understanding anatomy ?
- Expertise at headstand ?
- Chanting Vaidic Mantra ?
- Yoga Alliance accredition ?
- "Lineage" tag for credentials ?
- 50K followers on Insta ?
- Knowledge of Sanskrit ?

What if someone had none of the above, would they still be considered a Yoga practitioner ?

Guess not from modern Yoga view but from a traditional Yogic perspective - Yes, because the above mentioned requirements are supplimentary & optional, NOT core to Yogic practitioner's growth

The core of a Yoga practitioner lies in,
- Faithful Commitment to Sadhana
- Curiousity & critical thinking mindset
- Viewing Yoga as a path of self understanding
- Honoring the history & roots of Yoga, &
- Above all, being humble & empathetic

You may be a master of anatomy & biomechanics but may not be doing your sadhana. You may know Sanskrit & Veda Mantra but it may have become a tool for you to gain social validation. Insta Followers can be bought & also can teaching certificates & accreditions. These days one can professes initiation in a 'traditional lineage' even without being officially initiated by the Guru. So, none of these claims automatically assert one as a Yoga Sadhaka. Stocking up on more qualifications & newer modalities may not be the only thing that makes one a sincere student practitioner. The context goes much deeper than that

Social Media world is full of suggestions of "How a Yoga practitioner should be". We knowingly or unknowingly buy into popular ideas & try to mould ourselves accordingly, completely missing the point that the core of Yogic process is about realizing who you are & not trying to be what others say you should be or be what others are

In my understanding, a Yoga Ssdhaka is someone who lives with faith in Yoga & is committed to the Yogic process to make their mind lighter & life simpler

Faith & commitment is the Key to Yoga

To go deeper in unwavering faith & unshaken commitment has been my own personal Yoga practice ethos, & it has held me in steady for the past four decades of spiritual struggle & confusion

Life may not have become easy or exciting but it has surely become simpler & meaningful with it 🙏

Since childhood Indian kids are told that Hanuman's essence is his physical strength. But I always used to wonder what was the source of his strength
.
As I understood Hanuman more, I realized that his essence is not his physical strength per se, but what lies beneath it 
.
Hanunan's essence is his Bhakti, devotion to his Lord, Shri Rama. In every context of his life, Hanuman's Bhakti allowed him to get his ego out of the way. Its as if he became a nobody. When he got his ego out of the way he became the channel of the Universal Consciousness itself, which was none other than Shri Rama
.
Channeling the powers of Universal Consciousness by melting away one's ego through Bhakti is the lesson Hanuman's life teaches us
.
His life reminds us that though we all have an animal, a monkey (mind) within, anyone can attain the heights of spiritual mastery simply through devotion and discipline
.
Since Yoga is the ability to control one's mind, Hanuman is also the perfect Yogi, having mastered his senses and mind solely through selfless devotion (bhakti)
.
His Bhakti also makes him a perfect Karma Yogi, the one who performs his actions with detachment, selflessly, purely out of love & compassion rather than selfish motives
.
Thus, for me, Hanuman is a perfect Yogi. He is an ideal of how Bhakti (Yoga) can flower into Karma (Yoga)
.
Having perfected his mind through Bhakti, Hanuman embodies the highest potential we can achieve if we let our ego get out of the way
.
May Shri Hanuman's devotion inspire us to let our Faith eliminate our Fears
.
Wish you an inspired Hanuman Jayanti 🙏🏾

One day, no matter what, you'll have to come around and forgive yourself for not being kind to yourself in the past.
That very day, you will let go off the impossible standards of your inner critic and  the heaviness of your heart will immediately melt away.
But remember, the basis of forgiveness cannot be in anger and resentment. It has to emerge from genuine self-compassion.
Be gentle with yourself as you balm your past wounds, your resentments and hurts. 
Know that forgiveness is the bravest act you can do for yourself, and the widest step you can cover towards yourself. 
Your act of forgiveness will let you unconditionally accept yourself for who you are and be empathetic with yourself for what you did. 
So, treat yourself kindly, 
close your eyes, 
be brave, and 
go on, do it - Forgive yourself.
And then, repeat.
Keep repeating. 
.

For me, the essence of Easter is in knowing that we can rise above our sufferings. Move away the boulder of self-doubt & emerge from the darkness of your own limiting beliefs. There is life beyond 'death' if you can rise in Love
 
Jesus is an inspiration of Love for me, the Love that Loves till the end, whatever that end may be. In John, it is seen how much Jesus loved his people & how much he urged them to love one another, “Jesus knew that the hour had come for him to leave this world & go to the Father. Having loved his own who were in the world, he loved them to the end.” (John 13:1). “A new command I give you: Love one another. As I have loved you, so you must love one another. By this, everyone will know that you are my disciples, if you love one another.” (John 13:34-35)

Resurrection points at the immortal nature of Being. Physical death is not the end of our existence. We all are more than our embodied form. We have the power within to elevate ourselves in faith & raise ourselves to the level of immortality, as Paul mentions “For as by a man came death, by a man has come also the resurrection of the dead. For as in Adam all die, so also in Christ shall all be made alive.” (1 Corinthians 15:21-22)

Peter also says, “he has caused us to be born again to a living hope through the resurrection of Jesus Christ from the dead, to an inheritance that is imperishable, undefiled, and unfading..” (1 Peter 1:3-4)

The gist of Christ’s teachings can be presented in this beautiful quote by St. Augustine in De Magistro, he says “Our real Teacher is he who is listened to, who is said to dwell in the inner man, namely Christ, that is, the unchangeable power and eternal wisdom of God”

Some of Christ's teaching are similar to the Upanishadic teachings. As Kathopanishad says, "when limiting desires for the transient fade away, the mortal becomes immortal & attains Absolute" (Kathopanishad 2:3:14)

Both, Christ & Upanishads talk about importance of self-transformation, inner-light, love, devotion & compassionate service to all 

This Easter let's pray for healing & unity of all 
Rise above the fear of the other & keep Loving 🙏

How did Arjuna go from
“I can no longer stand, my knees are weak, my mind is clouded and spinning. I am confused about my duties and what is good for me.” in the early chapters, 
to
“I have discovered clarity in my mind and my purpose. I am no longer in illusion” in the last chapter ?

Arjuna could turn around his mind because, the Bhagavad Gita, and Yoga in general, is all about transforming the mind. All Yoga paths, no matter what modes they use, the body or the sound, are directed ultimately toward refining the mind.

Emotion management is the most important aspect of Mind Management, because Mind communicates through emotions.The Yogic texts give us a variety of methods to manage limiting emotions, methods that have been tried and tested by Yogis for over 3 millenea. 

When limiting emotions are managed, overwhelm and anxiety decrease, energy leakages reduce and the mind becomes focused on what needs to be done. When the mind is clear, calm, and centered, the potential energy of the mind can be harnessed towards self-evolution and growth of the society.

If you would like to understand your emotions from the Yogic perspective and would like to know how to manage the basal, limiting emotions, my Yoga-based Emotion Management course is just what you need.

More info on the link in Bio

See you in the course.

This post from 10 years ago showed up today as a memory. Interestingly, it talks about Yoga as a Community endeavour even before the concept of Yoga Communities was a thing

I have always believed that the future of modern Yoga will not merely be in teaching classes. Don't get me wrong, the class model is excellent, but I believe it is a door way to something bigger, i.e. its an opportunity to generate a sense of camaraderie, community, togetherness amongst fellow Yoga students

A sense of Community awakens a shared sense of belonging, which I see as Bhakti

Even back in the day when I used to teach classes in Mumbai the student groups had organically become a Community of sorts, most of whom are still in touch with each other though oceans apart.

In ancient times & even today in some traditional setups, the student group/s of the teachers galvanize in a Community, a Sangha. The Sangha then functions as a support system, which one relies on when the spiritual path becomes challenging

So, here is my little dream

"Each Yoga teacher, building a humble community of sincere students, guiding them as a facilitator through methods of Yoga, transforming themselves, inspiring others and in turn raising that community’s awareness, where Yoga is not seen only as a practice but as a process, not only as a class but as a mindset, not only as a feel-good activity but as a life-long transformative modality"

I have dreamt of millions of such Yoga communities sprung around the world in the near future, creating hot spots of raised awareness, positivity and peace making Yoga simple and accessible

My respects and gratitude to the students and teachers who are together in this dream and are working in their own way to create such communities. This is the very ideal of Lokasangraha that the Bhagavad Gita talks about

Will you dream this dream with me and wake up to achieve it ?

You may say I'm a dreamer, but (I’m sure) I'm not the only one… 😊

Share the post & Share the dream

In 2015, during my 300 Hour Teacher Training high up in the Himalayas, I went for my regular evening walk and saw these lil' ones playing in the earth. When asked what they were doing, I was told that they were making a house. So, I asked them if they could build me one as well. 

After a short conversation amongst themselves they said they would make a cave for me instead. For some reason they thought a cave was more appropriate for me 😄

So, it was decided that I would be back in an hour or so and find my cave ready.

What I found after coming back was one of the most intricate and innocent creation I had ever seen, a cave dug out of the earth and tastefully decorated with delicate, colourful flowers.

I found a new home (cave) but lost my heart to these lil' angels in the bargain.

I made 3 new friends, Naina, Sonam and Issu, for the next few days and played with them and their two cows, Gautam and Maya.

Simplicity of life and innocence of heart gives joy that an overwhelmed life and a restless mind misses out on. 

Take time to make your hands dirty in the earth, roll around in the grass, sleep naked under the twinkling stars, climb a tree, breathe deeply, write a poem, sing with the river, dance wild in your room, laugh with your friends, and kiss a butterfly.

Keep your life simple, keep your mind peaceful.

You won't regret it, ever ❤️

This is an incident from one of my stays in a monastery in central India around 14 years ago. 

It was about 4.00 p.m. A visiting Bhagat (devotee) started arranging firewood to make afternoon chai. We all were fast asleep. I heard some noise and immediately jumped up to help him with the preparations. I went to fetch water from the well as he started lighting up the Dhuna (fire pit). 

It was our daily afternoon routine. Post-lunch we all would sit on the porch and talk philosophy or sing Bhajans, after which everyone would just lay on their side and take a nap. When I was not pestering Peerji (the Abbot of the monastery) with my questions or feeding the cows, I would also join them and get some rest. 

As the hot Chai was being served in clay cups, one visiting Sadhu happened to burn his tongue while sipping Chai in hurry. We all laughed. Peerji gave him a stern look. Yet we all couldn’t help but notice the innocent twinkle in his eye and his smirk. 

It is said that a Guru never misses an opportunity to teach the student. Seizing the opportunity, Peerji recited a couplet in Awadhi language which I will try to translate. It is a dialogue between tongue and teeth. I am sure you all will enjoy it

‘Hum battees, tu akeli, vase hamari mai,
jara bahar nikle lo, hum sau kaati jai.’

The teeth say to the tongue in a condescending manner, 
"We are 32 and you are all alone, bound by us. If you stick out even a bit, we will bite you."
 
To this the tongue replies,

"Rasana kahe dasan ko, tum kahat hain sanch, 
Par hum tedhi baath kahein, to battes pade khanch."

"You are right in what you say, but the moment I move in a crooked way, you all will be knocked out."

The wise Peerji had seized that simple incident to drive home a very important point which I want to share with y'all 

– strength may not always be in numbers, a single person, with clarity and confidence, can move mountains. 

Don't put yourself down. 
You are strong in what you are.
Believe in your self.

Have a good day 🙏🏽

Starting a new series called ‘Discomforting Conversations’ to reflect upon & invite inquiry into topics & issues of Yoga industry that are not usually discussed, for whatever reason

A ‘Job Description’ details main duties & responsibilities of a professional or an employee

Few months ago a Yoga teacher complained to me that despite studying for 2 years in an ashram in North India, he has to teach ‘butt workouts’ & slimming modalities in class. Some weeks back another Yoga teacher told me how her Yoga classes have changed into ‘Nervous System healing’ sessions in the last 2 years. Both posed the same questions – Where is Yoga in this? 
Am I even a Yoga teacher?

The 'Yoga industry' is still in its infancy & grappling to find its identity by heavily experimenting with hybridization & trend integration. Somewhere, the strain of this experimentation is borne by the Yoga teacher

An Accounting Clerk is responsible for maintaining financial records, running reports, & recording transactions. A Sous Chef ensures nothing goes wrong in the kitchen, from ordering ingredients to keeping inventory list, ensuring cleanliness, & providing Head Chef with everything they need

Do we have a clear Job Description of a Yoga Teacher in the contemporary Yoga industry? Nope!!

They have to teach asana & also guarantee ‘good workout’. They have to counsel students & also offer diet guidance. They are seen as healers, spiritual guides, therapists, care-givers, confidants & even channelers. They are expected to have knowledge of Ayurveda / Anatomy / Nutrition / Shamanism & also be an ace at Tech. They are expected to sing kirtans, guide meditations, chant Sanskrit Mantras, activate 3rd eye, know philosophy, read Tarot & astrology charts & yes, be an activist too – all this with a serene face as if an epitome of detachment

The contemporary Yoga Teacher’s Job Description is ambiguous, if not all over the place - like that of a surgeon who is expected to be anaesthetist, nurse, cook & also an ambulance driver

Have you felt the overwhelm of wearing too many hats, the stress of juggling multiple roles & the confusion - "am I even a Yoga teacher?"

Today is the World Book Day. Have you ever wondered what the difference between a Yoga Book & a Yoga Scripture (text) is?

Words printed on paper that are bound together is considered a book. So, in that sense, any Yoga Scripture fulfilling the above conditions is a Book. But, qualitatively speaking, a Yoga Scripture is much more than just a bound piece of printed information

Yoga has been codified & presented in what is known as the Shāstra. Shāstra means ‘the one that saves through its teaching’. Thus, Yoga Shāstra are not mere texts but a compendium of knowledge specific to spiritual liberation

The Yoga Shāstras are not considered mere books in the Yogic tradition but living entities. They are so highly regarded that Adi Shankara, 9th CE, compares Shāstra to a mother who lovingly feeds & teaches her child. The Gitā says that we should study the scriptures, practice what is mentioned in them & spiritually elevate ourselves. The Shāstra aims to guide, educate & motivate the seekers to facilitate their own liberation.

There are thousands of Yoga scriptures written over thousands of years. They are not haphazard in order. Different texts present knowledge at a different level of maturity & are to be studied depending on one's maturity. One can segregate Yogic scriptures (Shāstra) into three types,

• Scriptures that present only the theory, 
• the ones that explain only techniques/practices &, 
• the ones that present both, theory & practice

Here are three points that can help you navigate your Scriptural study (Swādhyāya)

1) Do not just read through a Yogic text like a novel. Study it, practice what’s given in it patiently, & reflect on its content to contemplate deeply on your self & your life 

2) Study the Yogic texts with a teacher, at least initially, because the symbolism, grammar, contexts & interpretation could be misconstrued

3) Handle & treat the Yogic scriptures (even in form of printed books or e-books) with regard, respect & humility, as if you would treat a person. This is why in India the students don’t touch a book with their feet or sit on a book or use it as a Yoga prop. Yoga texts in form of books are considered Goddess Saraswati herself

Our body is our residence.
And just like owning a house warrants a
sense of responsibility, our body too needs 
to be handled responsibly.
.
Just like one doesnt go about denting the walls of one's house, don't scar your body in your posture practice trying to chase someone else's benchmark of postural perfection.
.
Generate an understanding of YOUR own musculoskeletal, biomechanical, myofascial and neuronal integrity at the gross level and develop deeper sensitivity to YOUR own subtle prāna, nādi, ādhāra and lakshya at the energetic level. By knowing yourself at both these levels your body wont feel like a house that you live in, but like a home that you thrive in.
.
Your body is the home for the self.
Your body is the address for this life.
Its the address that your anxious mind
comes back to for sanity, 
its the home that your exhausted being 
comes back to for safety.
Make your stay at this address an 
experience of a lifetime, literally.
.
Cheers ❤️

Today is Adi Shankaracharya Jayanti & my mind goes back to 2015 to the beautiful times when this picture was taken.

It was during my stay & study at the Shri Sharada Peetham, one of the four main monasteries aligned with the Advaita Vedanta thought founded by Adi Shankara Acharya. Mornings were spent doing japa on the foot steps of the 1200 year old Śrī Śāradāmba temple after meeting, listening & talking to the then Shankaracharya, Shri Bharathitirtha Swami, the head of an equally old, unbroken succession of Acharyas of Advaita Vedanta, starting from Adi Shankara himself

Adi Shankaracharya was one of the most important philosopher, Yogi Saints of India and the main propagator of Advaita Vedanta Darshana - non-dual Vedanta philosophy. 

I am as inspired by his Managerial and Leadership qualities as I am by his intellect and devotion. Those who do not know of him, please read up - it will inspire you too. 

Here are three quotes from Adi Shankara that have helped me in my life by giving me a direction.

Living his teachings would be the best way to wish him and celebrate the occasion 🙏🏾

"Drop the pride of wealth, people, relations, friends and youth. All these will be swallowed by time in the blink of an eye. Giving up your attachment to this apparent world, realize and attain the Supreme." 

"Like the appearance of silver in mother of pearl, the world seems real at first, until the Self, the  fundamental  reality is realized." 

"Knowing that I am different from the body, I need not neglect the body. It is a vehicle that I use to transact with the world. It is the temple which houses the Pure Self within.
.
Video 1: was shot in Omkareshwar, in Madhya Pradesh, where Adi Shankara was initiated by his Guru Shri Govindabhagavadpada

Video 2: is one of my fav places in the world, Kalady in Kerala, where Adi Shankara was born. The video shows the serene Periyar river. I've taken so many students to this place & all gave been charmed by its beauty

This question is so hotly debated in the Yoga world that since last 3 year I repost this piece once every year. So, here goes... 

Well, the answer is not a simple Yes or No,  because Indian culture is very complex

The word ‘Namaste’, pronounced ‘nuh+muh+stey’, originates in Sanskrit but is mainly used only in a few North Indian regions. Most of India does NOT say Namaste. (Note: India has 121 major & 1600 minor languages) 

Other regions use variants like Namaskar, Namo Namaha, Namaskara, Namaskaram etc

Etymologically, Namaste means 
“my respectful obeisance to you”
Namaḥ = respectful obeisance & te = to you 

‘Namaste’ is NOT just a word, its a practice comprising 3 parts 
• the spoken word
• the gesture (joining hands/bowing head/genuflecting/touching feet/prostrating) 
• the intention

Intention is the main part, without which saying or doing Namaste is mere tokenism 

Through Namaste or its variants we convey the intention of honoring the other, human or non-human. In India, especially in temples & rituals, we ‘Namaste’ to children, Elephants, Cows & Rats too, & NOT only elders

The practice of Namaste is a beautiful practice that reminds us to honor the formless Divine behind the physical form

Some must have seen Thai Airways Flight Staff do a Namaste gesture & greet passengers on board – I love this practice & immediately feel welcomed 

Colloquially, Namaste has become a casual greeting amongst Hindi speakers & could be equated to a Hello or a Bye. Many do it as a token, tradition, or as a socio-cultural norm. Yet, the term still carries its original intent

In my mother language (Marathi) we say ‘Namaskar’ instead of Namaste, when we meet someone, say bye, when we start a letter, when we sign off a note - the aim is to convey the intention. The same with 'Namaste'

Looking at the rising intolerance, trolling & cancel-culture in our society I think we all need some TLC through a heartfelt, sincere Namaste (or its variants)

What do you think?

Imagine if we all sincerely meant “I offer my respectful obeisance to you” & consciously reminded ourselves of the divinity behind everyone we encounter, how peaceful our world would be? 

Pls Share

Namaste🙏🏽

Imposter Syndrome is something that everyone’s talking about, but Maharishi Patanjali had warned us about it already, around 2000 years ago...

I am sure most of us have heard about it, but here is a gist anyway

Imposter Syndrome is when one feels like a fraud, often unqualified & undeserving, despite the opposite being true. It usually manifests as self-doubt, negative self-talk, nervousness during task performance & so on

An example would be a Yoga Teacher, who has good enough qualifications, & experience of study & teaching, constantly feeling not good enough or not deserving enough to be teaching Yoga. Almost every day I receive messages or emails from teachers around the world expressing this feeling

Though the term has gained traction in recent years the context has been discussed by Maharishi Patanjali in his Yoga Sutra a couple of centuries ago. Even the Bhashyakars (traditional commentators) have elaborated on it over two millenia

Patanjali talks about ‘Samshaya’ - doubtful thoughts, that emerge due to our ignorance of what is. One traditional commentator called Bhoja Raja says Samshaya is about doubting the practice of Yoga itself. In the same Sutra, Patanjali talks about Bhranti Darshana, delusional perception. Shankaracharya says Bhranti Darshana is having misconceptions about one’s Yoga practice. [PYS 1:30]

Apart from the above, Patanjali also mentions a type of Vritti (conception) called Viparyaya, i.e false knowledge – a kind of mental state which is far removed from the right knowledge of things [PYS 1:8]

Thus, all throughout the Yoga Sutra Patanjali has indicated the experience of what we know nowadays call ‘The Imposter Syndrome’

So, how can we handle Imposter Syndrome from Patanjali’s view?

Patanjali would say that the Imposter Syndrome is based in our primal ignorance of our True Nature, Avidya. To remove it, we need to work on our fundamental misconception of Self

Inorder to work on it we need to gradually work on making our mind one-pointed [PYS 1:32] & this can happen only by Abhyasa (consistent, long-term practice) & Vairagya (detachment) [PYS 1:12]

This is how, the model of Patanjali's Yoga is as relevant as it was back then

In the popular Yoga culture we have heard that Maharishi Patanjali defines Asana as ‘Sthira & Sukha’ - or that’s the part that gets most attention

For some reason, the term ‘Sthira’ has come to be seen as ‘Perfection’ of a pose, demanding years of effort, along with the stress, dejection, injuries & burnout that comes with chasing perfection. The performative postural Yoga stance too pumps up this drive.The Bodybuilding adage ‘No Pain, No Gain’ has quietly filtered into the practice ethos of some modern Yoga asana ‘styles’ over the past decades

But, does Patanjali ask us to push our efforts and strive in Asana?

No, in fact, he states exactly the opposite. He asks us to relax the effort or the exertion

For Patanjali, Asana is a steady postural seat, taken to facilitate subtler practices like Pranayama (2:49)

He says, Asana becomes Sthira & Sukha – Steady & Comfortable (or agreeable) only by dropping effort & absorbing thoughts into the infinite

प्रयत्नशैथिल्यानन्तसमापत्तिभ्याम् ॥४७॥
prayatna-śaithilya-ananta-samāpattibhyām ||2:47||

Dropping the effort or strain then is a crucial component of Asana without which the Asana would not be able to facilitate further subtler practices like Pranayama, because a striving mind cannot be channeled towards a steady-state (Ekagra Chitta)

A strained, effortful body, that is continuously in a heightened state of arousal, just cannot facilitate subtler practices 

The Vyasa Bhashya, the most important commentary on Yoga Sutra, says - Effortlessness stops the body from being shaky. Such effortless steadiness of Asana is called Asanajaya, or, mastery of Asana in Yoga Sutra (Vyasa Bhashya 2:48)

There's a thin line between dedicated effort and obsessive exertion, and that thin line is of patience

This is why the Yoga Sadhaka needs to be acutely self-aware during Asana & consciously work on making the Asana joyful and effortless

How do you cultivate effortlessness in your own Asana sadhana ?

As Yoga teachers, we love our analogies, imageries, hyperboles, our ‘breathe through your feet…, our ‘melt your body into the floor...’ and all that – don’t we? 😊 I am sure we take it with a pinch of salt, and let it pass

But what happens when Absolute Statements are used for spiritual bypassing?

There is a hazard of getting carried away by absolute statements like “we are all consciousness”, “there is nothing to do”, "it’s all here and now", “everything is love”, "its all Oneness" etc., without keeping the context in mind
 
In modern spirituality we are surrounded by quotes. Spiritual Quotes do help us stay motivated. But, transferring statements made by mystics from their absolute states onto our present reality to escape self-work is an act of self-delusion
 
The Upanishadic teachings clearly state that between the Guru telling the disciple “Tat Tvam Asi” - You are THAT, and the disciple experientially proclaiming “Aham Brahma Asmi” - I am THAT, lies an intense journey of hard work, sacrifice, detachment, anxiety & doubt that continuously tests our faith, resilience, surrender, patience & clarity. 

Arjuna had to go through the grind even though he had, literally, the Supreme God, as his best friend

Yoga is NOT a path of Spiritual bypassing

Yes, it is indeed enchanting to bathe in quotes of J. Krishnamurthy, Buddha, Ramana Maharishi, or Rumi. Their words do inspire us.

But the reason for this post is - over the years, I have met way too many who take these statements literally & completely lose connection with their subjective reality.
 
Our troubles are not due to Absolute reality, God, True Self, whatever you call it. It's the mundane, the day-to-day transactional reality, that tests us & challenges us

Using Absolute ideas, to avoid challenges of self-growth, is an act of self-denial

Try to figure out how to rise above the entrapments of transactional reality. Your personal Sadhana & your trust will help in this pursuit.

When you can stabilize your mind in the seemingly contradictory experiences & triggers of day-to-day life, you will naturally experience the steadiness of Absolute within.

Today is a very special day for me. Some 38 years ago, on this day, my systematic Yoga study started & gradually became the very essence of my life

I remember waking up at dawn & walking hand in hand with my elder sister to attend this month long Yoga training. For a 8 year old boy it was exciting & intriguing to explore movements of the body, plays of the mind & relish the inner calm. It was my first Yoga Course, & my sister and I were the only kids amongst all adult participants, yet we never felt out of place in the group. 
.
Yoga scene in India back then was completely different. Yoga training at the school where I studied was inclusive, holistic & taught with a goal of holistic wellbeing & self-knowledge. This ethos still reflects in my teachings
.
I could say that it truly was a Yoga training & not an Asana training
.
In retrospect, I have tried to recall how my training looked back then & made a list of some points that may interest you. Here they are,
.
• Asanas were taught as a self-experience & not as an exercise
• The teachers showed us what to do & let us discover the Asana ourselves under strict supervision.
• The instructions were minimal
• There was no pulling, tugging or pushing by the teacher 
• The general ambience in the teaching hall was cheerful, encouraging & very supporrive of each other. As an anxious kid I felt safe in the course
• There was never a class without start & end chant, Pranayama, Shavasana & Dhyana 
• The Teacher ended the class with a spiritual talk or quote from Yogic scriptures with a brief explanation
• We were encouraged to practice at home & were given handouts
• We were all respectful towards the teachers, beyond age & gender, not out of force but out of a regard for their knowledge & experience
.
Through ups and downs of my life Yoga has always been with me. I am growing with Yoga & Yoga keeps growing on me. Here's to many more years with Yoga 🙏🏾
.
I want to thank my Mom for having the sense to know where to direct her children's energy at that age. 
Thank you Aai ❤

Sharing a slice of my life, especially for the new Yoga Teachers here

So, 20 years ago, in May 2003, I was invited to speak at an International Fitness Convention in Germany. I was to deliver 3 lectures & demos

I was double nervous because it was my first International Workshop & I was the only presenter from Asia.There was a lot at stake. I was used to teaching groups but teaching at this level was nerve wracking

My first presentation was on Aquatic Methods of Relaxation

After delivering my presentation, which I thought went well, I waited upon the participants to come & talk to me as any presenter would

The participants slowly started coming out of the pool & walking towards me. The first person who came up to me smirked & said, “who made you a speaker?”, the next one said, “I wasted my money”, the third lady said, “boy, you have lots to learn”, the fourth one was visibly unhappy & said, “you do not get a good feedback review from me”, the one next stomped out saying, “you are not coming to the conference next year for sure”

Soon, I saw the rest walking away without even acknowledging me. My mind went numb, I impulsively started to laugh out of confusion & shock. I couldn’t make sense of anything that was going on

I quickly picked up my bag & ran out of the premises towards a green patch some distance away, trying to figure what the heck had just happened

My mind was blank, in shock. My eyes were foggy, my heart was racing & my spirits defeated

I sat under a tree to let the feeling fade away, trying to process it all & calm down. Those few minutes on that green patch of grass were some of the most precious moments that have contributed to my self-clarity, something that I still carry in my heart
 
Friends, we all have our journeys
Don’t give up on yourself
We don't fail, we only learn
Let your clarity show you the way 🙏🏾

This is one of my favourite pictures taken by my student @yunyogaportrait during a workshop on Bhakti Yoga, 5 years ago in HongKong

Look how the projection of letters has fallen on my body. Coincidently, that time I was mentioning how the Tantra mentions that the human body holds 52 sounds from the Sanskrit alphabet 

In Indian culture, the ‘Word’ (Shabda), along with sounds, language & grammar has always played an important part, both in the Vedic & the Tantric traditions

In fact, many may not know that Patanjali has written extensively on language, grammar, sense & meaning. Tantric Philosophers like Bhartrahari have even developed spiritual philosophies revolving around language, called Shabda advaita – linguistic non-dualism

Each letter is considered a Goddess. There is a group of Goddesses called the seven Mother Goddesses (Saptamātrikā) that correspond to the seven consonant groups in Sanskrit language

In Tantra, the seven Mātrikās (Goddesses) are said to be the guardians of the embodied self. All 52 Goddesses (more or less) are seated within the human body. When we chant a Bija or a Mantra, we are not only creating sound through our mouth but also manifesting a vibrational super-structure Matrix & waking up the Goddesses. Invoking Goddesses has a direct implication on our cognitive reality & perception

This is how sound, in the form of letters, is seen as a medium of communication, expression & interaction of ideas, emotions & beliefs

Deep within the belly of every letter, ( Mātrikā, Vibrational Goddess) there is a potent meaning & sense waiting to be deciphered. This sense is called ‘Bhāva’

Hinduism considers that the world is divided into manifest & the unmanifest, thought of as sound & silence

Silence always underlines everything that is spoken, & this is why the highest speech is considered to be that which brings sound back to silence

Retracting speech into silence & making the mind still is essence of Mantra Yoga

The scriptures state that when the mind’s noise is quietened, the sound of silence is heard. This sound of silence is the primal Nāda, the Om, from which the word & world emerges & in which it dissolves

Few weeks ago, I was told my posts are ‘edgy’, but in a good way, because they invite deeper reflection

The tone of my writing is thanks to my spiritual teachers. Fortunately, none of them let me get away with an unexamined idea. They would cut my ideas short with the sharpest counter-argument based on logic & scriptural testimony. It was not easy being their student, & I say it with gratitude 🙏🏾

Once, I worked on an inquiry for over a year & went to my teacher thinking he would be impressed. But it took him just one sentence to demolish my entire thought process, just one line to destroy my year-long reflection 😃 This is how they kept breaking my ill-informed, un-analyzed ideas, only to keep refining my mind

This is something that I feel modern Yogic pedagogy is missing, i.e. training in critical inquiry. There is an entire science of reasoning in Indic tradition called Tarka Shāstra, just like there is the science of Yoga, Yoga Shāstra

Tarka is the process of inquiring & reasoning ideas to arrive at a conclusion.It’s an important tool & study subject in all traditions i.e Hindu, Buddhist & Jain

Tarka is essential to Yoga, because it helps filter through baseless ideas & fanciful beliefs that are neither rooted in experience nor in scriptural testimony

Though it’s a complex subject, I think modern practitioners would benefit from some of its basic tenets to help clear confusion, esp. these days when anything passes off as Yoga

Over past 100 years, as Yoga became more about health & wellbeing, the focus of study shifted from learning systematic inquiry & reasoning to doing physical practices

Also, for some reason, logic & analysis is perceived as an enemy of spirituality, in turn emphasizing matters of the ‘Heart’.But, in Yogic tradition, critical thinking is essential to sharpen the faith. Faith & Reason are NOT enemies in Yoga. Logic & reflection purifies mind & unblocks the ‘Spiritual Heart’.Only a mind thus purified anchors deeply in faith & surrenders without doubt

The reason why I've paused my Teacher Trainings since 4 years is that I am reworking the curriculum & plan to include basics of Yogic critical inquiry in it
Let's see how it shapes up

Abhyāsa & Vairāgya are two most important aspects of Yoga. They are like the two wings of a Yoga practitioner

Abhyāsa, as practice, is recognized as important in popular Yoga, because Yoga itself is seen as practice

But, Vairāgya, as detachment, is either ignored or dumbed down because it is considered scary or impossible

One more reason why Vairāgya has not gained traction in modern spirituality is economics. Abhyāsa, as practice, fills up the revenue streams. We buy stuff to practice Yoga. But Vairāgya, as detachment, is counter productive to spiritual consumerism

Vairāgya comes across as scary because its usualy perceived as giving up everything & going away to the Himalayas, far from friends & family. Seekers are afraid of losing the charm of life. But such romanticized notions are erroneous

Vairāgya, as non-attachment, doesn’t mean “giving up” of everything, rather, it is about giving up of specific things that are not any more conducive for self-growth (Ātmajnāna)

Vairāgya in Yoga is neither random nor impulsive. What exactly to give up is known through self-clarity. Such clarity is called Viveka. Thus, Viveka preceeds Vairagya, & are complimentary practices

Non-attachment is like lifting off one foot from the lower step to climb the higher step.Unless one is ready to detach from the lower step how will one advance to the next?

If you find it difficult to detach from something, make sure to examine the intensity of your attachment to it. Unless we detach from the old & unproductive, we won’t be able to embrace the new & the positive

Also, Vairāgya is not a one-time activity. It is a lifelong process of lightning up. The entire ashtānga yoga is based in Vairāgya. There can be no Yoga without it

Be clear about your priorities, realise what doesnt serve you anymore, know what to let go of, be trusting enough to detach from it, & be adventurous enough to embrace the new

Detachment is challenging, but surely well worth the realization it brings

And, if you are still afraid of Vairāgya, know that what you can drop is NOT really you & the true You can never be dropped

Let go of the old & make space for the new, your True Self awaits YOU
