NOT surprised by these findings at all. My upcoming Europe tour has factored in the variable of exhaustion already.

This article from The Guardian states,
"A survey has found that tiredness is why 35% of people don’t make the changes to their diet and physical activity levels that would help them close the gap between good intentions and concrete action."

Over the last 4 years or so, it has become very clear to me that, professionally, I am dealing with a society of physically tired & mentally exhausted individuals that prefer Yoga as a quick fix, feel-good modality & not as a lifelong pursuit of self-transformation.This is because long-term pursuits feel overwhelming. People prefer excitational highs over consistent increments.

Yes, Yoga makes us feel good and at times quick fixes do help, but that doesn't have to make us reduce the holsitic lifelong pursuit of Yoga to an instant gratifying commodity. Yes, it is important to meet the students where they are at and give them what they need, but this needs to be done without compromising the grand narrative in which Yoga is rooted.

Yoga teachers will agree that this is indeed a tough terrain to navigate, a professional challenge I've accepted to take head on. 

What gives me confidence is the knowledge that the discomfort between Shreya (holstic growth) versus Preya (instant gratification) has been discussed even by the Upanishads. So, it is not a new problem as such.

It is this very exhaustion and overwhelm that doesnt let us stick to our Sādhana. Even Patanjali talks about it in his discussion of the Antarāya.

So, Yoga teachers, care givers, coaches, educators, parents, please read the article. It is an eye opener. This is the ecosystem of the new 'normal' that we have to operate in as Yoga Teachers.

So, if you are exhausted, first help yourself. 
If you have found a balance, help others help themselves.

Let me know in comments 👇🏼
• How do you manage your own exhaustion & motivate your exhausted students to commit to long term practice ?

As modern Yoga discourse borrows from different religio-cultural narratives, & as gas-lighting & cancel culture becomes commonplace in social media, many Yoga teachers & seekers have come to feel that there is something essentially wrong with them

The worst part is, in my conversations & counselings with numerous practitioners I've found that many have been told/taught that according to Yoga we are ‘ignorant’, & that our vulnerabilities are imperfections, because of which we need to transform ourselves using Yoga

My heart breaks for those who have bought into this flawed narrative of Yoga that makes them feel as if they are fundamentally flawed 

Is there any truth to such narrative in Yogic tradition that devalues personal agency?

Last month I taught the most essential Sankhya scripture, called Sankhya Karika. One of the main point in it states, ‘The Purusha is never really bound’, i.e. the misidentification of Consciousness with matter is NOT absolute but apparent. In simple terms, the individual (Purusha) was, is, & will always be Purse Consciousness (Chetan) despite what the mind makes it believe

The Bhagavad Gita too states that ‘God’, as Universal Consciousness (Parabrahma), is seated in the hearts of all beings. No matter how deeply limited an individual is, due to circumstances or capabilities, all will merge into the Universal Consciousness eventually because the essential nature of Individual & Universal is the SAME. Advaita Vedanta tells us, Atman = Brahman. The Upanishads too boldly proclaim, ‘YOU are the child of immortality’ (Shvetashvatara Upanishad). Hundreds of such examples from the Yogic texts ask us to be hopeful, be trusting, & do our self-work (Sadhana) to keep growing in our understanding of our Self

Human (or any sentient being for that matter) is neither fundamentally flawed nor existentially faulty. Yogic wisdom of Upanishad says, "This Self (Atman) is Infinite (Brahman)" (Mandukya Upanishad)

Dear Friends, do not feel less about yourself. Yoga does NOT say you are flawed. Yoga does NOT claim your vulnerabilities are imperfections. Yoga says, you are THAT, the very Universal Consciousness (Chandogya Upanishad)

Years ago, during my study at a Hatha Yoga monastery in Nepal mountains, I met a traveling Sadhu who was also a priest. He did his Arati (prayers) for 30 mins in a peculiar way. He would raise his heels, squat slowly till his hip touched the heels & rise up fast. He did hundreds of repetitions while chanting his prayers holding a heavy 5 kilo ghee lamp. He told me that in his monastery, which was located in Dang district in interiors of Nepal, they prayed in Utkatiasana as a form of Tapas (bodily challenge) to reduce identification with the physical body

In pre-modern Hatha tradition, such dynamic squats are called Utkatasana / Utkatiasana.These days its often called chair pose - which is fine as an anology, but I feel it dilutes its deeper sense & makes it purely physical

In Sanskrit, prefix ‘Ut’ or ‘Ud’ means upward, & ‘Kata’ means to go, or a mat. Thus, Utkatasana literally means ‘going upward’ or ‘moving up, off the mat’

Though scriptural instructions differ, practitioners are often asked to raise heels during eccentric phase

One benefit of Utkatasana in oral Hatha tradition is that it helps in ‘reversing the flow’ of Apana Vayu. The pre-modern Hatha Yogis take their ‘reverse’ & ‘inverted’ practices very seriously

It is said that reversal of Apana Vayu (i.e Prana flowing downward) helps in pushing Kundalini upward, into the Sushumna

Though everything doesnt have to be complimentary between Hatha anatomy & bio-medical anatomy, I see a parallel in the ‘reversal of downward flow' or the 'going upward’ narrative

Anatomically, heel raised squats strengthen the Calf muscles, esp. anterior, lateral, & deep posterior compartment, thus helping pump venous blood up toward the heart more efficiently (thus 'reverse flow').
This is why Calf muscles are called 2nd Heart. The verticle flow has 2 components, centripetal flow during contraction & centrifugal flow during relaxation of Calf that creates pressure changes

Issues of foot, ankle, calf, knee, thigh, or network of veins in legs, may lead to impairment of calf muscle pump & reduce venous return

This is how, Utkatasana could work to ‘reversing downward flow' in both, traditional & bio-medical sense

Yesterday was World Meditation Day. Here are some common Meditation Myths. Note, here the term Meditation is understood as the process of Yogic Dhyāna

1) Meditation is about emptying the mind: 
No, in fact, Dhyāna is about first calming down the mind & then focusing the mind completely. Working with an idea of ‘emptying the mind’ can actually be overwhelming & discouraging, especially in early stages of practice when we realise how full our mind actually is

2) Meditation is only possible in lotus position:  No, the primary instruction for meditation posture in Yogic scriptures is that the head, neck & torso should be held straight (Gita) & steady position of comfortable ease (Yoga Sutra). One can choose to sit on chair, couch or floor. Avoid lying down as it may put you to sleep. Meditation is about the state of mind, when body is comfortable & mind is at ease

3) Meditate for an hour a day:  No, don't have to. It can begin with short sessions & the time can be gradually increased. One can start with sitting still for 15 mins, increasing a minute a week. Remember, the quality of meditation in terms of the state of mind it generates is more important than the time spent in sitting position

4) Meditation is about chanting in a language you don't understand: No, meditation can be done using varied ‘holding points’ (ālambana) that include breath, visualisation, images & even sensations. If you choose to meditate with a Mantra, see to it that you resonate with the Mantra, you know its meaning, the correct way of pronunciation, method of chanting, & follow the prescribed practices that are associated with chanting a Mantra

5) My mind is not quiet enough for meditation, so I don't do it: We find it tough to calm down the mind, but that’s exactly why one should start meditation journey. Dhyāna is long, gradual & layered process that starts with sensory-cognitive regulation & ends in Samādhi. Calming & steadying the mind takes long time & needs to be supplimented by lifestyle regulation, trust, discipline & detachment

So, don’t judge yourself, don’t compete, & don'r rush – just practice. Gradually, over years, mind will calm down & focus (ekāgra). 
Be patient 🙏🏽

In the pre-modern Hatha path of Yoga, Asana are practiced mainly to generate Stability (Dhridata - दृढ़ता).

Stability is considered an important aspects of a Yogin that wants to grow on the path of Meditation (Dhyana)

Physical Stability translates into mental resoluteness, because body and mind are two sides of the same coin.Resoluteness is what the term Hatha (हठ) means.

Earth element is directly related to Apana Vayu – the impulse of ejection. Apana Vayu is cognitively related to detachment. Detachment is called Vairagya, and it is one of the two wings on which the bird of Jeeva (bound Being) flies out of the tangle of delusion (Avidya).

This is why in the path of Hatha, physical stability, especially of lower regions of the body i.e glutes and thighs, is given prime importance.

The essence of Hatha Vidya (knowledge of Hatha yoga) is summarized thus, 👇🏼

Your thoughts and actions, have the potential to weave and color the fabric of Cosmos - the infinitely vivid Cosmos, within and without.

This is the fundamental tenet of Hatha Yoga called the Micro-Macrocosm Principle (Pinda Brahmanda Siddhanta) which says whatever is within, is also without

Remember,

Practice of Yoga is non-linear.
Practice of Yoga is not uni-dimensional.
Its you moving through your layers to realize your Self.
The Method Matrix of Yoga pierces through the entire spectrum of human personality, breaking through the layers and ideas of self, to reveal the Being encased in Human form

“I was into Yoga, now I practice mindfulness”. I've heard such statements innumerable times

When Yoga is reduced to a purely physical project, mindfulness becomes something separate 

But, it doesnt have to be that way. Yoga & mindfulness are NOT different practices per se. Neither is mindfulness solely a ‘Buddhist’ practice, but that topic for some other time 

Yoga is practice & mindfulness is the way the practice is done. The basis of Yoga is in mindfulness. Without being mindful, there can be no Yoga 👈🏽

On the internet, Mindfulness is defined as the practice of being aware and/or focusing attention. In this sense, the entire practice of Yoga is based in mindfulness

Note, when I say Yoga I do not mean Asana only, but an entire process of self-transformation to realize the True-Self within

Here are just a few points on how traditional Yoga is & has always been a practice of mindfulness,

1) When Patanjali says, ‘Yoga is cessation of mental fluctuations’ – he is speaking to those practitioners who are mindful of their own mental fluctuations (chittavritti)

2) When Krishna asks us to do our actions without attachment (Gita 5:11) – he is intending it as a mindfulness practice

3) Krishna also asks us to be mindful of our sleep, activity, food habits and recreation (Gita 6:16), this too is a practice of mindful living

4) Pratyahara, as a process in Yoga, is all about turning the mind inward by being mindful of sensory input

5) When Uddalaka tells his son Shvetaketu in Chandogya Upanishad (6.8.7), Tat tvam asi, ‘You are That’, he is asking him to be mindful of his inner nature

6) When Svatmarama asks Hatha Yogis to practice Pranayama with ‘sattvik buddhi’ (2.6), he is indicating an undisturbed mindful state of awareness

What is important is to appreciate the fact that Yoga is an attempt to realize (become mindful of) our True-Nature (Atman) that we have forgotten due to mis-identification (Avidya).

In this sense, Yoga, from its core premise, is truly a mindfulness practice & not something seperate from it. There can be no Yoga without mindfulness

Share with friends & help bring clarity to this topic 🙏🏽

They said it and its true, on this path, you will lose the you and not find anything new. Are you ready to lose the you to know the True ?

It’s going to change your world, not by a few degrees but by a complete 180. No, neither 50% nor even 99% commitment will take you there, it needs 100 % and it knows how to take it.

There are no crutches there, no dependencies then, neither asked, nor required. Only trust lights the way through darkness - total, unflinched trust.

It’s neither a place, nor a state, neither an object nor a happening, neither a being, nor a scene – it’s where concepts exhaust themselves and ideas accept defeat. 

Once seen it can't be unseen and through that scene the unknown is known, the unknowable realizes itself.

Sant Kabir states that it’s a wonder where fish marries a tree. Sant Muktabai describes it as an ant that swallows the Sun. Jesus Christ says, it's where the last shall be first and first shall be last. Maulana Rumi declares it as an ocean within a drop. Mahayogi Goraksha Nath says it’s a city of nothingness, and the Upanishads say it's where there is neither knowing nor non-knowing.

Nothing seems normal then, for it never was, nothing seems certain there, for it never is, this is where things literally turn over their heads and one peacefully rests in the paradox.

It is then that you burst into a loud laughter and allow yourself to fall into the bottomless pit of existence, carefree, knowing that you are the fallen, the fall and the one that is All.

The emphasis on bodily perfection in popular Yogic culture is real. The pressure of wanting to be perfect, especially with regards to the shape of the body, precision of poses, mental states & Yogiclifestyle shows on many Yoga Teachers, especially the new ones. Chasing perfection is exhausting - I am sure we know this. So, here's  something about it,

Yoga is not about becoming perfect, because the Being (ātman) is already perfect according to the Yogic understanding. One can't become what one already is ...

The body, poses, behaviour, emotion, morality, are all transient, & whatever is transient cannot have lasting perfection according to the Yogic view.

Your asana will never be perfect always, your body will never have an ideal state, because the mind-body complex keeps changing as it responds to the process called life.

So, what to do then?

Focus on being sincere to the Process, instead of being rattled by ideas of Perfection.

A little child is not an imperfect adult, it is a child. A tiny sprout is not an imperfect tree, it is a sprout. You, as a Yoga practitioner, are not an imperfect Yogin, you are a Yogin in process.

Lets get this straight. The journey of Yoga that we are on is long, tedious & challenging. Why go through it with a stubborn Mulabandha? Chill, Relax!! Let out some steam 😄...

Live, laugh, learn, let go & move on. Neither take yourself, nor your identities seriously, but do take it sincerely....

I was leaving for my yearly Europe tour on 14th May 2012. I said goodbye to everyone at home &, as per tradition, touched my mother’s feet for her blessings. She was sitting next to the picture of her recently ailed husband. I hugged her, gave her a kiss. She said all the best, wished me luck. I rolled my bag, stepped out of the door waiting for the elavator to come up. Then, something deep inside my heart pulled me back in saying "go, hug her once again" – I rushed & sat at her feet holding her hand silently. This was unlike me, so she asked – is everything okay? Hearing me not say anything, she said, "don’t worry, I will be fine. All the best". Hugging her tightly, with a numb mind & a heavy heart, I stepped out straight for the airport

On 27th May 2012, I got a frantic call from my sister during my Yoga workshop in Holland. She said I had to fly back home as mom had slipped into Coma. Emotionally broken, I flew home with dramatic expectation that hearing my voice she would come out of Coma, but nothing like that happened. Two days later, she left her body. It will be 11 years tomorrow since her passing

The opportunity to see & hug her one last time before I left comforted me through my grief. I have nothing but gratitude for all that my mother & father gave my siblings & I. But, their passing also taught me the value of not holding on to grudges, resentment & regrets 

Our time here is short. We all will be subjected to discomfort, disease, decay & eventual death. This is the Truth of our embodied existence

So, do NOT hold grudges. Lighten the heaviness of your past & refrain from gnawing at your wounds. Settle your disputes, forgive, make closures & gradually wipe your mental slates clean. Only then will your heart fill with Love, Love that is free of conditions, Love that is empowering. It takes courage to do this, but this is exactly what Yoga practice is all about

The successive death of my father & mother within a short span of 3 months has been the most spiritual experience of my life. It left a big hole in my life, but also made me confront the reality of Death & reflect on the nature of Life. In their loss, I found mySelf

Thank You Aai & Baba

From drastically changing our spending pattern to overthrowing governments, Social Media has deeply entrenched our lives & mind. I often reflect on how Social Media has changed the perception of Yoga. Mentioning here a few points. I am not against Social Media but discerning Yoga practitioners should surely reflect 👇🏼

1) Traditional Yogic knowledge is based in definite principles & practices. Core message of Gita/Sutra has not changed for hundreds of years.The scriptures teach clearly & in context. But, Social Media is a subjective platform. A Yoga Influencer who experiences things in a particular way may end up summarizing personal (subjective) experience as the Truth of Yoga, stating "For me Yoga is XYZ, therefore Yoga is XYZ". This perpetuates subjectivism, especially if there is no teacher to mediate or ability to discern

2) Instead of reflecting on “What is it that I need from Yoga”, we end up asking “What are others doing that I should too”. Constant comparison on Social Media could create FOMO & force us to comply with trends. Algorithm too encourages Herd Mentality.
Eg: Forcing oneself to do a Yoga Challenge to stay relevant, or be seen

3) This is the reason why, every time there is a new Socio-Political Issue, newer definitions of Yoga are born on Social Media
   
4) Popularity is perceived as experience & wisdom. A blue-tick neither automatically makes someone venerable, nor wise. A simpleton Yogi may not realize this & fall into a Bandwagon trap

5) As a Visual Medium, Social Media keeps us engaged in the sensory world. But Yoga is about moving away, or at least regulating senses

6) We are made to alter our perception & behavior based on Algorithms. Insta moved from Image to Video format making movement modality videos garner more views v/s still pics, reinforcing a belief that movement modality is Yoga

7) Algorithm has power to selectively promote specific ideas & censor others, creating lopsided view of Yoga. Unaware users unconsciously buy into it. Through images & videos we are told how to think & what to do, thus erasing our ability to think critically. Critical thinking is Buddhi, the most important faculty for a Yogin

Found a beautiful old picture of my dear teacher & thought of writing about Fear & Time - a topic not much discussed in popular Yoga

During my study with him in a Nātha Monastery in Nepal we would talk a lot about dates & years in history of Yogic traditions

Now, in Nepal they use Vikram Samvat calendar by which we are in the year 2080. But, in India, we use Shaka Samvat system by which we are in 1945. So, whenever he used to talk history I had to keep 3 different calendars in mind. There was no single time frame for me to refer

I also remember, back in 2006, I was about to miss a flight in Europe because I did not account for Daylight time-saving. I had no idea people tampered with time like this because we do not have that system in India

Friends, all our fears are linked to death, & death is linked to time. But Time is psychologically real, not absolutely real. If time is a psychological phenomenon, why do we get so bound by it? That’s because of our attachments 

Einstein states in Special Theory of Relativity that time is relative. Even Yoga regards time to be relative. Yet we keep fighting time in our head. How tightly are we bound to temporal constructs like getting a job by this age, marrying & having kids by this age, biological clock, not aging & so on

Time & Death is an important topic in traditional Yoga. Upanishads mention death & its nature repeatedly. So close is the relation that in Yoga, Time & Death are indicated by the same word, Kaal. Both are psychological (mental) realities & not absolute realities. Therefore, when a Yogin moves beyond mind, the Yogin also moves beyond time

Many of us are exhausted chasing time & ruled by the fear it brings. That’s because we see time as something absolute & not as a passing mental phenomenon. This is where Yoga comes in. Yoga helps us manage our mind, & hence regulate the time

This is also why advanced Hatha Yoga practices are done in Cemeteries. Here I remember a profound quote from one of my favorite western philosophers, Martin Heidegger. In a lecture in 1961, Heidegger was asked what should we do to live better lives, to which he said: “we should simply aim to spend more time in graveyards”

.
👉🏽 What really is Bhakti Yoga?
👉🏽 Is it only about praying to some deity, chanting mantras & singing kirtan songs?

Here's a summary,

Human existence is driven by 2 main impulses, existential anxiety (fear) & 
the need to belong to something greater (faith)

In my teachings I repeatedly clarify that Yogic life is nothing but a journey from fear to faith

Faith is a journey & not a one-time happening. Faith gradually matures till it becomes total – choiceless. All ancient traditions indicate this through stories of sacrifice. In choiceless faith everything happens on its own accord, with a profound sense of calm & effortlessness - this is Ishwarapranidhāna

The journey of faith is not easy. Faith is tested, again & again, & that is what makes faith grow. The evolution of faith is Bhakti Yoga

Bhakti is not all prayer & chanting, it’s about navigating life’s challenges with firm faith in something greater than the limited self (ego)

Living in faith is essential to humanness, & trying to live in faith is Bhakti Yoga.

Faith is not all about religion. Atheists may not have faith in 'God' but have faith in the power of science. No matter who or what one has faith in, it is essential for human thriving. If you dont like the word 'faith', use trust

Yoga practitioners can grow their faith in three things, the teacher-teaching, 'God', & self.

Whatever is easily accessible, one can start with that

This faith is not blind faith. The path of faith itself tests the practitioner's faculty of reason, compassion, & presence of mind. Faith (shraddhā) in Bhakti Yoga is not at the cost of suspending critical thinking. The journey of faith is like any relationship – it takes time to mature & has its own ups & downs. So, be patient. Whatever or whoever you choose to have faith in, give that faith time to mature. How you win your daily battles determines the maturity of your faith

Personally, I see my entire life as a journey of faith & nothing else.This is my process, my practice, my path & my teaching

Allow your faith to raise you from your fear.

Belgium & The Netherlands, a big thank you. The first leg of my Europe tour is done, and it was disruptive of sorts in many ways. It was so, so, so nice to meet so many familiar faces again, as if the last 4 years didnt exist. And ofcourse it was great to meet new seekers 

Over last 10 years I've consistantly expressed the importance of simplifying Yogic teachings & focusing more on the process than the pose, more on the trust & not just the techniques. Through this tour I am trying to reinforce the above even more emphatically. The strain of life & stress of survival has become heavier now, people are physically more exhausted & mentally more spent. In such a case, where life itself has become complex, the spiritual teachings dont need to be complicated

I conducted 5 gatherings in the last 7 days & met hundreds of people, from 17 year olds to 70 year olds, from cancer patients, lawyers, home makers, medical doctors and to Yoga teachers, all agreed that in times like these we need simplified Yogic teachings that stick to the core tenets of Yoga. Yoga that is not diluted but accessible to one and all

Funnily enough, one would not even call these workshops "Yoga workshop" in the conventional sense, yet they were closest to the core tenets of Yogic tradition

We met, we sang, we talked, we discussed, we cried, we shared, we empathized with each others challenges, we laughed, we respired together, we hugged & somewhere deep within we tapped into the essence of our Being - a Being that is Simple in its very existence, a Being that is Calm beyond the chaos of the mind

In popular Yogic spirituality it is often assumed that the goal of Yoga is ‘Oneness’. But, that may not be the case, especially in the most commonly cited Yogic philosophy, i.e Patanjali’s Ashtanga Yoga

Philosophically, the Yogic process mentioned in the Yoga Sutra does not culminate in Oneness. In fact, it would go against Patanjali’s core tenets to say that the goal of his Yoga system is Oneness.

Patanjali’s Ashtanga Yoga culminates in Only-ness and not One-ness. It is called Kaivalya, a term that is derived from the word Kevala, which means Only (or, by itself).

Patanjali’s Yoga is mainly based in Sankhya philosophy, which is fundamentally Dualistic. Dualism is a philosophical orientation where everything is finally reduced to two independent and fundamentally different principles. For Patanjali, the two principles are Purusha & Prakriti i.e consciousness and matter. 

Dualistic philosophies are different to ‘One-ness’ propagating Monistic philosophies like Advaita Vedanta, where everything is reduced to a single reality.

The philosophical duel between Dualism and Monism has been going on in the history of global thought for thousands of years, may it be Parmenides vs Heraclitus of ancient Greece, Spinoza vs Descartes of medieval Europe, or Sankhya-Yoga vs Advaita Vedanta of Indic thought.

Superfically, such differentiations may not account to much but, as sincere Yoga students & teachers, it becomes important to have a basic idea of the key philosophical differences between the many Indic spiritual philosophies so as to avoid projecting one's own ideas on the author's original intention

True renunciation that Yoga talks about is not in giving up the world, but in giving up the idea that the world is the answer to our questions.
.
Don't run away, 
don't hide, 
dont ignore, 
don't avoid.
.
Live in the world, do what you have to, and Face challenges with Trust and Patience. Do not get distracted, there is nothing to Yogic life beyond this. Be sincere with your Sādhanā and allow life itself to lighten your mind.
.
A time comes when answers are not sought any more, because the questions themselves disappear. And when that happens, one lives as is.
.
Sending hugs to all fellow Yoga practitioners who are struggling to find answers to life's questions.

We do Asanas categorized as ‘Heart Openers’. They help us breathe more, feel good, & 'opened up'. The term “Heart Opener” has a fairly wide scope that includes aspects like openness, compassion, empathy, love, & togetherness. It is popular to say that back-bends “open the heart” or they are 'Heart Openers'. But, how do Yoga scriptures indicate this process of Heart Opening?

Traditionally, ‘Heart Opener’, as a metaphorical term, stems from the idea that there is something closed in the Heart area (hridayākasha)  that needs to be opened. That ‘closed’ part is known as ‘Granthi’ or a knot.

The Mandukya Upanishad  2-2-8 talks about this knot & says,

bhidyate hridaya granthih chhidyante sarva sanshayah, kshiyante chasya karmaNi tasmin drishte paravare

Which means, "pierced is the knot of the heart, slashed are all the doubts. Annihilated are the chains of Karma, when the Truth is realised".

This knot is the knot of ignorance of our Self. It’s the knot of attachment to the idea we have created about our self, a perception on which we base our existence. An idea of self  that bases itself on shaky beliefs and feeds on temporary satisfactions keeps sapping our energy and holds us in anxiety.

As the above line says, it’s the knot of self-doubt. This doubt is no ordinary doubt, it’s the doubt emerging from fundamental ignorance of Being. The doubt emerging from not knowing the Self. It’s the knot that binds us to the cycle of suffering for lifetimes.

Breaking free from this knot begins only when one becomes ruthlessly honest about one’s spiritual journey, is ready to detach from all that doesn’t serve the journey of self-discovery, & becomes strongly dedicated to Sadhana. This needs a lot of Trust. Unless the Yogic seeker is ready for this ‘leap of faith’, no amount of back-bends will help open the Heart.

This Cheetah needs Vritti Nirodhah 😁
Does your Chitta too ?

If doubting or Impostering Vrittis are infecting your Chitta, then reflect on these points

Vairāgya: Step back from your fear and worry, and don't allow it to cloud your sense of purpose. Perform your work with clarity and let time help bring in more confidence. Don’t be attached to the fruits of your actions or the opinions of others. As Bhagavad Gita says: “You have control over doing your respective function, but no control or claim over the results of that function. The fruits of work should not be your motive, and neither should you be inactive.”

Sangha: Doubting oneself is a common obstacle and many people face it. You can try to overcome it by joining a community of other yoga teachers who support you, celebrate you and guide you. As the Upanishads say, ‘Sahanau Bhunaktu, Saha Veeryam Karavavahai’, May we work together with great zest…’ But remember, a sense of belonging to a Sangha could help reduce self-doubt only if you avoid comparing yourself with members of the Sangha. 

Shraddhā: Don’t neglect or diminish your talents and achievements, but acknowledge them with gratitude. Your innate talents & capabilities are gifts given to you by the divine to share with others. Have faith in the divine will and confidence in your own skills to bring goodness in the world. If someone compliments you, accept it with grace and joy. In the words of Bhagavad Gita, your core abilities are your Svabhāva, your personal nature. Work with it. Owning your Svabhāva with humility won’t make you egoistic, denying it will.

Marinate – was one of the first English words that my mind retained as a kid. Though we didn’t speak English at home, this word stuck with me for some reason. As a kid, I used to love hanging out with my mom in the kitchen, especially when she would marinate fish & veggies. When asked, she would say in English that she was ‘marinating’ instead of using a word from my mother tongue, Marathi

I was fascinated by the entire process of marination, how things felt & looked different after the period of transformation. It was like magic for the kid in me

As I grew up & started teaching Yoga, I saw myself using the same word to explain the process of Yogic learning

Yogic education is not as immediate as learning Math, 2+2=4, & that’s it. Rather, it is literally a process of marination, where the student marinates over years in knowledge through study, practice, & living

I think as Yoga Teachers it's important to realize this, especially in recent times when Yoga is seen as instant gratification & being a Yoga Teacher is a numbers (hours) game

Dear Yoga Teachers, Yoga teaching is NOT about passing on knowledge that you have learned, but transferring wisdom from what you have experienced. Our modern competitive Yoga teaching scene compels us to want to teach as soon as we learn something new, out of FOMO or out of a need for validation that Social Media ignites. There’s a certain hurry to establish oneself as an 'advanced teacher’. Be mindful of this impulse, of your impatience

Give your learning the time to resonate within. Allow your study to marinate in every cell of your body. Live what you have studied, experience what you have heard, & realize what you have been taught. Give yourself time to flower

This is what will make you a teacher who speaks out of genuine personal experience (anubhava) & not merely out of words printed in books or swiped on devices

The great contemporary Yogi, Neem Karoli Baba used to say, “Saints did Japa & Sadhana for 10,000 years..., only then they could succeed in Japa, Meditation and Yoga. But people want to be expert within 5-7 months only”

Are you patient enough to ‘Pickle’ yourself in Yoga? Something for us all to reflect upon

Few years ago, at the end of Day 1 of my workshop, someone asked for my Insta handle. The next day she said, “I saw your Instagram handle. Your Yoga seems more like a life-coaching thing than Yoga. I didn’t see any pictures of you in poses”. Saying this, she walked away

I have to give it to her. Yes, the Yoga I teach does come across as life-coaching, thats because Yoga, in its traditional sense, is a life-skill, & teaching Yoga is life-skill coaching 

Krishna was Arjuna’s ‘life-coach’ who showed him a way out of personal delusion. The Upanishadic Gurus were life-coaches to young Brahmacharis who came to the ashram at age 8 to stay for 12 years. Buddha was the ‘life-coach’ of King Bimbisara, & so was Ramakrishna the coach-mentor of Swami Vivekananda – all this because Yoga is a science of self, & the self never operates in isolation from life

The modalities of Yoga, from asana to dhyana & the philosophies of Yoga, from Vedanta to Tantra, are directed towards refining the mind to help an individual navigate life

Krishna in Gita, Buddha in his ashtanga path, Swatmarama in Hatha Pradpika, & the Upanishadic Rishis talk about diet, habit patterns, & lifestyle – because, Yoga is all about living efficiently & purposefully. And, since no one is an island, the ethical injunctions of Yama-Niyama are directed towards upliftment of the Society (lokasangraha) & not merely an individual

Thus, Yoga has always been about the self & life. And Yoga is a life-skill

I am very clear about the kind of Yoga I want to teach, & actually teach. Even in my current Europe tour I am emphasizing the holsitic nature of Yoga, as a life-skill, beyond poses. This clarity has come with its own fair share of damages, like walkouts, cancellations, hate-mails, being labelled inauthentic, & most definitely, financial compromise over the years. But, at the end of the day, I am happy to help a few navigate the rough terrains of life with a lighter mind through holistic teachings of Yoga. In that sense - Yes, my Yoga is surely life (skill) coaching

The 3rd leg of my Europe trip is over. Austria & Germany, it was great to be with you again.

The main focus of all the 5 workshops was on,
• Breath practices & Mental Health 
• Simplifying life & calming the mind, &
• Creating happiness with Yoga

Thank You all for travelling from so far & participating so sincerely

As I meet hundreds of Yoga practitioners & fellow Yoga teachers on this tour, it once again becomes evident how closely our lives, joys & sufferings are interrelated. It reminds me of the Yogic concept of Yajna that Yoga practitioners should know 

Yogins have always believed in fundamental interconnectedness between everything, understood as Yajna. Bhagavad Gita asks us to be conscious of this interconnectedness so that every action not only contributes to self-growth but also to the greater good of all. Like a watch made of hundreds of small parts, each part being an important aspect of the bigger whole, we too need to work out of a realization of our importance in the smooth functioning of the world

The term ‘Yajna’ literally means an act of offering. It can be viewed at personal & social levels. Most times Yajna is translated as ‘sacrifice’ - but it is anything but that

Yajna has been mentioned in the oldest Veda, Rig Veda. Hindus perform Yajna by offering items like ghee, milk, grains, into holy fire, which is symbolic of the host’s contribution to grand interconnectedness of everything. Its an act by which the host surrenders to Gods, only to serve the larger salvation of humanity, shreyārtha (Ref: Apastamba Yajna Paribhasa-sutra 1.1)

The host’s input keeps the wheel of interconnectedness turning. When everyone sincerely contributes, the system becomes beneficial to all without any resource wastage. This model is nowadays called ‘Circular Economics’ in modern macroeconomic theory. If everyone were to behave as they please, without responsibility, wasting resources, without a care for social harmony, our society would be chaotic

Working with this harmony in mind is called Karma Yoga. Please know, Karma Yoga is neither free labor, nor charity, as is popularly understood these days. Gita asks us to be aware of the inherent interconnectedness of all & contribute towards universal balance. This is the fundamental moral virtue that a Yogin lives by. This is also why Krishna asks Arjuna to do his appointed duty of fighting & defending his kingdom instead of running away to become a  monk

The process of Yoga is itself a Yajna

That inner hollow, 
the sense of emptiness,
the feeling of incompleteness.
How do you choose to fill it ?
With transient objects that melt away,
with brief relationships that slip away,
with fleeting experiences that disappear,
or fading excitements that lose their cheer ?
Or,
by changing completely, 
bit by bit, gently,
treating yourself nicely,
gazing inwardly, 
living mindfully, 
loving unconditionally,
thinking calmly, 
working faithfully, 
brutally, 
honestly ?
How do you want to meet yourself, ultimately ?

To understand the deeper reason why Beeja Mantras were contemplated upon (not necessarily chanted) by Yogis, we have to appreciate how Indic knowledge systems converge Language & Creation into spiritual philosophy

According to Sanskrit grammarians, the word (Shabda) is nothing but a string of letters & letters are sound vibrations. These sound vibrations have always existed & always will - that's why letters are called Akshara, the indestructible

In its indestructibility, every letter (as sound vibration) is Absolute. This is why, letters are equated to the Absolute (Brahman) & are called Shabda Brahma – the Absolute Sound

Om is the single syllable/word through which Absolute is denoted as sound. Vibrations will always be around, even if we are not. As Brahadaranyaka Upanishad says, ‘Vak Vai Brahma’ - speech is verily Brahman

Indic philosophies have contemplated on the link between word & world over last 2000 years, unlike modern Western philosophers who focused their attention on language just 100 odd years ago – famously called the ‘Linguistic Turn of Philosophy’. Many western philosophers like Russel thought language to be inadequate for expression due to its vague & ambiguous nature

So, since the word-sound creates the world, it also creates individual human. Humans are embodied sound, if you will. Tantras say that all letters of Sanskrit alphabet are plotted within human body, to form, what I call, a ‘Sound Matrix’. The Yogin manipulates this Sound Matrix through Beeja Dhyana (meditation), & Mantra Japa (mostly mental). This is why pronunciation is crucial in mantra chanting, as one small mispronunciation could change the word-sound

Each Beeja holds the energy of each element & functions as a vortex between cosmic & individual consciousness. In Tantras, letters are also worshipped as Goddesses 

A right Beeja Sadhana first brings ‘Individual Sound Matrix’ in harmony with ‘Universal Sound Matrix’ at each elemental level (5 Chakras) & this harmony is absorbed into the ‘Mind Matrix’- 6th Chakra. This itself is full Kundalini arousal

This is how, the Yogin uses word that created the world, for dissolution (Laya) of the ego-self – This is Laya Yoga

We practice Shavasana at the end of an asana class to allow the body to recover, or to relax.Though the system of using Shavasana as "final relaxation" to end the Yoga class is new, its benefits are well-recognized

These benefits have also been mentioned in Hatha Yogic scriptures like Hatha Pradipika & Gheranda Samhita. But, as with everything in Yoga, it is just one part of the story

Shavasana was used to relax the body & mind in pre-modern Yoga too, but the end goal was not only about resting the body after an asana practice 

Shavasana was also used as a Dharana, as a mindfulness practice 

Scriptures like the 17th century Hatha Tattva Kaumudi (7:11) asks practitioners to contemplate on Shiva with gaze fixed on the tip of the nose in Shavasana (nāsāgra ādhāya drṣam smaran Shivam...)

The great scholar philosopher & mystic Yogi,  R. D. Ranade (1886-1957) used to use Shavasana for the above benefits when he suffered due to ill-health for years & couldn't sit

The idea is to use Shavasana to relax the mind so deeply that it helps in deeper spiritual contemplations 

The term Shavasana means the posture of a corpse. In Gheranda Samhita, it is called Mritasana, posture of a dead body

Why was an asana thats supposed to connote rest & relaxation named after something triggering like death or corpse? 

Many other words could have been used to indicate “rest & relaxation”. Yet, they chose to use words like ‘Shava’ & ‘Mrita’ – Corpse or Dead, Why? 

This is because Shavasana was a part of a larger gamut of practices called Laya Yoga – the Yoga of dissolution of the ego-self. Laya Yoga is a mature stage of Hatha path where the corporeal body is consciously & cognitively “dissolved”

The reason for practicing Shavasana was to consciously reduce “Deha Bhāva” – the sense of “I am the body” or, identification with one's physicality. Complete removal of Dehabhāva was/is the foundation of Hatha & Laya Yoga

The locus of Premodern Hatha Yoga was not in the physical body, like it is in popular postural Yoga. The corporeal body was seen just as a means to an end, Moksha & not as a goal in itself

This crucial point needs to be borne in mind by contemporary Yoga practitioners

I’ve been working on simplifying Yogic spirituality for my students with an affirmation I created 12 years ago – Simplify to Simply Fly. Even today I believe that we live in times of spiritual excess, & that there is a need to simplify Yogic spirituality without diluting its essence

You see, the Yoga path has its own innate intelligence. When one works sincerely under a teacher’s guidance over time, the path organically flowers in such a way that one ends up with just one or two modalities that nourish sustained growth. This happens because the sadhana gradually simplifies the mind, & a simple mind doesn’t hanker for more

But, spiritual consumerism could distract us from this realization by creating a sense of spiritual "FOMO", pushing us to incessantly engage in multiple practices simultaneously, potentially leading to confusion, overwhelm, or a feeling of not being good enough. This is already a big issue with many Yoga teachers

Unless one deeply recognizes the natural spiritual drive towards simplification, one will be swallowed by spiritual consumerism that fosters a need for accumulation, where seekers crave for spiritual products, experiences, & teachings, adding complexity to their journey. The frenzy to mould one’s sadhana according to the latest spiritual trends or out of fear of being ‘left behind’, can distract one from the naturally unfolding simplicity of an inner-focused practice, as seekers become preoccupied with what everyone is doing, instead of asking what is it that they need

Patanjali talks about ‘Ekatattva Abhyasa’, practice of single principle (PYS 1:32). Maharishi Vyasa calls it generating ‘Ekagra Chitta', one pointed mind. The Bhakti Yogis call it ‘Eka Nishtha Bhakti’, singleness of faith. Yoga scriptures have indicated this natural unfoldment of simplicity too

Simplicity is the key to reaching deeper states of consciousness. Your ability to let go of unnecessary spiritual clutter & distraction enhances your Yoga

If you feel overwhelmed, I have a simple suggestion to start with. Sit quietly, step away from spiritual clutter, & ask yourself, how much is too much for me?

Remember, you don’t need everything, 
you need 'your' thing

As we age we tend to lose muscle mass faster. Muscle loss due to ageing is called Sarcopenia. Between the age of 40-60, a person on average gains about 1 pound of fat per year & loses 1/2 pound of muscle. By age 75, 50% of muscle mass is lost, Source: The Merck Manual of Geriatrics

Therefore, its our duty toward our body to work on retaining muscle mass. Retaining muscle mass has many benefits & is crucial as we age. Lean muscle helps in fighting diabetes & obesity, helps maintain structural integrity, improves immunity, keeps metabolism high & helps avoid risk of fall & fractures. Strength training helps retain muscle mass. Muscle corresponds to Prithvi Tattva (Earth element), & we all need it for body-mind stability, esp. Vāta dominant individuals

Study of 57 adults aged 65–94 showed that performing resistance exercises 3 times per week increased muscle strength over 12 weeks, (Tufts University study)

 Here are some tips to reclaim muscle tissue,

1) Be active, move every day for at least 60 mins
2) Strength train 3-4 times a week – focus on compound movements
3) Work on each body part twice a week for optimal muscle growth. Train using Progressive Overload Technique i.e gradually increase resistance 
4) Get atleast 7-8 hours of sleep for optimal recovery 
5) Stay hydrated & get-in those Macros, including proteins. Dehydration can reduce insulin sensitivity which impairs muscle growth (Judelson et. al 2008)
6) Practice Pranayama, esp. Deep Slow Breathing, & Meditate every day (Had to get that in 😉 )
7) Reduce stress. Mental stress can restrict optimal muscle growth
8 ) Stop starving your body & experimenting with fad diets. Sacrificing muscle mass with fad diet is literally self-destruction
9) Work with a trainer till you get a hang of how to train yourself, safely
10) Change your mindset about muscle & strength training. If you are a human & have muscle, you need strength training

I went in, greeted him & sat quietly by the temple door. Back in 2008, I was staying for a few days in Joshi Muth studying Vedanta. Joshi Muth is one of the most important monasteries in India - established by Adi Shankaracharya, the proponent of Advaita Vedanta philosophy, in 9th Century

As I sat quietly leaning against the wall, a sparrow flew in through the window, pecked at a few rice grains from the altar & flew away happily. When she left, a small mouse came in, ate a few grains & ran to the corner. When the mouse went away, the sparrow, who patiently waited for her turn, would fly in for her share. When the mouse would see her gone, he would run in and bite on a few grains. This went on for a while. A moment came when they both stopped their visits. I guess they were content with what they had received. The temple premise was quiet again, after a good 20 mins of loud squeaking & chirping

At that very moment, as if synchronized, the Swami sitting on the other end of the temple & I started laughing loudly. He looked at me, I looked at him. Raising his eyebrows in amazement he said, ‘Ishwar Kripa’, meaning, God’s blessing. I, in total bewilderment, said ‘Sama Drishti’, meaning, equal vision

After a pregnant pause, we both started giggling again like two small boys

Neither the Swami, nor I, felt the need to shoo the creatures away from the Sanctum

The creature visits & their partaking of grains was neither destroying the sanctity of the altar nor our silence. After all, they too had an equal right on God’s bounty, so who were we to disturb their routine?

This unspoken understanding between the Swami & I could be summarized as the basis of Vedanta philosophy - divine grace & equal vision

After that incident I humbly approached him. His name was Swami Ramananda Saraswati. He was one of the main Swamis staying at Joshi Muth monastery since a long time.

Over the next two days we had heartfull conversations on different views of Vedanta. We concluded that it was most important to see everything & everyone with an equal vision

One evening, I asked him for a picture, he obliged shyly

The next morning I left for Badrinath, Himalaya, to be with my teacher

The other day when I was teaching a group of 200-Hour Yoga Teacher Trainees, someone asked me

"What would be the expertise that a Yoga teacher needs to develop in context of teaching a class ?" 

Here is what my reply was,

I believe that the expertise in teaching a Yoga class lies in how the teachers seamlessly balance giving general instructions while supervising with specific attention

Effective Yoga teaching balances generic guidance with individualized, specific attention, ensuring every student feels seen and supported in their practice.

General instructions establish the rhythm and flow of the class, ensuring everyone is on the same page regarding the sequence and overall practice goals.

General instructions also promote inclusivity, making the practice accessible to students of various levels, backgrounds, and experiences, fostering a sense of belonging and unity within the class.

Specific attention ensures students with varying abilities and limitations receive personalized guidance, enhancing their practice tailored to their body's requirements.

Personalized supervision prevents injuries by correcting improper postures and aligning movements, ensuring students perform asanas correctly and safely.

What more would you add to this, apart from developing soft skills like empathy etc. ?

Most of us know the Yama-Niyama mentioned in the Yoga Sutra, which is great. But, did you know that most Yoga scriptures mention their own Yama-Niyama ?

One then wonders, why is it that Yama-Niyama becomes central to Yoga based spirituality?

Indian spiritual tradition is not devoid of ethical considerations. Yoga aims for self-realization, & the ethical-moral principles (Yama-Niyama) form the foundation of Yoga philosophy, guiding practitioners toward self-realization, mental well-being, selfless action, social harmony, healthy relationships, & cosmic-environmental consciousness. These ethical principles guide the seekers in fostering inner peace (Shanti), contentment (Santosha) & harmony (Samatva), which are essential for spiritual progress. By adhering to these principles, individuals create a conducive environment for their spiritual journey while positively impacting the world around them

Bhagavad Gita gives a list of 32 traits to work upon. In fact, some of them are similar to Patanjali’s Yama-Niyama, like ahinsa – non-injury, satya – truth, santosha – contentment, & other more accessible conducts like akrodha – absence of anger, shanti – peacefulness (peaceful nature), daya – compassion, mardava - gentleness, abhaya – fearlessness, & so on. Even Mahabharata talks about Yama-Niyama in context of personal & social behaviour

Hatha Pradipika too mentions 10 Yamas & 10 Niyamas, some of my favorite are, Kshama – forgiveness, Dhrti – fortitude, Aarjava – non-hypocrisy, sincerity, Mitahaara – measured diet, Mati – reflection & Japa – recitation of mantra

One point to note here is that, in the traditional sense of Yoga, there can be no Yoga without ethical-moral conduct (Yama-Niyama). The Yogic process starts with first sorting out one’s external & internal relationships, without which spiritual pursuit becomes a mere show, hypocracy, as Bhagavad Gita states

So, when in doubt, get back to the basics of Yama & Niyama

Why the mind doesn't become still in meditation?

That's because that mind is not steady in regular life.

A lot of emphasis is given to the practice of meditation, the abhyāsa.

What is ignored is detachment, vairagya.

Both, Patanjali and Shri Krishna say that mind can calm down and become one pointed only through practice and detachment, and not only through practice. 

Unless you detach from what doesn't serve you anymore, you will never be able to still a mind in meditation, no matter how many hours of sitting you log in.

The practice of meditation (abhyāsa) has to go along with the practice of detachment (vairagya). These two are complimentary processes, and this is what makes Meditation (dhyāna) a 24/7 practice, a living and not merely a doing.

10 October is World Mental Health day. This post is dedicated to the mental health of Yoga professionals (& others too). If we want to serve others, we need to take care of ourselves too. 

Ofcourse the list could be more, but for now these 3 points are good enough for those who want to sincerely work upon their mental health. Please share this post with your friends & those who may need it

3 things to avoid on Social Media as a Yoga practitioner for the sake of your Mental health

1) Do not compare yourself with others

Social media is about presentation. Everyone tries to present their best, & that's fine. But someone else's best may not necessarily be your best. Each one of us is unique, and as a Yoga practitioner, one must focus inward and discover that uniqueness and grow through it rather than trying to be like someone else. In fact, this is one of the most important lessons of Karma Yoga in the Bhagavad Gita

 
2) Do not blindly believe everything you see or read

Just because something is available on social media doesn't mean it is sacrosanct, especially when it comes to scriptural & scientific claims about Yoga. Surely, there is great content out there, but do not sacrifice your ability to think critically just because someone is popular or something is trending. Do your own research & draw your own conclusion

 
3) Do not allow trends to distract you from your focus

When you do not have clarity in what you stand for as a Yoga professional, anything & everything has the power to distract you. Every new style, topic, hashtag & trend will light up your FOMO & make you rush here and there to be that. As Patanjali says, ‘vritti sarupyam itaratra’. This is exactly how spiritual materialism works. Instead, use that energy in generating self-clarity

This Navaratra, let's discover the women Yogis of India & know how they
successfully voiced expressions of self-authorization, womanhood, disapproval of patriarchy & raised themselves to the highest possible spiritual level by sheer determination, hardwork & faith

These essays are from my talks called "Silent Saints - the women yogis of India" that I've been conducting across the world since 2015

So, here goes...

Day 1 - Lalla / Lalleshwari / Lal Dedh

She is the Yogini prophetess of Kashmir, whose date has been approximately fixed at the end of the fourteenth century. She was a mendicant ascetic, who wandered about preaching the yogic doctrines as the best means of ultimate absorption into the Supreme

She has been rightly described as 'a predecessor' of the Medieval Social Reformers of India like Rāmānand, Kabir, & others of the 15th & later centuries. She was the creator of a style of mystic poetry called vatsun or Vakhs, which in Sanskrit means "speech"

What I love about Lalla's teachings is that they are practical, yet deeply rooted in detachment (vairagya). She speaks mostly in parabels, which I love. Lalla, for me a mystical mystery to solve through my own unbecoming

The true saint, according to her, is ''the one who serves of all humankind through humility & loving kindness"

She did not believe in the efficacy of external observances, ritualism, or idol worship. She insisted on the performance of duty for duty's sake, loving surrender to the divine & reflection on one's current state

Here are some of her poems that I love, 

1) 
I, Lalla, entered
the gate of the mind’s garden and saw
Shiva united with Sakti.
I was immersed in the lake of undying bliss. 
Here, in this lifetime,
I’ve been unchained from the wheel
of birth and death.
What can the world do to me?  

2)
I have seen an educated man starve,
a leaf blown off  by bitter wind.
Once I saw a thoughtless fool
beat his cook.
Lalla has been waiting for the 
allure of the world to fall away.  

3) 
I might scatter the southern clouds,
drain the sea, or cure someone
hopelessly ill.
But to change the mind
of a fool
is beyond me.

Navaratra Day 2 - Woman Yogis of India number 2

Andal, from 8 CE, is one of the 12 Alvars, saint devotees of Lord Vishnu. Andal means ‘she who rules’

She is best known for her passionate love & devotion to Lord Krishna, which she expresses through poetry. Her most famous work is the lyrical rhapsody "Thiruppavai," a collection of 30 hymns which depict her as a young girl in love with Krishna. In them she implores other young girls to observe penance, wake up early, & worship Lord Vishnu to attain good husbands & eternal bliss. Andal's verses are not just expressions of devotion but also literary masterpieces that are so deeply entrenched in the cultural fabric of South India that they are recited everyday by devoted Vaishanava women even today

Her other significant work is "Nachiar Tirumozhi," where she describes her longing for Lord Krishna, portraying herself as a Gopi (cowherd girl) seeking union with Him. The tone of her poems communicates divine pleasure in the mere sight of her beloved divine, supreme delight in his proximity & in the ineffable union with him

These 14 poems cover a wide range of topics, from imaginings of a little girl building sand castles, to a woman frustrated in love, calling her lover bitterly for having led her on & betrayed her

In her poems she also comes across as a woman who has experienced the Bliss of Divine but is now separated by that Bliss & is in anguish of separation – thus, one can say, Andal was born to manifest a dimension of Bhakti called as ‘Bridal Mysticism’. Her expressions, though raw, physical & in the language of ordinary human love, are of a mystical, supra-sensory nature. Her eventual Samadhi Consciousness in form of divine union with her beloved Krishna is represented by silence & implied by full moon

Here are parts from 2 of her poems

1) 
Bring me the cool nectar from the mouth of His flute
Spread it upon my face, it will revive me
Bring me the dust from the footprints left by the insensitive Lord
Smear it upon my body, that life may linger

2)
My Lord of Shrirangam, rich and righteous, who owns this sea-swept earth and the sky
Has made his possession now complete with bangle I wore on my hand !

.
Navaratra Day 3 - Women Yogis of India number 3

Akkamahadevi, 12th CE saint, mystic, & poetess, was a trailblazer in the Bhakti movement of India. Renowned for her unwavering devotion to Shiva, she defied societal norms by forsaking her royal heritage & embracing a life of asceticism. Her poems express the tension between family life, as a human wife & her love for the supreme divine, in context of her unhappy marriage to Kaushika, the king of the region

Her devotional compositions, called Vachanas, are imbued with profound spiritual insights & eloquently express her Bhakti. Rejecting conventional expectations, she wandered naked, considering herself wedded solely to her Lord (Shiva), transcending societal judgments & material attachments. She is said to have thrown away her clothing & cast off all sense of shame, flagrantly defying all notions of women’s sexuality

Her poetry reflects spiritual longing, the ephemeral nature of life, & the quest for divine union, inspiring generations with her radical spirituality & unwavering faith. She makes it very clear that Bhakti is an all-consuming affair, which many devotees cannot commit to if they have not mastered detachment

Her legacy endures as a symbol of fearlessness, radical asceticism defying social norms, & total surrender in Bhakti

2 months ago, I engaged with leaders from Akkamahadevi’s Virashaiva community & the insights I received in their company made me admire Akka (meaning, elder sister) even more for how she embodies classical asceticism of Yogis, pure heart of the Bhaktas & radical spirit of social reformers
Above picture is from her temple

Here are some of her strong writings,

1)
People, male and female,
blush when a cloth covering their shame comes loose
When the lord of lives,
lives drowned without a face in the world, 
how can you be modest?
When all the world is the eye of the lord,
onlooking everywhere, 
what can you cover and conceal?

 2)
I have fallen in love, O mother with the
Beautiful One, who is without any family,
without any country and without any peer;
Chenna Mallikarjuna (Shiva), the Beautiful,
is my husband
Fling into the fire the husbands 
who are subject to death and decay

Navaratra Day 4 - Woman Yogis of India number 4 

Sant Mukta bai (A.D 1279-1298) 

In her short life of 19 years this little girl inspired generations to come with her wisdom and wit. The life story of Muktabai is chiefly bound up with that of the great Hatha Yogi & Bhakta, Sant Jnanadev who was one of her brothers. Even though as siblings the children were ostracized by the society and treated badly by the people, and in spite of their parents committing "suicide", the four children stuck together with integrity and perseverance, and achieved Moksha

She speaks of the secrets of 'Maha Yoga' and how to live successfully in this world and yet rise above it to reach out to God

She was a great Siddha 'Yogini' of the Natha Siddha lineage, like her brothers

Her abhangas (spiritual poems) are full of deeper meaning of life and give instructions on how to manage life and spirituality being grounded in the world itself

There are some amazing stories of her spiritual prowess and situational wit in the short life of this dear Saint. Muktabai wrote forty-one abhang (spiritual poems) throughout her life span. I have been fortunate enough to grow up on her poems since my childhood

One of my favorite abanga is about her own spiritual transformation and her experience of totality when the duality dissolved. She speaks in deeply mystical parables, a kind of lingusitic style often used by Hatha Yogis, even today

She says

"An ant has flown to the sky and has swallowed the Sun. A great wonder has taken place indeed. A woman who is infertile has given birth to a child. A scorpion has gone to the nether world. Shesha, The serpent king is worshiping its own legs. A fly has transformed into an eagle. Muktai smiles at this. Mukta exhorts to rise above the obvious, materialistic level and recognizes the all-pervading Brahma represented by all living beings..."

Time (age) and Gender are the strongest limitations that we force on ourselves. Looking at the short but inspiring life of Muktabai we understand how we can rise above the two.

Do you feel guilty for missing your 'practice'?

Many practitioners feel overtly sad or self-critical for missing their Yoga 'practice'. Perhaps, reflecting on the definition of 'practice' could help

You see, as humans we live by our definitions.The narrow the definition, the narrower the scope of working

When practitioners complain about missing their Yoga practice, usually they mean their Asana practice

Viewing Yoga as Asana is a fairly recent phenomenon

The traditional, pre-modern view of Yoga Sadhana (yoga practice) includes all aspects & dimensions of a human person.Yoga has always been seen as a Life Practice, & not merely an Asana practice

This is why scriptures like Bhagavad Gita & Hatha Pradipika include tips on dietary habits, sleep, level of activity, & such everyday life variables

Yoga is about your entire day, not just about what you do on the mat or with your body

When we start seeing Yoga as a 24/7 life process, instead of a one-hour practice on the mat, we expand the scope of our transformation. It’s like multiplying the scope 24 times.That is when we start living Yoga & not just doing Yoga (asana)

Indeed, a diligent asana practice is important, & a gateway to Yoga for many. But limiting the entirety of Yoga practice just to asana practice could narrow the scope of practice and keep the practitioner in a loop of guilt & self-blame for having missed their practice hour. I've seen way too many practitioners give up on Yoga because they couldn't continue with asana

Lets expand the definition of our 'Practice' & let out some steam from the pressure we put on ourselves as a practitioner 

There is lots more to Yoga Sadhana (practice) than Asana Sadhana (postural practice)

Look at your Life process itself as a Yoga practice. Enjoy the practice, learn what you have to & progess gradually with patience

Our present anxiety is an outcome of past experiences, our future fears are a projection of present anxiety. It’s as if our life is garnished with anxiety, dare I say filled with the juice of fear

Fear is the most primal limitation. This is why Self-realization has been equated to fearless in Yogic literature

Our anxiety is based on identity. A Yoga teacher's anxiety is based on identity of being a Yoga teacher, & so on

The range of deities in Indic thought is not just a representation of the divine, but also a ‘lock & key’ mechanism to help refine the mind

Each deity is an embodiment of a certain quality (guna) or principle (tattva). The Guru guides the disciple’s transformation by assigning a specific deity ‘Key’ to open a particular mental ‘Lock’ – like administering a disease-specific medicine

The spectrum of deities is wide, ranging from gentle ones like Saraswati to extreme ones like Kali, or from Krishna to Mahakaal

The most radical of them is Kali. She is related to time because she 'eats' time. That’s why the name, Kali - the one who devours time. When time ends, everything ends – including self-identity

Kali is NOT a generic Goddess. Neither will you find many Indian girls named Kali, nor will you see as many temples dedicated to Kali. This is because Kali is like a nuclear reactor – admittance to those only with the right competence

Kali is one of the main deities of Tantras. Traditional Tantra is a secretive path, open only to initiates vouched by secrecy (guhyamarga)

As Tantra is reduced to an erotic modality by pop-spirituality, Kali’s radicalness has become fashionable. The ‘Cool factor’ has also diluted the responsibilities & prescriptions that are demanded when invoking a deity as specific as Kali 

Exotifying deities, especially ones as radical as Kali, & invoking them for their ‘Cool factor’ without knowledge of their principle & impact, is like popping prescription medicine without knowing what it’s meant for

Yes, Kali is a mother, but she is a no-nonsense, disciplinarian mother. Her radicalness may come across as 'rad' at first, but it’s going to demand ruthless detachment from the seeker, & that may not feel so 'funky' at all

So, what does it take to be a confident Yoga Teacher?
- Knowledge of anatomy?
- Expertise at headstands?
- Physical flexibility?
- Yoga Organization accreditations?
- Repeated visits to India?

I get asked this question often.

What if I said none of the above ?

The points in the list above are optional but not the core. You may have all of them, yet you could feel unclear and unconfident as a Yoga teacher. These requirements are feathers in a cap, but the cap per se is something completely different.

To become a confident Yoga Teacher with an inspiring work ethic, one must first know how to be a Yoga Student. A Yoga Student, matured by trials and learnings of studentship, organically starts teaching, and thus becomes a teacher.

Such a Yoga Student has to develop some essential qualities during their studenship, namely

- Sincere Discipline & Commitment to Sadhana & Study.
- Trust in the process of Yoga.
- Humility, empathy, patience (lots), & zest.
- Seeing Yoga as a pursuit of Self-mastery & not only as postural mastery.
- Honoring the culture & living tradition of Yoga.

All these qualities can be summarized under the first one - sincerity towards Sadhana & Study.

Only when the Yoga Students have a well-rounded approach to the process and practice of Yoga, they can become an efficient channel of transmission and inspiration as Teachers. Being a student and going through years of studentship, patiently and sincerely, makes one ready to teach confidently and humbly, out of personal experience (swānubhava)

A Yoga Teacher then is nothing but a living inspiration, a reflection of what practice, experience, faith, and studentship has created.

Unless required, see yourself only as a Student of Yoga and do not allow your role as a Yoga Teacher to hijack your studentship
.
Share with fellow Yoga Teachers. 
Let's all study together and grow together.

No, Yoga is not a system of one book.
No, Yoga is not a teaching of one seer.
No, Yoga is not a gift of one 'God'.
No, Yoga is not based in one language.
No, Yoga is not one, single philosophy.
.
Yoga is a vast body of knowledge that has continously emerged from the intersection, interaction and intermingling of ideas, experiences, myths, symbols, legends, signs, traditions, cultures and influences across, at least 3500 years, in the Indian sub-continent.
.
In the field of Yoga philosophy there are views & counter views, each seemingly opposite, which does get overwhelming. The scope of Yogic philosophy includes both, techniques & theory, atheism & theism, dualism & monism, practicality & spirituality and everything in between
.
This makes the enterprise of studying & teaching Yoga an extremely complex, yet humbling task, that demands commitment, patience, wonder, and discipline
.
There is a big interest nowadays to know Yoga philosophy. Which is great, but, our impatience, the rush to know everything quickly & to tell everyone I know it, may compell us to reduce the entire Yoga philosophy to Yoga Sutra, or entire Hatha Yoga to Hatha Yoga Pradipika, or the entire devotional tradition to Krishna bhakti & so on
.
Yoga philosophy has to be learned in wider perspective. Cherry picking narratives will only give us a uni-dimensional view of this vast knowledge system
.
So, what should a Yoga student do to understand Yoga philosophy?
.
Commit to a long term study of Yoga philosophy from someone who has faith & experience in living the Yoga philosophy that they teach. Study with a teacher who not only makes you intellectually study but also helps you practically LIVE the philosophy to realize the teachings
.
Remember, the aim of Yoga philosophy is NOT to complicate the mind further or help sound like an intellectual, but to free the mind from deslusion of self. 
.
What really matters ultimately is your own intuitive realization of Self that lies beyond the concepts & ideas that Yoga philosophy talks about, & this realization arises only through dedicated & long term commitment to
• swadhayaya (self-study), 
• sadhana (living the practice) & 
• shraddha (faith)

The scope of sound goes beyond mere communication in Indic tradition

Shrimad Bhāgavatam (3.26.33) says

arthāśrayatvaṁ śabdasya
draṣṭur liṅgatvam eva ca
tan-mātratvaṁ ca nabhaso
lakṣaṇaṁ kavayo viduḥ

"The learned ones & those with true knowledge define sound as that which conveys the idea of an object, indicates the presence of a speaker, & constitutes the subtle form of ether"

Thus, sound is understood as a medium of communication, expression, & interaction of ideas & emotions. Sound is not mere "vibration", but a fabric of interaction

Deep within the belly of every word there is a potent meaning & sense waiting to be deciphered. This sense is called Bhāva, the state of expression (of emotion)

Bhāva (भाव) is derived from Sanskrit word ‘bhāvayanti’, meaning, to pervade. Thus, sense & meaning pervade sound, & Mantra is nothing but codified Bhāva

Bhāva enlivens a Mantra. Yes, phonetic correctness & grammatical fineness is important in Veda mantra but nothing can replace the critical importance of Bhāva. (Also, not every Mantra is a Veda mantra). This is why, even Patanjali says, one must do Japa with Bhāva (PYS 1:28)

Bhāva emerges from Shraddhā – faith/trust/devotion. Bhāva is what makes words powerful & that very word power is used for spiritual evolution in Yogic tradition via Mantra chant, Japa, Bhajan, Kirtan etc

Shraddhā (faith) evokes Bhāva (expression) & Bhāva (expression) invokes Shraddhā (faith). Sound not only helps us express but also evolve. Bhāva carries Sharddhā to its peak, i.e., Sharanāgati, total surrender

According to the Hindu thought, the world is divided into manifest & unmanifest, & this has direct correlation with sound & silence

Silence always underlies everything that is spoken, & this is why the highest speech is considered to be that which brings the sound back to silence

This is also the main intent of Yogic scriptures – to show us how to retract speech into silence

Scriptures like the Upanishads indicate that when the mind’s noise is quietened, the sound of silence is heard - which is nothing but Om

Making the mind silent using sound (Mantra) to reveal the Being beyond the sound is the secret of Mantra Yoga

Looking at the extensive hybridization & rampant dilution of Yogic methods over the last few decades, the usage of the term ‘traditional yoga’ has become necessary to give a context to the Yoga one is learning or teaching

But, what does the prefix ‘traditional’ in traditional Yoga actually entail?

The term ‘traditional’ in traditional Yoga indicates Indic spiritual knowledge tradition that has emerged from the Indian subcontinent over (at least) the last 3500 years.Thus, the term has geographic & cultural specificity

Traditional Yoga includes a large corpus of diverse philosophies (not just Patanjali’s Yoga) & modalities (not only asana-pranayama) that are ultimately aimed at Atma Jnana, Self-realization, variously also called as Moksha, Nirvana, etc. This is unlike ‘modern Yoga’ that may not have Self-realization as its goal

Traditional view sees Yoga as a complete mind-body-life transformation process based on a multi-dimensional view of the human person & not as a fitness-wellness modality that sees human only as a physical form

Traditional Yogic knowledge is not mere information studied from the teacher & taught to the student, but is a ‘lived realization’ that is highly personal in nature. This is why traditional Yoga insists on stringent ethical-moral norms (Yama-Niyama), stable faith & unfailing commitment. Modern (popular) Yoga doesn't insist on such pre-conditions

Any claim of teaching ‘traditional Yoga’ needs to be backed by relevant scriptural citation and/or demonstrated by studentship under a teacher belonging to a traditionally sanctioned lineage

Clarification
1) This is a simplistic post on a highly nuanced topic
2) The note doesn't necessarily make 'traditional Yoga' ‘good’ & the other ‘bad’, or ‘right’ / ‘wrong’
3) Though ‘traditional Yoga’ is also taught in parts, like teaching asana-pranayama classes etc., the final goal of Moksha should be clearly specified in teachings that call themselves ‘traditional’
4) Though traditional Yogic teachings emerge from a specific geography, they are meant for the entire world
5) Yes, cultures grow over time & so has/will Yoga, but that does not give us the license to ignore its roots & history
