In the pre-social-media days, when I started teaching Yoga internationally, I had interesting experiences with Yoga stereotypes that weren't prevalent in India back then

After a workshop in Europe, the organizer remarked that if I had worn ‘orange clothes like an Indian Swami’ they would have gotten more signups. In another incident, some participants left the hall because I was wearing Jeans (it was a Yoga talk🤷). Way too many times I’ve been told I don’t look like an authentic ‘Indian Yogi’ because neither do I wear malas, nor am I thin like the sadhus. Once an organizer expressed doubt over my competence because I didn’t use incense to 'cleanse' her studio before my workshop, & many such incidents

Here's the economics.Consumerism perpetuates stereotypes because stereotypes help boost sales & keep production costs low. Advertising creates demand, perpetuates FOMO, &, we (literally) buy into stereotypes (I am glad this narrative is been challenged over the last few years)

Our choices, sense of style & purchase habits are heavily manipulated by someone sitting in a Boardroom. Look how we are arm-twisted by Social Media companies to express only in ways that help them optimize revenue

Take the example of global yoga clothing market, an industry that majorly perpetuates body stereotypes to boost sales.The industry is projected to grow from $22.72 billion in 2021 to $39.91 billion in 2028 by telling us how we should look, & what we should wear to look the part. I know way too many Yoga enthusiasts who determine their self-worth based on such stereotypes in mainsteam & social media

I remember a line from the movie Fight Club, “The things you own end up owning you…”

Spirituality is about the 'spirit', stuff is only the aid. Do not allow the aid to become your need. Remember you are consciousness, not a mere customer

An old Hatha scripture, Dattatreya Yoga Shastra, notes this & says, ‘The one who is devoid of Yoga practice (sadhana) but only wears signs & attires to show otherwise, the company of such a person should be avoided’

The way to Self is via sincere Sadhana. If stuff has become more critical than Sadhana, it’s a wake-up call

Reflect & Share🙏🏽

We all have grown up on the social construct ‘More is Better’. Consumerism culture thrives on this dictum. We are told, the more you have the better you will be.

The Yoga practitioner too may unconsciously comes under the influence of such a narrative, thinking that knowing twenty Pranayamas is better than doing two,  doing 10 variations of Suryanamaskar is better than doing one, having multiple certifications is better than having a few, & doing complicated things is more advanced than simple practices

But, when it comes to Yoga (at least the one that aligns with traditional ethos), More may not necessarily be Better, & Complicated may not always be Advanced. This has been my consistant message in my ongoing Living the Gita course - since we are working  on simplifying our understanding of Yoga

This is where we need to remember that Yoga is a path of gradual withdrawal or lessening – a Nivritti Mārga. And, an essential aspect of that is simplification

If your Yoga is about 'stuff', then surely go ahead & consume more. But, if you seek to explore the core of Yoga, then simplification needs to be woven into your Yoga practice

The ‘advance’ of Yoga is not in complexity but in simplicity. How you simplify your life, how you lightening the mind, how you unwind your relations, how you exist in effortlessness, is the key to advancement in Yoga

Neither doing complicated practices nor quoting fancy philosophies necessarily connotes advancement in Yoga. Advanced Yoga is practiced by living life honestly, navigating challenges confidently, accepting success humbly, and opening to the unknown faithfully.

This is why most Hatha scriptures mention just a few asanas. This is why at the end of explaining everything to Arjuna, Shri Krishna says, “just surrender to me”. This is why all practices of Yoga are ultimately about how you refine your mind & meditate. This is also why, spiritually evolved Yogis live frugally, with simple needs, but deep contentment

Becoming Simple is the "advanced" of Yoga. Allow your Yoga to gradually help you stabilize your mind & simplify your life 🙏🏽

Has your Yoga practice made your mind calmer and life simpler?

As ‘How to be a Teacher’ gains traction in modern Yogic curricula, one needs to ask if we are being taught how to be a Student – because, there can be no Yoga Teacher without a firm grounding in Yogic studentship. Are we? 
 
In Prashna Upanishad, 6 students approach Sage Pippalada for spiritual knowledge. But, the teacher doesn't start teaching right away. He requires them to live with him for a year, lead a life of discipline & practice, to see if they are fit to be taught

In the Tantric scripture, Tripura Rahasya, Parashurama had to cleanse his mind via Japa for 12 long years before Dattatreya could grant him spiritual knowledge

Not only in India, in every ancient tradition, studentship has been the basis of knowledge transfer. Plato lived with Socrates for 12 years, Aristotle was a student of Plato for 20 years

Even today, in corporate & academic sectors, the junior has to ‘shadow’ or do ‘assistantship’ of a senior. Apprenticeship is a requirement in every craft, then why not in modern Yoga? 

Is it because we are so taken by the idea of becoming a Leader, that we have ignored how to be a follower?

Teachers without a firm grounding in study, sadhana & studentship are churned out by the thousands every year by institutions that run YTTs solely to keep their studios running due to economic compulsion. Also, pressure to stay “Certified” has promoted an incessant pursuit of collecting ‘Hours’ instead of committing to patiently deepening self-knowledge

I hope at the industry level this is given due credence. Till then, let's realize importance of Studentship & work towards cultivating the essence of a Student within. Leaving here my perspective today, on Thursday, the day of the Guru
 
Studentship is dedicated, disciplined, diligent & faithful commitment to teacher & study over a long period of time. Tips 👇🏽

• Find teacher/s who can impart theoretical knowledge as well as guide your spiritual growth. (This search will take time)
• Once you find such teacher/s, deeply commit to studying with them for a long period of time
• Stay humble & see yourself as a student
• Be courageous to go through the grind
• Stay true to your own Sadhana till teacher appears

Why are many Indian Gods & Goddesses blue in colour?

In Hinduism, the depiction of Gods and Goddesses, like Krishna, Shiva, Kali etc. with blue skin tone is deeply symbolic and holds a profound cultural and philosophical meaning. Here are a few reasons for representing the divine in Blue colour.

The colour blue represents the immeasurableness associated with the vastness of the sky and the boundless depths of the ocean. Thus, blue (or its shades) symbolize immeasurable power of the divine. Blue colour also symbolises that the divine permeates the entire universe and signifies that the divine is not confined to a specific form or colour but encompasses the entire universe

Blue and its shades also invite us to immerse ourselves in the shades, to go beyond the shades and into the pure ‘white’ that denotes transcendence of attributes like name and form. This symbolizes the Yogic journey of a seeker, through the shades of our self- consciousness, and into the realization of the limitless consciousness.

According to ancient Indian Mathematics, Gaṇitashastra, the colour blue (Nīla) is said to have been used as a symbol for the unknown. And, in Shilpashastra, the ancient Indian science of iconography, blue is referred to as a primary colour which can be used to prepare an infinite number of shades – thus connoting infinite and unknowable forms of the divine.

Dark Blue colour was also used to symbolize the ‘Dark’ that one has to face and conquer beyond the boundaries of name and form. Eg: Kali and Bhairava are often represented in this context. Also, Shiva turning ‘blue’ after drinking the Halahala poison is in this context

Traditional Yogic narrative is full of legends, metaphors, demonstratable accounts & symbolic stories, which do have their place in the larger context of how Yogic tradition views things
 
Popular Yoga too has followed in the foot steps of its predecessor, but many times the claims made are either cherry-picked, wrongly ascribed or taken out of context

I've heard some unique legends & exaggerated claims over the years. Here are a few,

I have been told by many followers of a popular 'style' of Yoga that, in the ‘original’ Yoga Sutra, Patanjali had prophesized the birth of their founder. When pointed out that nothing like this is mentioned in the Yoga Sutra, I am told that it is clearly stated in the ‘original’ Sanskrit text of the Yoga Sutra & that many English translations purposely omit translating this fact due to conspiracy

Then, over multiple times I have heard a claim that "according to Yoga scriptures, Ajna Chakra is the Pineal Gland, which is the seat of the Soul". Well, there is not a single Yogic/Tantric scripture (at least to my knowledge) that claims this. If you know one, do let me know. This correlation was a popular idea in Western philosophy & Western occultism though, & thus must have come into popular Yogic narrative. The Greco-Roman physician called Galen, 200 CE, talks about this relation, & so does the famous 17th Century French Philosopher & Mathematician Rene Descartes

Then, there are those ever-popular claims as to how "Yogic scriptures ask us to wear red clothes & eat red veggies to "open" the Root Chakra.." & so on. This is a highly simplified claim & correlation. Again, if one can back it by citing a legit (authentic) scripture (shāstra), I am all ears

Friends, we all need metaphors, inspiring stories, analogies & symbolism to help decipher, understand & connect with Yoga. But there is a thin line between legends & metaphors and scripturally backed demonstratable accounts

How I dream of a time when Critical Thinking becomes an essential part of every Yoga Teacher Training. This is extremely crucial to preserve & practice authentic knowledge

What is the top Yogic Urban Legend that you've heard of?

Many Yoga Teachers feel that they don’t know enough about Yoga. This is a legit issue that creates self-doubt & hampers them from going out & doing their thing. This is a reassuring post for them

A few weeks ago I saw an advert for a 200-Hour Training that promised to teach 100 asanas & over 20 Pranayamas in a 21-day residential program. I can only imagine the pressure on the students to absorb as much as they can in 21 days because they have come to believe that the more they know the better teacher they will become

The anxiety of not knowing (enough) is also compounded by the fact that Yoga itself is thousands of year old knowledge system with hundreds of scriptures & dozens of philosophies that one can't keep up with (at least initially)

Upon that, due to commercial pressures of standing out from the crowd & a constant, in-the-face performative Yogic culture that triggers a sense of lack, a Yoga Teacher may feel compelled to keep offering a lot of options & varieties to just stay relevant & retain students

In short, contemporary Yoga teachers are under tremendous pressure to become "experts" fast 

Lots can be said on this, but today will just leave few tips to help manage this quandary

1) You will never know enough because knowledge is inexhaustible. Whats needed is right knowledge, not more knowledge

2) Yes, there are many scriptures of Yoga, but one need not study them all. This is why its crucial to find your teacher & study with them over a long period of time

3) Many techniques are listed in scriptures, but one doesn’t have to teach everything. In ancient times the Guru used to filter & administer specific techniques based on the proclivity of student. Since books have largely replaced Gurus, that filter is gone, making us feel we have to teach everything. If you feel compelled to teach too many techniques, enquire why

4) You are a work in progress, don't think of yourself as a finished product. Give yourself opportunity & time to grow. Be patient with yourself

5) It’s not about how much you know, but what you do with whatever little you know

We are (still) conditioned to see asana unidimensionaly - as a pursuit of flexibility, believing, more stretching = better flexibility = better asana. For decades practitioners have broken their backs going 'deep in the pose'

Remember that cult meme of Batman slapping Robin saying ‘But, I am not flexible…’? How much flexibility would Robin need to pass off as a ‘Yoga’ practitioner?

Yesterday I spoke to someone who is a fitness instructor for 2 decades, a lifelong spiritual seeker, & a graduate of an 18-month Teacher Training but is doubting his capabilities as a Yoga teacher cuz’ he is not ‘flexible enough’

Yes, depth in asana is subjective, but how deep to go in asana should be assessed by an honest Risk v/s Benefit analysis

If going deep compromises safety, ease of breath, focus of attention & sense of effortlessness, solely to increase the ‘depth’ of a pose, then such a trade-off is risky

But performative, picture-video-driven asana culture makes us overlook this & chase an ‘ideal scenario’ dictated by someone else’s body type (ideally a bendy person) that may not be one's requirement

Blind pursuit of stretching may even make us overlook what type of flexibility we are actually developing, dynamic, static, or ballistic

Also, let’s face it, our self-esteem is closely attached to our asana performance. Asana practice invariably becomes a pursuit of lifting a sagging self-esteem.
Better at poses = Better Yogi = More self-worth, being the correlation. So, a lot of mind games are at play even in a physical practice. So why not work on the mind?

One can only go so ‘deep' physically, up to joint range of motion. But, there is another level of ‘deep’ that awaits us - the depth of self-awareness. Asana practice can help us do that

Asana is a gateway to deeper mental realignment. This is why one important Hatha scripture called Matsyendra Samhita says that the goal of asana is Manah Sthira Kārana, stabilizing the mind

Breathe & move effortlessly in asana, working with acceptance instead of focusing on reaching another pre-established flexibility goal. Let asana practice be a patient journey, not a desperate pursuit

What is 'deep' for you in a pose ?
We are all going back home....

How has been your journey of extending compassion and gentleness towards yourself ?

Remember, by prioritizing your own well-being and being compassionate toward your mind and body, you, as a yoga teacher, not only model a holistic approach to health but also foster an environment of understanding and self-love.

The journey of self starts with kindness towards oneself.

Let me know your thoughts.

Please Share and educate 🙏🏾

#yogateacher #yogateachertraining #yogabeyondposes
...will you answer the door?

When we perceive a muscle in an asana, we have to realize that it's not some dead tissue that we are working with, it is a living, responsive component of our body.

The muscles communicate through the zone of sensation. Such communication is a request from the nervous system, asking us to be aware, and may be even restrain ourselves, as we approach the end range
of motion.

Please, do not forget this inner communication between your muscles and the nervous system in your Asana practice. Its an extremely crucial component that introduces you to the inner universe.

Some teachers give too many instructions which can distract the students from establishing inner communication. Some teachers even tell their students where and how much to feel, which robs them from finding their own authentic inner connection, and some insist so much on the precision of the shape of an asana that the students get overwhelmed, watching & copying the teacher, trying to fit into someone else's concept of an ideal asana.

Such strategies restrict the students from experiencing their own subjective 'feel' of the Asana.

If we want to use asana beyond its physical dimension, and open it up as an inward practice, then its important to tune into our own body's communication mechanism before getting distracted by the teacher's instruction or our own expectation.

Only then one will be able to establish one's own standard of effort and ease in an asana practice.

Remember, Asana practice can become a beautiful process of education and assurance, where our mind
tells the muscles..

'It's ok, I am watching over you. Do only what you can."

Be responsible, be aware and work with your limitations, not against it.

How has your asana sadhana helped your inward communication with self ?

Share 🙏🏾

Have you ever wondered why terms like Drishya, Drishtā, Darshana, terms that pertain to vision, are so common in Yoga thought ? Here's a context,

So over the last 10 weeks we've been studying the Bhagavad Gita through my 'Living the Gita' course. Students have started submitting their feedbacks and reflections and the most common feedback is about how their vision, their perception of self and the world has transformed. 

It's something like this picture. Both pictures are of Jupiter taken 100 years apart. Jupiter did not change, what changed was our vision of Jupiter. With better Vision we gained better understanding of Jupiter. 

This is how broadening our Vision, our Drishti, reveals self and life in its true colours. 

This is why the term Drishti is NOT just about sight, but about the Vision, not only about what the eyes see but about who sees what is shown.

The most profound Vision is the Vision of Self (ātmadarshana), with which one sees the Atman within all.

How has your self-perception transformed because of Yoga ?

Spoke with a group of sincere Yoga teachers in our Yoga Camp today about how seekers & teachers downplay their magnificence just to not come across as being proud or egotistical. Its as if misconstrued interpretations of spiritual ideals like humility, non-violence, compassion,  simplicity, are used to limit the self instead of liberating it

We let others' opinion create our self-perception, in turn becoming what others want us to be, or end up bending to market demands sacrifing personal principles. This is made worse especially in spiritual circles where idealistic notions make us feel guilty if we transgress even a bit, making us too hard on ourselves

It’s sad to see so many capable Yoga teachers underplay their abilities due to fear of being labelled egoistic. So many who have sacrificed their boundaries to become people pleasers

"I don't post much, because real Yogis are not on Social Media", “I don’t write about my own journey because it doesn’t look humble”, “I don’t use ‘me’ & ‘my’ in my posts as I don’t want others to see me as a narcissist”. "I shouldn't be posting about my challenges as it will make me look weak". By feeding into such notions we are limited by the same ‘Ego’ that we are trying hard not to project

I was once rebuked by a ‘senior’ Yoga teacher (who I didn’t know personally) for posting my picture on my FB profile. She said my students won't respect because I could come across as self-obssesed. For reference, she said, “Look, that’s why I have a pic of my dog instead of my own picture on my profile’. It was clear that she didn’t see the ‘My’ in both cases

Look, we all have issues with our esteem, confidence, expression, & we need to resolve them gradually with patience & self-compassion

Honest acceptance & patient transformation is the way. But delaying, hiding, repressing or bypassing our issues by using misconstrued spiritual notions is self-sabotage

Arjuna could have faked courage just to impress Lord Krishna, but he didn’t. He recognized his despondency, owned it & sought counsel

Generate self-clarity & don’t be reduced by the same ego that you want to reduce

So our 3 day Abhyāsa Boot Camp is done, and I am speechless

Why "Boot Camp"? Some asked. 
Someone else stated, but it doesn't sound 'Yogic'....😄

Well, this is exactly why I wanted to (and want to) have rigorous study programs like these - programs that replicate the āshram model of study.

In Sanskrit, āshram means a set-up where one puts in effort. As āshrams become more like 'cash'rams, its difficult for Indian Yoga students to find unbranded, non-sectarian places of study where knowledge is taught with a critical approach, without the sugar-coated mumbo jumbo

That's why the name 'Boot Camp' , study training intensive. I know its not 'Yogic' but thats the point 😊

In our Camp we approached Yoga in its pre-modern interpretation, sticking closely to its original purpose, as a science of self-understanding, as a study of life, without the fluff, without dilution - busting myths, clarifying hearsay, stirring clear of mysticism, with reverence to the culture & scriptures, & had lots and lots of fun doing that...🥰

Such dedicated bunch of students came from near and far, and immersed in a loving incubator with ruthless honesty -  crying, laughing, hugging, sharing their deepest fears, holding each other, studying, moving, bending, twisting, empathizing with each other's pains and traumas and going home with a lil' more hope and a lesser self-doubt. 

A big thankyou to my dear @rcp_yoga yoga for holding the camp so capably with your knowledge and understanding in your studio  @kurma.shala , and being such an amazing partner in the project. 

And, for the students. Uff, what can I say. I learned so much from y'all. I am so stoked by your passion, your sincerity and your capability. I am so excited for your future. We are all cheering for you. Go, win the world 💪🏽

And, as for more Abhyāsa Boot Camps, for now let me just say, ....this is just the beginning

During last three days of our Yoga Camp the problem of too much was talked about a lot.

There is soooo much to know in Yoga & there is soooo much information out there in the public domain that it can be truly overwhelming and confusing, especially for someone starting off on the path

In modern spirituality, we are surrounded by a plethora of techniques. We are floating in a sea of information. It is very easy to “know”. Knowing is just 0.003 seconds away on Google. But, are we really processing & experiencing what we know?

Oftentimes, as seekers, we get excited about learning new stuff. Every method feels right & we want to practice everything. But, in our excitement of collecting knowledge we forget to pause & ask, “is it the right teaching for me?”

We go to different teachers to learn more & more, gather certifications & hours of education, which, on paper, look impressive, but gathering more information & certification neither denotes knowledge, nor connotes spiritual maturity.

Unlike other fields of knowledge, spirituality is not about the width of knowledge but the depth of knowing. Our craving to know more mainly stems from our self-doubt & our impatience.

Don’t romanticize information, do not flirt with knowledge, it will only make you swim on the surface. Be courageous and pursue the One Single Truth (Ekatattva) which will not be known by externalized knowing but by internalized experiencing (Anubhava)

If your Yogic learning is not helping you Unlearn your self, then that learning is mere decoration - just a performance. 

Swelter on the path till you establish self-clarity as to what you want to know & where you want to go. Then, give all you've got to find the teaching and the teacher. Once you find 'your' teacher, steer away from all distractions & dive deeply into the practice & study wholeheartedly with total commitment, faith, and sincerity.

This is what Traditional Yoga calls “Ekānta” - Single End of seeking.

👉🏻 What is your strategy to stay focused amidst the overwhelm of information out there ?

Reflect and Share 🙏🏾

I've been asked way too many times about what one should look for in a Yoga Teacher if one wants to practice or study with them sincerely. This is asked especially by newer Yoga Teachers who seek clearly defined goals to grow.

And, since the whole of Yoga is not only about poses, here is a list that could help you find, or become, a better Yoga teacher.

10 things to look for in a Yoga Teacher that has nothing to do with how they do their poses

1) They have transformed themselves through their own Sadhana & study

2) They teach holistically with reverence to the Yogic tradition

3) They encourage questions and explorations guided by critical inquiry

4) They empower without creating dependency

5) They are open about their own life struggles and stories

6) They back their yogic claims with proper citations and evidence wherever needed

7) They are empathetic and considerate

8) They contribute to the society

9) They have faith in their own teacher & the teachings of Yoga

10) They live with clarity & integrity and are undettered by public opinion.

Note: Number 3 & Number 9 are NOT oppositions, because faith and reason are not opposed in Yogic system, as some colonial systems of knowledge believe.

I love hugs, giving & receiving. I've often wondered, what if all philosophies & practices of Yoga that we try (struggle) to engage with lead to an embrace, a warm comforting hug? 

What if all our spiritual pursuits, challenges & stresses end in a cuddle, a gentle loving cuddle? Beyond terse philosophies & rigid notions of spirituality, what if it all is just a big sigh, a deep rest of sorts in the comforting  arms of the Divine? My Yoga sādhanā makes me sink deeper into those arms, more n' more..

So many mystics, across cultures have expressed their highest spiritual state as a loving embrace from the Divine. The 13th century Yogi Saint, Sant Jnaneshwar expresses his most profound spiritual experience as “shevati vishwarupe mithi det Hari”, meaning, at the end I was embraced by the universal Lord Hari”. Then, we have the 17th century mystic, Saint Tukaram exclaiming lovingly his spiritual enlightenment as “prem rase baisali mithi”, a cuddle filled with nectar of Love

On the other side of the world, we have the Christian mystic, Saint Angela of Foligno of the 13th century, presenting her enlightenment as “The embrace of God that produces a light so great that the soul understands the fullness of God's goodness, which it experiences in itself”. Or, the Sufi mystic, Jalalludin Rumi, expressing his unconditional love for the beloved by saying “In the orchard and rose garden, I see your face. In the shadows of passion, I am embraced by your love”

Truly, a Bhakta (devotee) doesn't care for transcendental experiences. The devotee, in their love for the Divine, manifests the profundity of enlightenment in the here & now. There is nowhere to go & no place to reach for the Bhakta. While philosophers argue & the skeptics debate about what it is & how it is, the Bhakta experiences it right in the heart through total surrender & unashamed love of the beloved Divine. Divinity is always embracing us, we just have to acknowledge it & melt in it. Why struggle when you can snuggle? 

Hug somebody warmly today
Assure them with a gentle touch
Comfort them with a cheerful smile
Our world needs more of it now then ever 

I send you all comforting Hugs 🤗

Share & pass the hug
Just this for today.

We all would love to have a single idea of Yoga, a simple interpretation of its terms & a linear view of its history and philosophy, right? 

Of course, because it makes life easy. But the fact is, for a body of knowledge that is at least 3000 years old, it is just not possible.

I often see Yoga teachers - influencers generalizing the whole of Yoga to one book, one philosophy, one language, but such reduction does more disservice to Yoga than benefit, & is exactly what the colonisers (who came from spirituality of one book) did when they couldn’t place the sheer diversity of Indic spiritual ideas in one basket.

And this is the discomforting (dare I say overwhelming) aspect of Yoga – it is vast, diverse, layered and ancient. The more comfortable we are with this fact, the easier & exciting our study of Yoga History & Philosophy will be.

· No, Yoga is not only 8 limbs

· No, Yoga is not only of 4 types

· No, Yoga Sutra is not the only book of Yoga philosophy

· No, Sanskrit is not the only language of Yoga

· No, Veda is not the only origin of Yoga

· No, Shiva is not the only God of Yoga

· No, Yoga is not only union

The most important term in all the above statements is ‘not only’, because it takes into account the diversity of thought that emerged under the umbrella of Yoga through Indic history and also opens up to context-based interpretation.

That’s why, when someone asks me a question like ‘what does Yoga say about XYZ?’ my answer is, ‘…it depends’ - because, it truly does. Anything & everything in Yoga needs to be interpreted in context, context of time period, language, school of thought, social structure, lineage (sampradaya) and so on.

Note: Contextuality of a subject matter doesn’t mean ambiguity. Just because Yogic ideas can be interpreted in different ways doesn’t give us a licence to interpret them the way we want. The Yogic tradition gives a systematic way of interpreting the terms which needs to be aligned with.

Share and spread the word.

• Despite being on the path for 10 years I doubt myself
• Inspite of daily sadhana, my mind is busy in meditation
• Nothing is happening, should I change my practice, or do something different?

We all have had such thoughts, right? 
We also beat ourselves, have FOMO or feel left behind

Well, patience is not spoken of much in modern spirituality, but is one the most important virtues to cultivate 

Since we live in a material reality that's dictated by time, we also tend to view spiritual development through the lens of time. This is more so due to our colonial conditioning that created norms of time-based value (hourly wage system) during the Industrial Revolution.

But spiritual development may not be determined by time alone, like say industrial productivity standards that guarantee more output with increased ‘man-hour’ labor

Yes, we need time to count class hours, age, breath holds etc. but all this has nothing much to do with spiritual evolution really

This is why Yogic scriptures emphasize patience. Patience is indicated by many terms in Yogic texts

Gita says one needs to develop teeteekshaa, tolerance. Tolerating the (slow?) pace of spiritual growth, despite our desperation to be at a 'higher' level, is patience itself
 
Many of us read spiritual books, get inspired, but then also become impatient & want to reach the level of Yogis & Saints today!! Krishna tells us to tolerate this desperation (patiently)

Another term is Dheera, which means patient. It also means the one who is firm. Krishna says that our material existence is bound by time, & the ones firm in their resolve are not disturbed by the passing of time

In Yoga we are trying to regulate the mind, & this mind has been with us through billions of conditionings for millions of lifetimes. If you don’t believe in ‘Karma theory’ then too, resolving a mind thats conditioned since infancy is a ginormous task

So, be considerate & empathetic with yourself. Don’t allow your desperation, comparison & impatience to complicate a mind that is on the way to uncomplicate itself. 

Be patient with yourself, it’s the gentlest self-care practice you can do for yourself

"Come to my class, you will feel good” – we all have said or heard this. Yes, Yoga sessions can help us feel better. We all have benefited much from them. But, one can’t deny the fact that Yoga may NOT always make us feel good or happy

Traditionally, Yoga is understood to be an existential inquiry via a deeply cathartic self-transformation process that works on the innermost dimensions of the seeker

If Yoga is practiced with sincerity & faith, a time will invariably come when the ‘ugly’, ‘painful’, ‘dark’ aspects of our personality will have to be confronted. This act of confrontation is called ‘Tapas’ & going through the process is called ‘Tapasyā’. Both Patanjali & Shri Krishna talk about it

No matter what one starts with, Asana, Pranayama, or Dhyana, when you open to the Yogic process with sincerity, the process itself makes sure that the mind is thoroughly cleansed, cleansed off lifetimes old limiting conditioning - and that may not always feel good

I have had students who had panic attacks in simple meditations, who've sobbed their way in Pranayama, went through fits of rage & attacked me physically in classes. I myself have cried for days in some of my Sādhanā immersions. I am sure many of you too have, or are still going through the churning

As Yoga classes increasingly position themselves as ‘feel good', ‘relaxing’ sessions there is a quandary that Yoga Teachers find themselves in...

On one hand, the teachers want to create an ambience of safety, security, positivity & calm, but, on the other hand, they also know that the practice is inherently cathartic, & that it will not always be ‘feel good’. Especially, the deeper one ventures in the Yogic process it surely isn't all ‘love n’ peace’

This is the tight rope walk that every well-intentioned Yoga teacher walks

I know there are many considerations at stake but here are 4 points that can help

• Give an honest view of the nature of Yogic process to the students even though you conduct 'feel good' sessions
• Know what depth of process you can facilitate
• Make yourself resilient through Sādhanā & Swādhyāya  to support your students
• Be patient & empathetic

👉🏻 How do you manage this situation ?

Sanskrit is an indicative language, a flamboyantly descriptive one at that. A word in Sanskrit may have different meanings depending on the context. That's why a naïve translation of Yogic terms without due consideration to the context & sans reference to the cultural paradigm only handicaps our comprehensive understanding of Yoga

One common term that I feel is largely misunderstood is Buddhi

Buddhi is usually translated as intellect or reason, which makes people think its about intelligence

Well, yes, Buddhi means intellect & reason but it would be myopic to view Buddhi only in the sense of intelligence, smartness, IQ, scholarship etc.

Buddhi, in its profound sense, is a faculty through which the true nature of our existence is cognized, including the limits of what we know & what we are not. In its refined sense, Buddhi is the ability to discern subtle realities of life

This is why, according to the Sāṅkhyakārikā (37), Buddhi is responsible for discriminating between prakṛti & the purusha

Buddhi also connotes presence of mind, & ability to discern, & is therefore one of the foremost abilities the Yoga practitioner has to develop

Buddhi can be hijacked by the lower tendencies (rajasic, tamasic potencies). Buddhi is 'sharpened' through constantly reminding ourselves of our true nature, abiding by ethical practices, keeping the faith, doing sādhanā sincerely & above all, embracing life in its bitter-sweetness only to become steady in a stable knowing of what is & what is not    

Shivapurāna says, buddhiryasya balaṃ tasya nirbuddhestu kuto balam, i.e., having (refined) buddhi is power, how can one be powerful without buddhi? 

That’s why, the Gita calls the process of sharpening the Buddhi & knowing who one truly is as BuddhiYoga - eṣā te'bhihitā sāṃkhye buddhiryoge tvimāṃ śṛṇu Gita 2:39

A “Buddhimāna” - the one with refined Buddhi, is the one who operates in the world knowing that the Self is permanent & infinite, thus immunizing against the suffering that the transient world brings

Pic: Saraswati, the deity of Buddhi. Look how relaxed & cheerful she looks. Thats the sign of a refined Buddhi

How do you maintain your sanity in this world ? 😀
Share 👇

‘Ego’ gets a lot of flak & creates so much anxiety in the Yoga world. I’ve met many who reject their current state of self as (bad) ‘Ego’, to desperately seek some (good) ‘True Self’ out there, somewhere, & end up in a state thats neither here, nor there. Such self-rejection births Spiritual Bypassing.

Beyond its popular understanding as self-conceit, ‘Ego’ is nothing but the “I” or the limited self. It's neither good nor bad. Ego is a place-holder of self-identity. Rejecting, hating, or denying it as bad or evil creates an inner division that is constantly at war with itself

One CANNOT realize the Higher Self (ātman) without working out the Ego-self (ahamkāra)

Yoga is deeply rooted in acceptance of how & where one is. The entire 1st & start of 2nd chapter of Gita details Arjuna’s dismal mental state. If Yogic tradition wanted us to look away or deny the present self, then such incidents wouldn’t have been stated

Arjuna neither rejects his confused state, which wouod be spiritual bypassing, nor does he fake a positive stance, which could be seen as toxic positivity. He is neither embarrassed by his sorry state, nor does he feel shy in front of his Guru & friend, Krishna. Arjuna embraces his ‘Ego-self’ totally, & in this totality he is humbled to seek the counsel of Krishna

In Itihāsa - Purāna (the epics) one finds many brave men & women, including Gods like Rāma & Krishna, going through their own challenges with complete acceptance of their current state of self. Even Bhakti tradition is full of incidents of sadness, suffering, guilt, regret, the so-called, ‘shadow emotions’

There can be no transformation in denial. If one rejects current state of self, as bad ‘Ego’, then one is rejecting self-transformation itself, cuz’ there can be no transformation without recognition of the Ego-self

Yoga is a path of accepting the limited Ego-self, & realizing the True-Self hidden within/by it. A blanket rejection of the limited self as 'bad Ego' will only cause division & anxiety

Be kind, embrace your current state of Ego-self, & transform mindfully, with empathy & faith

What practices of self-acceptance have worked for you ? 👇🏼

We all have heard of the generalized notion that Tantra is body positive & doesn't reject bodily pursuits & pleasures. In fact, such a narrative is the foundational basis of s€xualized Tantra in popular culture. Even some scholars promote a stark binary that Tantra accepts the physical, while Yoga & Vedanta reject it

Just want to state here that one needs to be careful about generalizing ideas from Indic spirituality

There are Tantric lineages that have sheer disregard for the body. For them body is to be rejected & shunned. Some Tantrics also use extreme body-mortification practices as self-sacrifice. So, (traditional) Tantra doesnt always ‘pamper’ the body & its pleasures

Over years, I’ve had interesting interactions with some genuine Tantric Sadhus, mainly from 2 Tantric sects that could be considered 'extreme' from modern standards - the Kapalika & Kalamukha

This is an incident from 2014, during my stay with my teacher who was a Mahant (Abbot of a Monastery)

It was lunch time, & we were finalizing designs for beds for 2015 Kumbha mela. Suddenly, walked in a Kapalika Sadhu. He was very tall (6.4’), lean, with dreads till his knees, dressed in all black, with many skull necklaces & a human femur in his hand

He came in straight, stood & shouted a greeting banging his right foot hard on the ground. We all greeted him

With his blood-shot eyes he asked my teacher, ‘Kitne Moordey hain yahan?’ which literally means, ‘How many corpses do you have here?’. We disciples were shocked by his choice of coarse words. But our teacher calmly replied that there were half a dozen in the monastery. Replying with a Hmm, he walked away to the lunch hall (Bhandara) with the same stoic poise he had walked in with

Later, my teacher clarified that he was a high strature Sadhu & that in their Tantric lineage they recognize only 2 levels of beings, ones who are Self-realized & others who are not. Those who are not, are categorized as corpses. We were relieved when the context was clarified

Though such Tantric sects have become rare, one can find some genuine Sadhus if one knows how to

Last year, in Rishikesh, we met this sweet little man dressed up as a Kapalika Sadhu

.
Let life take away everything from you,
everything that you are not.
So it can make you realize

I am in love with ageing. Yes! I am truly enjoying watching this body age. Like a curious child I am amazed at how the body complains at efforts that it once managed with youthful zest. It’s quite an eye-opener to notice how hard it is to drop body-fat now as compared to my competitive bodybuilding days. I chuckle at the fact that I can’t manage activities & effort that were a breeze just a decade ago. I enthusiastically wait to regrow my beard every few months just to be surprised by the growing number of grey hair, &, above all, the gradually receeding hairline, the ever growing crows feet, the sagging skin, pigmentation, the faintly crackling joints, they all have become my besties now. I deeply appreciate how my ageing body has made me value it even more & made me disciplined towards maintaining what I consider my physical ‘home’ for now…

In Hatha Yogic terms the body is addressed as a Ghata, a baked clay pot. The pot is said to ‘house’ contents only for a certain time period. For me, it’s beautiful to see how life entered this pot some decades ago, how life is ‘life-ing’ itself through the years, & how the pot endures on despite the bruises & batterings.

In due course, a day will come when this pot will crack & the life within it will be released. Then, life will ‘life’ itself someplace else - in another pot. I await with curiosity to go through that beautiful process of Death,  the time when this pot will eventually break. Life will go on, repeatedly housing itself in temporary accomodations that are beyond my idea of I, me & myself, & even beyond my concept of 'my body'.

So sacred is this ritual of Life n' Death for me that being alive has itself become my prayer.

We all are ageing, willingly or unwillingly. I choose to age willingly with total acceptance of what life presents in its journey, from one pot to the next.

#lifequotes #ageing #yogateacher #lifeanddeath
As many go about doing goal-setting for 2024, here are some simple, yet poignant reminders from Bhagavad Gita that could help.

Today we celebrate Bhagavad Gita Jayanti, the Birthday of Shrimad Bhagavad Gita.

It would be natural to ask, why are we celebrating the Birthday of a book?

To know this, we have to understand that Bhagavad Gita is not merely a book, & therefore it shouldn’t be treated like one.

It is, what is called in the Yogic tradition as, a Shāstra, i.e., a scripture, a science, technology or methodology.

Shāstra in Sanskrit comes from the etymological root which means, the one that releases via its teachings.

So, this scripture has a clear purpose, i.e., to release the individual from their own misconceptions of self.

Therefore, it is not to be merely read (like a book), but is to be studied, practiced and reflected upon continuously till the goal that it promises is reached.

I have been delving into chanting, study & practice of the Bhagavad Gita for the last 40 years now, and in my own experience, I have seen Bhagavad Gita work like an Algorithm. Algorithm in the sense that as I have grown with the Gita, it has revealed to me exactly what I need.
Three decades ago the Gita revealed to me what I needed as a teen, then it revealed to me what I needed as a youth, now it helps me consolidate my life through existential insights – the same Gita, has always given me answers and solutions for where I am at. Thus, for me, the Gita has always been responsive and receptive.

For this very reason, Bhagavad Gita is considered a compassionate mother, because she knows what to give to her child for it to flourish, & in this sense, the Gita Shāstra is addressed as a Goddess.Today is the birth of this deity, Mother Gita.

I have much to say, but will end for now with a short quote by Gandhi that echoes the above point,

“The Gita is the universal mother. She turns away nobody. Her door is wide open to anyone who knocks.”

Greetings on Gita Jayanti 🙏🏾

How have the teachings of the Gita helped you ?

“Whose family doesn’t have faults? Who is never afflicted by illnesses? Who hasn't faced failures? Whose is endowed with lasting happiness? Its your behavior that speaks about you, your speech talks about your country, treating others respectfully creates affection and how you eat creates your body.” 

If you have a habit of beating yourself up with your thoughts, then remember the above quote from an ancient Sanskrit scripture called, Chanakyaneeti Darpana. The author of this treatise, Chanakya, was one of the wisest men of ancient India. He lived around 4 century BC and was a philosopher, scholar, political adviser, logician, economist and a statesman. Though a spiritual scholar on one end, he was also a down right practical person on the other. His advice, given way back in 4th Century BC, is still so relevant. 

Friends, Relax ! Don’t be so hard on yourself. Its okay to not be okay today. Tomorrow is a new day to create a new reality. Get up, dust yourself, and move on. After all, we are all a Work In Progress.

Don’t whip yourself because you are not perfect, no one is. Everyone has their troubles and everyone has their struggles. So, don’t focus on faults, don’t spend energy on defects, don’t keep reminding yourself of your shortcomings. Be Thankful for what you have, Know your Positives, Find your Clarity and Focus on what needs to be Done rather than what you don’t want to happen.

Have a cheerful end of the year.
Sending love filled hugs to all ❤️

Today is a very important day for the Yogis in India, it's Dattatreya Jayanti, the day of Lord Dattatreya who is considered the ‘Guru Principle’ – Guru Tattva. He is the primary deity of most renunciate ascetics, Yogis & Sadhus. This ‘teacher of teachers’ is so important that even the incarnating Gods go to him for knowledge

He cannot be understood as a concept, only as consciousness. One can only cognize him by becoming him. He is the original anti-authority of Yogic culture, taking all concepts & turning them on their head for us to emerge out of our minds. As a principle, he is the Avadhoot of Tantrics, the Aulia of Sufis, the holy-fool of Christians & the crazy oracle elder of the indigenous tribes of the world

He makes the seeker challenge norms, breaks their mindset & unwrap what lies within. Only beyond mind does his domain begin, if you can get there through self-effort & grace, you are welcome, or else, find yourself someone else

He is a strict disciplinarian, yet his love is as tender as that of a mother’s hug. He does not molly-coddle, yet his is the most secure lap to rest your head-on. He topples every ladder, he demolishes every structure that emerges from the recesses of mental constructs, that’s how he works. Words, language, scriptures & holy books squirm at his feet for he is beyond any tangible expression. He is represented as a wanderer ascetic yet he is the stable foundation of Yogic knowledge system. He is only accessible through Tapas, no non-sense view of life, sharp intellect & naked devotion of a loving heart

He inspires through perplexing ways, he teaches with the strictest of discipline, he guides with a keen eye of a parent and he supports with unconditional love. In this sense, he truly is the Guru of the Gurus

Where will you find him?, only in your heart. How will you reach him? only by strongest of Vairagya - dropping all that you are not. Silence is his expression, solitude is his abode. He is never in the grey, yet you find him when you go beyond the black and white

My salutations to Datta Guru, today & always. Thank you for holding my hand & showing me the way. All that I am is because of him. Gurudeva Datta 🙏🏾

It’s that time of year when we go all in to manifest New Year Resolutions. It’s good to have goals & pursue them, but we need to be aware of a few things here

For decades I used to make New Year resolutions out of a sense of inner lack. My low self-esteem would unconsciously compel me to raise bench-marks so high that they would be beyond my reach. The lesser I felt about myself, the higher the bench mark would be. I would strive hard, give it all that I had got, but would either exhaust myself or inadvertently give up and fall into the puddle of guilt and resentment. Every New Year Resolution would thus result in lowering my confidence and my sense of inner lack would sink further

Using the wisdom of Yoga philosophy helped a lot to resolve this issue. I learned the secret of Small Steps – to create goals not to fill the inner void of low self-esteem but for the sheer joy of experiencing a newer dimension of myself

Here are some realizations and reflections that have helped me, hope they help those who are in similar situation

1) When I would catch myself rushing to set new goals, I would ask myself, ‘What’s the rush?’. This would help me pause, reflect on my impulsiveness and be patient 

2) Don’t do what you don’t enjoy. If you have to do it anyway, learn to enjoy it, or be clear about that fact that you have to do it even though you dont enjoy it

3) Before setting goals be very, very objective about your circumstances and capabilities. Be realistic and deeply reflect on the impulse and sense of lack that’s making you set goals. Your goals should be ‘your's’, they should neither be compelled by social trends nor be pushed by peer pressure, especially stuff of social media

4) Realize that you cannot achieve everything all the time, there is no need to have everything or please everyone. You don’t have to be perfect, you just have to be your self

5) Above all, remember that every long journey is made up of smaller steps. You can realize lofty goals by breaking them into smaller parts and pursuing them joyfully without anxiety

Take it easy, easy does it 

Share this with friends

Happy New Year ❤️

I do handstand, therefore I am fit.
I run marathon, therefore I am fit.
I deadlift 400 lbs, therefore I am fit.
I have six pack, therefore I am fit.
I do 3 min. planks, therefore I am fit.
.
Above generalizations are uni-dimensional but Fitness is not. These goals are fine as far as self-motivation goes, but they are in no way a reflection of general fitness. I have seen bodybuilders who can’t sprint even for a minute. I have met marathoners stiff as a tree trunk. I have met anorexic teenagers proud of their six-pack and I have also met hand-standing Yogis who couldn’t sit still for 5 mins.
.
General fitness is an overall state of physical wellbeing which is a fine balance between aspects of mind, body, lifestyle, habits and inner peace. Fitness is a whole, not a part.
.
Fitness extends beyond the physical; it encompasses mental well-being, emotional resilience, and overall vitality. To truly embrace fitness, we must view it holistically, recognizing the interconnectedness of mind, body, and spirit, fostering a balanced and sustainable approach to our well-being.
.
Most importantly, I feel, the definition of Fitness is highly personalized. Sports persons have their own definition of fitness, their own benchmarks, which may not be practical for non-sports persons. 
.
Why am I saying all this? 
....because social media, which I feel is an amazing resource for self-motivation, has unfortunately become a source for blind pursuit of fitness trends without consideration to personal ability.
.
Just cuz some one is deadlifting, you dont have to 
Just cuz someone ran a marathon, you dont have to
.
Recognize what is it that will make you healthy & puruse that specific goal over time, as a lifestyle & not as a trend
.
If getting fit is your new year’s resolution, please make sure you consult a personal trainer / sports coach / gym instructor or expert in the fields that you seek to pursue and get an initial assessment done before you start off. 
.
Above all, do it for yourself and not for Likes on social media or as a trend that everyone is doing

Many Yoga practitioners limit themselves only to physical practices because they link Yoga to their idea of ‘God’, & therefore to an organized religion. I understand many may not have had comfortable experiences with an idea of ‘God’ &/or institutions of ‘God’ (organized religion) & therefore it's natural that they project their anxieties or views on Yogic spirituality

But, 'God' is a fluid concept & there's no single, specific idea of ‘God’ in Yogic knowledge systems. Followers of opposing views of ‘God’ have thrived side by side in India over millennia. Even Gita allows for such freedom of interpretation, Krishna says in 4:11, “Howsoever they seek Me, even so, do I approach them. All follow My path in every way”

This fluidity is because Yoga is primarily a pursuit of absolute Truth (Sat), not necessarily a pursuit of ‘God’. But, since the Truth takes the form of ‘God’/‘Gods’ Yoga can be seen as a pursuit of Truth and/or of ‘God’

Traditionally, view of ‘God’ depends on Yogic lineage. Here are some diverse ideas across Veda & Tantra. One can choose any to grow spiritually, for it’s not about who one worships, but how the worship transforms the seeker

• Theism (Bhakti lineages)
• Polytheism (Hindus worship many deities)
• Monotheism (Vaishnava, Shaiva lineages)
• A-theism (Sankhya, Bauddha)
• Deism (nature deities like river goddesses)
• Pantheism (Vedic Gods permeating the universe/nature– like Sun God, Surya Dev)
• Divine as human/animal forms (Krishna/Saints/Hanuman)
• Divine without form, as Absolute consciousness (Brahman)
· God as Creator, Sustainer, Destroyer
• God as a principle (Tattva)
• God as one’s own Guru, child, lover, friend, mother, father & also the guest
• Spiritual illusion too is considered a Goddess (Maya-Shakti)
• Most importantly, God in each one of us, in hearts of all (says Krishna in Gita)

Let ideas of ‘God’ not stop you from embracing Yoga. There are diverse views of Divine in Yoga for all

Even if one doesn't want to prescribe to any view, one's own undeniable (Self) existence itself is ‘God’, the Truth (Sat)

Nothing is not Divine, nothing is not ‘God’, nothing is not ‘Truth’ in Yoga - I find such a broad view very liberating

The other day I saw a sponsored post – “Do Camel pose to cure back-pain” - how simple it sounds, right ?
But is it really ?

Human individual is not so simplistic that we make blanket statements like the above. Our personhood is not unidimensional, it is complex, multilayered, interactive & inheres a larger matrix

That’s why, offering unidimensional, generalized, linear solutions to problems needs to be avoided by Yoga Teachers, which is common in the Yoga world, especially in the Therapy area, 
Eg: 
Migraine? – Do Headstand
Shortness of breath? – Do Pranayama
Insomnia? – Do Yoga Nidra

I've even heard some teachers make statements like, "Just do Yoga, no need to do anything else" - which I feel is irresponsible

Simply saying “Do this pose to cure back pain” won't help because the causes of the person’s back pain could be many. Causes need to be examined one by one. Its easy to assign the cause to physical body & give a physical solution (like, do this pose), but the cause could have its origins in ergonomics, diet, sleep, habits, foot-wear, posture, inactivity, heredity, past-traumas & so many other factors, working together

Individuals exist simultaneously at multiple personality dimensions – physical, mental, emotional, behavioral, social, cultural & spiritual, that constantly interact to keep them alive & thriving. We live in a crucuble of constant push & pull

The multidimensional interconnection of a human person needs to be kept in mind by Yoga Teachers & Therapists when providing solutions, even though simplistic solutions have the capacity to bring in more business

On an important note though, it is very easy for a Yoga teacher to get carried away by the glamour of teaching and conveniently ignore personal sadhana (one's own sincere yoga practice) for the highs that the role brings.

A diligent sadhana infuses energy that helps one stabilize in the role of a Yoga teacher. Ignoring sadhana could lead to professional burnout, physical fatigue, mental exhaustion and an eventual self-dissatisfaction with the thought of teaching.

There can be no yoga professional without first being a yoga practitioner. ❤

There you go, I said it. Wanted to address this issue since some time.

As Yoga teachers we love teaching Yoga & guiding people. We identify with it as our purpose etc. It’s all good, but some amount of caution needs to be exercised.

Here is something I want to ask you all, because this important topic is never discussed in Yoga Teacher Trainings. Teachers are not taught how to handle success & failure as professionals.

So, here is my question.

Have you been using your Yoga and/or Spiritual work for self-worth & self-esteem boost? Has Yoga teaching become a crutch for you to feel good about yourself?

It could have happened unconsciously, but here is why doing that may not be good for your mental health.

• External Dependency

If approval from students becomes the primary source of validation it could lead to emotional dependencies, creating emotional ups and downs based on external feedback. Eg: More sign-ups for a workshop makes one feel worthy, less sign-ups creates worthlessness.

• Exhaustion & Disillusionment

Constantly tying self-worth to the success of yoga teaching may lead to burnout. Disillusionment may arise if classes don't meet expected standards. Overcommitting to teaching classes or pushing oneself beyond healthy limits in the pursuit of validation can compromise physical and mental well-being.

• Identity Entanglement

Identifying too closely with the role of a yoga teacher (asmita) may result in an entanglement of personal identity with professional success & worthiness. This can make it hard to separate one's sense of self from the demands and expectations of the teaching role.

• Feeling Inauthentic

Generating self-worth primarily through yoga teaching can influence teaching authenticity due to not being in one’s own clarity. There may be a tendency to follow social trends & teach what others are teaching rather than offering genuine, honest guidance based on personal experience, thus potentially compromising the quality of teaching.

Please reflect on how you handle your Yoga Teaching work and your esteem dependencies on it, and seek help if needed.

Share with fellow Yoga teachers 🙏🏾
